paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD, Duke of Gloucester, solus$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, Duke of Gloucester, enters alone.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Now is the winter of our discontent$NEWLINE$Made glorious summer by this son of York,$NEWLINE$And all the clouds that loured upon our house$NEWLINE$In the deep bosom of the ocean buried.$NEWLINE$Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths,$NEWLINE$Our bruisèd arms hung up for monuments,$NEWLINE$Our stern alarums changed to merry meetings,$NEWLINE$Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.$NEWLINE$Grim-visaged war hath smoothed his wrinkled front;$NEWLINE$And now, instead of mounting barbèd steeds$NEWLINE$To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,$NEWLINE$He capers nimbly in a lady’s chamber$NEWLINE$To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.$NEWLINE$But I, that am not shaped for sportive tricks,$NEWLINE$Nor made to court an amorous looking glass;$NEWLINE$I, that am rudely stamped and want love’s majesty$NEWLINE$To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;$NEWLINE$I, that am curtailed of this fair proportion,$NEWLINE$Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,$NEWLINE$Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time$NEWLINE$Into this breathing world, scarce half made up,$NEWLINE$And that so lamely and unfashionable$NEWLINE$That dogs bark at me as I halt by them—$NEWLINE$Why, I, in this weak piping time of peace,$NEWLINE$Have no delight to pass away the time,$NEWLINE$Unless to see my shadow in the sun$NEWLINE$And descant on mine own deformity.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Now all of my family’s troubles have come to a glorious end, thanks to my brother, King Edward IV. All the clouds that threatened the York family have vanished and turned to sunshine. Now we wear the wreaths of victory on our heads. We’ve taken off our armor and weapons and hung them up as decorations. Instead of hearing trumpets call us to battle, we dance at parties. We get to wear easy smiles on our faces rather than the grim expressions of war. Instead of charging toward our enemies on armored horses, we dance for our ladies in their chambers, accompanied by sexy songs on the lute. But I’m not made to be a seducer, or to make faces at myself in the mirror. I was badly made and don’t have the looks to strut my stuff in front of pretty sluts. I’ve been cheated of a nice body and face, or even normal proportions. I am deformed, spit out from my mother’s womb prematurely and so badly formed that dogs bark at me as I limp by them. I’m left with nothing to do in this weak, idle peacetime, unless I want to look at my lumpy shadow in the sun and sing about that.$NEWLINE$that

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And therefore, since I cannot prove a lover$NEWLINE$To entertain these fair well-spoken days,$NEWLINE$I am determinèd to prove a villain$NEWLINE$And hate the idle pleasures of these days.$NEWLINE$Plots have I laid, inductions dangerous,$NEWLINE$By drunken prophecies, libels and dreams,$NEWLINE$To set my brother Clarence and the king$NEWLINE$In deadly hate, the one against the other;$NEWLINE$And if King Edward be as true and just$NEWLINE$As I am subtle, false, and treacherous,$NEWLINE$This day should Clarence closely be mewed up$NEWLINE$About a prophecy which says that “G”$NEWLINE$Of Edward’s heirs the murderer shall be.$NEWLINE$Dive, thoughts, down to my soul. Here Clarence comes.
paragraphs.translated:
Since I can’t amuse myself by being a lover, I’ve decided to become a villain. I’ve set dangerous plans in motion, using lies, drunken prophecies, and stories about dreams to set my brother Clarence and the king against each other. If King Edward is as honest and fair-minded as I am deceitful and cruel, then Clarence is going to be locked away in prison today because of a prophecy that
“G” will murder Edward’s children. Oh, time to hide what I’m thinking—here comes Clarence.$NEWLINE$“G”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter CLARENCE, guarded, and BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE enters, surrounded by guards, with BRAKENBURY.$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY

paragraphs.original: Brother, good day. What means this armèd guard$NEWLINE$That waits upon your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: Good afternoon, brother. Why are you surrounded by these armed guards?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$His majesty,$NEWLINE$Tend'ring my person’s safety, hath appointed$NEWLINE$This conduct to convey me to the Tower.
paragraphs.translated:
CLARENCE$NEWLINE$His majesty is so concerned about my personal safety that he has ordered them to conduct me to the
Tower.$NEWLINE$Tower$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Upon what cause?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You’re being arrested? Why?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Because my name is George.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Because my name is George.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Alack, my lord, that fault is none of yours.$NEWLINE$He should, for that, commit your godfathers.$NEWLINE$O, belike his majesty hath some intent$NEWLINE$That you shall be new christened in the Tower.$NEWLINE$But what’s the matter, Clarence? May I know?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That’s not your fault! He should imprison the person who named you, instead. Maybe the king is sending you to the Tower to have you renamed. But, really, what’s going on, Clarence? Can you tell me?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Yea, Richard, when I know, for I protest$NEWLINE$As yet I do not. But, as I can learn,$NEWLINE$He hearkens after prophecies and dreams,$NEWLINE$And from the crossrow plucks the letter G,$NEWLINE$G$NEWLINE$And says a wizard told him that by “G”$NEWLINE$His issue disinherited should be.$NEWLINE$And for my name of George begins with G,$NEWLINE$G$NEWLINE$It follows in his thought that I am he.$NEWLINE$These, as I learn, and such like toys as these$NEWLINE$Have moved his Highness to commit me now.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you as soon as I know, Richard, because at this point I have no idea. All I’ve been able to find out is that our brother the king has been listening to prophecies and dreams. He picked out the letter “G” from the alphabet and said a wizard told him that “G” will take the throne away from his children. He thinks “G” is me. I’ve learned that this, along with other frivolous reasons like it, is what prompted the king to send me to prison.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, this it is when men are ruled by women.$NEWLINE$'Tis not the king that sends you to the Tower.$NEWLINE$My Lady Grey his wife, Clarence, ’tis she$NEWLINE$That tempers him to this extremity.$NEWLINE$Was it not she and that good man of worship,$NEWLINE$Anthony Woodeville, her brother there,$NEWLINE$That made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower,$NEWLINE$From whence this present day he is delivered?$NEWLINE$We are not safe, Clarence. We are not safe.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Well, this is what happens when men let themselves be ruled by women. The king isn’t the one sending you to the Tower, Clarence. It’s his wife, Lady Grey, who got him to do this. Remember how she and her brother, Anthony Woodeville, made him send Lord Hastings to the Tower? Hastings was just released. We’re not safe, Clarence, we’re not safe.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$By heaven, I think there is no man is secure$NEWLINE$But the queen’s kindred and night-walking heralds$NEWLINE$That trudge betwixt the king and Mistress Shore.$NEWLINE$Heard ye not what an humble suppliant$NEWLINE$Lord Hastings was to her for his delivery?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$By God, I think the only people who are safe are the queen’s own relatives and the late-night messengers the king uses to fetch his mistress, Mistress Shore. Did you hear how Lord Hastings had to beg the queen to be freed?$NEWLINE$are

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Humbly complaining to her deity$NEWLINE$Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty.$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you what: I think it is our way,$NEWLINE$If we will keep in favor with the king,$NEWLINE$To be her men and wear her livery.$NEWLINE$The jealous o'erworn widow and herself,$NEWLINE$Since that our brother dubbed them gentlewomen,$NEWLINE$Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$Hastings got his freedom by bowing down to that goddess. And I’ll tell you what. If we want to stay in the king’s good graces, we’re going have to act like the
mistress’s servants, too. Ever since our brother made them gentlewomen, Mistress Shore and the queen have become mighty busybodies in our kingdom.$NEWLINE$mistress’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I beseech your Graces both to pardon me.$NEWLINE$His majesty hath straitly given in charge$NEWLINE$That no man shall have private conference,$NEWLINE$Of what degree soever, with his brother.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon, my lords, but the king gave me orders that no one, however high in rank, should speak privately to Clarence.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Even so. An please your Worship, Brakenbury,$NEWLINE$You may partake of anything we say.$NEWLINE$We speak no treason, man. We say the king$NEWLINE$Is wise and virtuous, and his noble queen$NEWLINE$Well struck in years, fair, and not jealous.$NEWLINE$We say that Shore’s wife hath a pretty foot,$NEWLINE$A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue,$NEWLINE$And that the queen’s kindred are made gentlefolks.$NEWLINE$How say you, sir? Can you deny all this?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$All right. If you like, Brakenbury, you can listen to anything we say. We’re not saying anything treasonous, man. We say the king is wise and good, and his noble queen is getting old, pretty, and not jealous. And that Mr. Shore’s wife has nice feet, cherry lips, pretty eyes, and a very pleasant way of expressing herself. And, finally, that the queen’s relatives have all been elevated in rank. What do you think? Is there anything inaccurate in that?

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$With this, my lord, myself have naught to do.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I have nothing to do with what you’re talking about, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Naught to do with Mistress Shore? I tell thee, fellow,$NEWLINE$He that doth naught with her, excepting one,$NEWLINE$Were best he do it secretly, alone.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$“Nothing to do” with Mrs. Shore! I tell you, mister, there’s only one man who gets to do
“nothing,” with her and not be punished for it. Everyone else had better keep their “nothings” to themselves.$NEWLINE$“nothing,”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$What one, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$Who is that, my lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Her husband, knave. Wouldst thou betray me?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Her husband, you rascal. Are you going to get me in trouble?

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I do beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal$NEWLINE$Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
paragraphs.translated:
BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I beg your
Grace to pardon me, and now please stop talking to Clarence.$NEWLINE$Grace$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$We know you have a job to do, Brakenbury, and we’ll do what you say.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$We are the queen’s abjects and must obey.—$NEWLINE$Brother, farewell. I will unto the king,$NEWLINE$And whatsoe'er you will employ me in,$NEWLINE$Were it to call King Edward’s widow “sister,”$NEWLINE$I will perform it to enfranchise you.$NEWLINE$Meantime, this deep disgrace in brotherhood$NEWLINE$Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$We are required to serve the queen, and we must obey her. Farewell, brother. I will go to the king and do whatever you want me to, even if it’s to call my brother’s wife “sister,” in order to set you free. But just so you know, I am very angry about how our own brother has treated you, angrier than you can imagine.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I know it pleaseth neither of us well.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$It doesn’t make either of us happy, I know.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Well, your imprisonment shall not be long.$NEWLINE$I will deliver you or else lie for you.$NEWLINE$Meantime, have patience.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Well, your imprisonment won’t last long. I will either get you out, lying if I have to, or stay in prison in your place. In the meantime, be patient.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I must perforce. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I have no choice. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CLARENCE, BRAKENBURY, and guard$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE, BRAKENBURY, and the guards exit.$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Go tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.$NEWLINE$Simple, plain Clarence, I do love thee so$NEWLINE$That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,$NEWLINE$If heaven will take the present at our hands.$NEWLINE$But who comes here? The new-delivered Hastings?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Go walk the path that you will never return from. Dumb, honest Clarence. I love you so much that I’ll send your soul to heaven very soon—if heaven will accept anything from me, that is. But who’s coming? The newly released Hastings?

paragraphs.original: Enter HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS enters.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Good time of day unto my gracious lord.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Good afternoon, my dear lord!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain.$NEWLINE$Well are you welcome to the open air.$NEWLINE$How hath your lordship brooked imprisonment?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The same to you, my lord! Welcome to the open air again. How did you tolerate prison?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must.$NEWLINE$But I shall live, my lord, to give them thanks$NEWLINE$That were the cause of my imprisonment.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$With patience, noble lord, as prisoners must. But I will live to thank those who sent me there.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No doubt, no doubt; and so shall Clarence too,$NEWLINE$For they that were your enemies are his$NEWLINE$And have prevailed as much on him as you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No doubt, no doubt. And so will Clarence, for your enemies are his enemies, and they have gotten the upper hand of him as well as of you.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$More pity that the eagle should be mewed$NEWLINE$While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$It’s a shame that we eagles are caged up while the vultures are free to do whatever they please.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What news abroad?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What’s the news abroad?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$No news so bad abroad as this at home:$NEWLINE$The king is sickly, weak and melancholy,$NEWLINE$And his physicians fear him mightily.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$No news as bad as the news at home: The king is sickly, weak, and depressed, and his doctors are very afraid he’s going to die

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Now, by Saint Paul, that news is bad indeed.$NEWLINE$O, he hath kept an evil diet long,$NEWLINE$And overmuch consumed his royal person.$NEWLINE$'Tis very grievous to be thought upon.$NEWLINE$Where is he, in his bed?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Now, by George, that really is terrible news. Oh, the king has abused his body with bad habits for a long time, and it’s finally taking its toll on him. Very sad. Where is he, in his bed?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$He is.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$He is.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Go you before, and I will follow you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You go ahead, and I will follow you.

paragraphs.original: Exit HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS exits.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: He cannot live, I hope, and must not die$NEWLINE$Till George be packed with post-horse up to heaven.$NEWLINE$I’ll in to urge his hatred more to Clarence$NEWLINE$With lies well steeled with weighty arguments,$NEWLINE$And, if I fail not in my deep intent,$NEWLINE$Clarence hath not another day to live;$NEWLINE$Which done, God take King Edward to His mercy,$NEWLINE$And leave the world for me to bustle in.$NEWLINE$For then I’ll marry Warwick’s youngest daughter.$NEWLINE$What though I killed her husband and her father?$NEWLINE$The readiest way to make the wench amends$NEWLINE$Is to become her husband and her father;$NEWLINE$The which will I, not all so much for love$NEWLINE$As for another secret close intent$NEWLINE$By marrying her which I must reach unto.$NEWLINE$But yet I run before my horse to market.$NEWLINE$Clarence still breathes; Edward still lives and reigns.$NEWLINE$When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
paragraphs.translated: The king won’t live, I hope. But he’d better not die till Clarence is sent packing to heaven. I’ll go see the king and, with carefully argued lies, get him to hate Clarence even more than he already does. If my plan succeeds, Clarence doesn’t have another day to live. Then God’s free to send King Edward to heaven, too, and leave me the world to run around in! I’ll marry the earl of Warwick’s youngest daughter, Lady Anne. So what if I killed her husband and her father? The best way to make up for the girl’s losses is to become what she’s lost: a husband and a father. So that’s what I’ll do, not because I love her but because I’ll get something out of it. But I’m running ahead of myself. Clarence is still alive; Edward is not only alive, he’s king. Only when they’re dead can I start to count my gains.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the corse of Henry the Sixth, on a bier, with halberds to guard it, Lady ANNE being the mourner, accompanied by gentlemen$NEWLINE$ANNE
paragraphs.translated:
The corpse of KING HENRY VI is carried in on a
bier, followed by Lady ANNE, dressed in mourning clothes, and armed guards.$NEWLINE$KING HENRY VI$NEWLINE$bier$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Set down, set down your honorable load,$NEWLINE$If honor may be shrouded in a hearse,$NEWLINE$Whilst I awhile obsequiously lament$NEWLINE$Th' untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Set down your honorable load, men, if there is ever any honor in being dead. I want to mourn the cruel death of this good man. Look at the noble king’s poor cold body—the measly remains of the Lancaster family.

paragraphs.original: They set down the bier
paragraphs.translated: They put down the bier.

paragraphs.original: Poor key-cold figure of a holy king,$NEWLINE$Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood,$NEWLINE$Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost$NEWLINE$To hear the lamentations of poor Anne,$NEWLINE$Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered son,$NEWLINE$Stabbed by the selfsame hand that made these wounds.$NEWLINE$Lo, in these windows that let forth thy life$NEWLINE$I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes.$NEWLINE$O, cursèd be the hand that made these holes;$NEWLINE$Cursèd the heart that had the heart to do it;$NEWLINE$Cursèd the blood that let this blood from hence.$NEWLINE$More direful hap betide that hated wretch$NEWLINE$That makes us wretched by the death of thee$NEWLINE$Than I can wish to wolves, to spiders, toads,$NEWLINE$Or any creeping venomed thing that lives.$NEWLINE$If ever he have child, abortive be it,$NEWLINE$Prodigious, and untimely brought to light,$NEWLINE$Whose ugly and unnatural aspect$NEWLINE$May fright the hopeful mother at the view,$NEWLINE$And that be heir to his unhappiness.
paragraphs.translated:
His royal blood has drained right out of him. I hope I can talk to your ghost, Henry, without breaking church laws. I want you to hear my sorrow. My
husband was murdered by the same man who stabbed you. My tears now fall into the holes where your life leaked out. I curse the man who made these holes. I curse the man’s heart who had the heart to stab you. And I curse the man’s blood who shed your blood. I want the man who made me suffer by killing you to face a more terrible end than I could wish on spiders, toads, and all the poisonous, venomous things things alive. If he ever has a child, let it be born prematurely, and let it look like a monster—so ugly and unnatural that the sight of it frightens its own mother.$NEWLINE$husband$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If ever he have wife, let her be made$NEWLINE$More miserable by the death of him$NEWLINE$Than I am made by my poor lord and thee.—$NEWLINE$Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load,$NEWLINE$Taken from Paul’s to be interrèd there.
paragraphs.translated: And if he ever has a wife, let her be more miserable when he dies than I am now. Guards, let’s continue on to Chertsey monastery, carrying this holy burden you picked up at St. Paul’s monastery.

paragraphs.original: They take up the bier
paragraphs.translated: They pick up the bier.

paragraphs.original: And still, as you are weary of this weight,$NEWLINE$Rest you, whiles I lament King Henry’s corse.
paragraphs.translated: When it gets too heavy, rest, and I’ll lament over King Henry’s corpse some more.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD, Duke of Gloucester$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD enters.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Stay, you that bear the corse, and set it down.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Halt, corpse bearers, and put down your load.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$What black magician conjures up this fiend$NEWLINE$To stop devoted charitable deeds?
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$What wicked magician has conjured up this devil to interrupt this sacred burial rite?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Villains, set down the corse or, by Saint Paul,$NEWLINE$I’ll make a corse of him that disobeys.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Villains, set down the corpse, or I’ll make a corpse of you.$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$My lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$My lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Unmannered dog, stand thou when I command!—$NEWLINE$Advance thy halberd higher than my breast,$NEWLINE$Or by Saint Paul I’ll strike thee to my foot$NEWLINE$And spurn upon thee, beggar, for thy boldness.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Rude dog! Stop when I command you to! And put up your weapon so it’s not pointing at my chest, or I’ll strike you to the ground and trample on you, you beggar, for being so bold.

paragraphs.original: They set down the bier
paragraphs.translated: They put down the bier.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$(to gentlemen and halberds)$NEWLINE$(to gentlemen and halberds)$NEWLINE$What, do you tremble? Are you all afraid?$NEWLINE$Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal,$NEWLINE$And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.—$NEWLINE$Avaunt, thou dreadful minister of hell.$NEWLINE$Thou hadst but power over his mortal body;$NEWLINE$His soul thou canst not have. Therefore begone.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$(to the gentlemen and guards) What, are you trembling? You’re all afraid of him? Well, I can’t blame you. You’re only human, after all, and mortals can’t stand to look at the devil. (to RICHARD) Begone, you dreadful servant of hell. You only had power over my father-in-law’s body; you can’t have his soul. So get out.$NEWLINE$(to the gentlemen and guards)$NEWLINE$(to

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sweet saint, for charity, be not so curst.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sweet saint, for goodness’s sake, don’t be so angry.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Foul devil, for God’s sake, hence, and trouble us not,$NEWLINE$For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,$NEWLINE$Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.$NEWLINE$If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,$NEWLINE$Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Ugly devil, for God’s sake, get out of here and leave us alone. You have made the happy world into your hell, filling it with cursing cries and lamentations. If you enjoy looking at your awful deeds, take a look at this noteworthy example of your butcheries.

paragraphs.original: She points to the corse
paragraphs.translated: She points to the corpse.

paragraphs.original: O, gentlemen, see, see dead Henry’s wounds$NEWLINE$Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh!—$NEWLINE$Blush, blush, thou lump of foul deformity,$NEWLINE$For ’tis thy presence that exhales this blood$NEWLINE$From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.$NEWLINE$Thy deeds, inhuman and unnatural,$NEWLINE$Provokes this deluge most unnatural.—$NEWLINE$O God, which this blood mad’st, revenge his death!$NEWLINE$O earth, which this blood drink’st revenge his death!$NEWLINE$Either heaven with lightning strike the murderer dead,$NEWLINE$Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick,$NEWLINE$As thou dost swallow up this good king’s blood,$NEWLINE$Which his hell-governed arm hath butcherèd!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, gentlemen, look, look! Dead Henry’s wounds have opened up and are bleeding again! —Shame on you, you deformed lump. It’s your presence that draws out this blood from his empty veins. Your inhuman and unnatural actions have provoked this unnatural flood of blood. Oh God, who made this blood, revenge his death! Oh earth, which soaks up this blood, revenge his death! Either let heaven send lightning to strike the murderer dead or let the earth open wide and devour him, as it does this good king’s blood.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Lady, you know no rules of charity,$NEWLINE$Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Dear woman, you don’t know the rules of charity. When faced with bad, you’re supposed to turn it into good, and when subject to curses, you’re supposed to convert them into blessings.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Villain, thou know’st not law of God nor man.$NEWLINE$No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Villain, you don’t know the laws of God or of man. Even the fiercest wild animal has some touch of pity.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$But I know none, and therefore am no beast.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If I know nothing about pity, that must mean I’m not an animal.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$O, wonderful, when devils tell the truth!
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$It’s amazing to hear a devil speak the truth!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$More wonderful, when angels are so angry.$NEWLINE$Vouchsafe, divine perfection of a woman,$NEWLINE$Of these supposèd crimes to give me leave$NEWLINE$By circumstance but to acquit myself.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$It’s even stranger when an angel is so angry. Divine, perfect woman, give me a chance to prove in detail that I’m innocent of the evils you accuse me of.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Vouchsafe, defused infection of a man,$NEWLINE$Of these known evils but to give me leave$NEWLINE$By circumstance to curse thy cursèd self.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Contagious infection of humanity, give me a chance to condemn you for the evils I know you’ve committed.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have$NEWLINE$Some patient leisure to excuse myself.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You who are beautiful beyond words, calm down and let me explain myself.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make$NEWLINE$No excuse current but to hang thyself.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$You who are wicked beyond belief, the only “explanation” I’ll accept from you is for you to hang yourself.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$By such despair I should accuse myself.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Such an expression of despair would only prove that I was guilty.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$And by despairing shalt thou stand excused$NEWLINE$For doing worthy vengeance on thyself$NEWLINE$That didst unworthy slaughter upon others.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Maybe, but if you killed yourself, it would also show that you felt some guilt for killing others.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Say that I slew them not.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Let’s say I didn’t kill them.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Then say they were not slain.$NEWLINE$But dead they are, and devilish slave, by thee.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Then you might as well say they’re not dead. But they are dead, and you killed them, you slave of the devil.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I did not kill your husband.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I did not kill your husband.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Why then, he is alive.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Well, then he must be alive.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edward’s hands.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No, he is dead. Edward killed him.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$In thy foul throat thou liest. Queen Margaret saw$NEWLINE$Thy murd'rous falchion smoking in his blood,$NEWLINE$The which thou once didst bend against her breast,$NEWLINE$But that thy brothers beat aside the point.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$You’re lying. Queen Margaret saw your sword steaming with his blood. It was the same sword you almost killed her with—and you would have killed her if my brothers hadn’t fought you off.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I was provokèd by her sland'rous tongue,$NEWLINE$That laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$She provoked me with her lying mouth, accusing me of crimes I didn’t commit.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Thou wast provokèd by thy bloody mind,$NEWLINE$That never dream’st on aught but butcheries.$NEWLINE$Didst thou not kill this king?
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$No, what provoked you was your own bloody mind, which never thinks about anything but butchering. You killed this king, didn’t you?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I grant you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes, I’ll grant you that.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Dost grant me, hedgehog? Then, God grant me too$NEWLINE$Thou mayst be damnèd for that wicked deed.$NEWLINE$O, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$You’ll grant me, you hedgehog? Then let God grant me that you’ll be damned for that wicked deed. Oh, he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The better for the King of heaven that hath him.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That will please God, who has him now.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$He is in heaven, where thou shalt never come.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$He is in heaven, where you will never go.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Let him thank me, that holp to send him thither,$NEWLINE$For he was fitter for that place than earth.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Let him thank me, who helped him get there. He’s better suited to be there than here.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$And thou unfit for any place but hell.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$And you’re not suited for any place except hell.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes, one place else, if you will hear me name it.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes, and one other place, if you’ll only let me name it.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Some dungeon.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Some dungeon.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your bedchamber.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your bedroom.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest!
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$There is no rest to be had in any bedroom where you are!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$So will it, madam till I lie with you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Exactly, madam, until I sleep with you.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$I hope so.
paragraphs.translated:
ANNE$NEWLINE$I
hope you’re right.$NEWLINE$hope$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I know so. But, gentle Lady Anne,$NEWLINE$To leave this keen encounter of our wits$NEWLINE$And fall something into a slower method—$NEWLINE$Is not the causer of the timeless deaths$NEWLINE$Of these Plantagenets, Henry and Edward,$NEWLINE$As blameful as the executioner?
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$I know I am. But, gentle Lady Anne, let’s stop this rapid-fire argument and move more slowly. Isn’t the person who caused the untimely deaths of these two
Plantagenets, Henry and Edward, as much to blame as the person who actually executed the murders?$NEWLINE$Plantagenets$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Thou wast the cause and most accursed effect.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$You’re both those people—responsible for both cause and effect.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your beauty was the cause of that effect—$NEWLINE$Your beauty, that did haunt me in my sleep$NEWLINE$To undertake the death of all the world,$NEWLINE$So I might live one hour in your sweet bosom.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your beauty caused what I did. It haunted me in my sleep. I would have killed the whole world just to be able spend one hour next to you.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$If I thought that, I tell thee, homicide,$NEWLINE$These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$If I believed you, murderer, I would take my nails and scratch that beauty right off my cheeks.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$These eyes could never endure that beauty’s wrack.$NEWLINE$You should not blemish it, if I stood by.$NEWLINE$As all the world is cheerèd by the sun,$NEWLINE$So I by that. It is my day, my life.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I couldn’t stand to see you destroy your beauty; you won’t touch it as long as I’m standing next to you. Just as everyone becomes cheerful from the sun, I’m cheered up by your looks. They are my daylight, my life.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Black night o'ershade thy day, and death thy life.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Then I hope night shadows your day, and death takes your life!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Curse not thyself, fair creature; thou art both.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Don’t damn yourself. You, fair lady, are both my day and my life.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$I would I were, to be revenged on thee.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I wish I were, so I could deprive you of both day and life.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$It is a quarrel most unnatural$NEWLINE$To be revenged on him that loveth thee.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$It’s strange that you want to take revenge on the person who loves you.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$It is a quarrel just and reasonable$NEWLINE$To be revenged on him that killed my husband.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$It’s just and reasonable that I want to take revenge on the person who killed my husband.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He that bereft thee, lady, of thy husband$NEWLINE$Did it to help thee to a better husband.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The man who killed your husband, dear lady, only did it to help you get a better husband.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$His better doth not breathe upon the earth.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$There is no better one on earth.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He lives that loves thee better than he could.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Wrong. There is a man who loves you better than your husband could.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Name him.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Name him.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Plantagenet.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Plantagenet.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Why, that was he.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Yes, that’s my husband’s name.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The selfsame name, but one of better nature.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Someone else has the same name, but he’s a better man.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Where is he?
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Where is this man?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Here.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Here.

paragraphs.original: She spitteth at him
paragraphs.translated: ANNE spits at him.$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: Why dost thou spit at me?
paragraphs.translated: Why do you spit at me?

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$If only I could spit poison.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Never came poison from so sweet a place.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Poison never came from such a sweet place.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Never hung poison on a fouler toad.$NEWLINE$Out of my sight! Thou dost infect mine eyes.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Poison never landed on such an ugly toad. Get out of my sight! You’re poisoning my eyes.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Thine eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your beautiful eyes, sweet lady, have infected mine with love.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.
paragraphs.translated:
ANNE$NEWLINE$I wish my eyes were
basilisks, so they could strike you dead!$NEWLINE$basilisks$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I would they were, that I might die at once,$NEWLINE$For now they kill me with a living death.$NEWLINE$Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,$NEWLINE$Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops.$NEWLINE$These eyes, which never shed remorseful tear—$NEWLINE$No, when my father York and Edward wept$NEWLINE$To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made$NEWLINE$When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;$NEWLINE$Nor when thy warlike father, like a child,$NEWLINE$Told the sad story of my father’s death$NEWLINE$And twenty times made pause to sob and weep,$NEWLINE$That all the standers-by had wet their cheeks$NEWLINE$Like trees bedashed with rain—in that sad time,$NEWLINE$My manly eyes did scorn an humble tear;$NEWLINE$And what these sorrows could not thence exhale$NEWLINE$Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.$NEWLINE$I never sued to friend, nor enemy;$NEWLINE$My tongue could never learn sweet smoothing word.$NEWLINE$But now thy beauty is proposed my fee,$NEWLINE$My proud heart sues, and prompts my tongue to speak.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I wish they were, so that I could die right now, because, at this point, I live a living death. Your eyes have made me cry, shamefully, like a child. I never cried before this. I didn’t cry when my father, York, and my brother Edward both wept at the death of my brother Rutland, whom Clifford slaughtered. And when your warrior-father recounted the sad story of my father’s death, pausing to sob twenty times in the course of the story so that all the bystanders ended up dripping tears like trees in a rainstorm—even then, I refused to cry. But your beauty has made me cry until I couldn’t see. I never tried to win over a friend or enemy with sweet words. I’m too proud for that. But if your beauty is the reward for sweet talk, I’ll talk.

paragraphs.original: She looks scornfully at him
paragraphs.translated: ANNE looks at him with disgust.$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: Teach not thy lip such scorn, for it were made$NEWLINE$For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.$NEWLINE$If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,$NEWLINE$Lo, here I lend thee this sharp-pointed sword,$NEWLINE$Which if thou please to hide in this true breast$NEWLINE$And let the soul forth that adoreth thee,$NEWLINE$I lay it naked to the deadly stroke$NEWLINE$And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
paragraphs.translated: Don’t curl your lips in scorn. They were made for kissing, not for contempt. If your vengeful heart can’t forgive me, here—take my sword and bury it in my heart so that my soul, which adores you, can be free. I open myself to being stabbed. In fact, I beg for death on my knees.

paragraphs.original: He kneels and lays his breast open; she offers at it with his sword
paragraphs.translated: He opens his shirt to expose his chest, and she points the sword toward it.

paragraphs.original: Nay, do not pause; for I did kill King Henry—$NEWLINE$But ’twas thy beauty that provokèd me.$NEWLINE$Nay, now dispatch; ’twas I that stabbed young Edward—$NEWLINE$But ’twas thy heavenly face that set me on.
paragraphs.translated: No, don’t pause, because I did kill King Henry, though it was your beauty that made me do it. Go ahead. And it was me who stabbed young Edward, though it was your heavenly face that set me to work.$NEWLINE$did$NEWLINE$was

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: She falls the sword
paragraphs.translated: ANNE lets the sword drop.$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: Take up the sword again, or take up me.
paragraphs.translated: Take up the sword again, or take me up.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Arise, dissembler. Though I wish thy death,$NEWLINE$I will not be the executioner.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Get up, liar. Though I wish you were dead, I’m not going to be the one to kill you.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(rising) Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.$NEWLINE$(rising)
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(rising) Then tell me to kill myself, and I will.$NEWLINE$(rising)

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$I have already.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I have already.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That was in thy rage.$NEWLINE$Speak it again and, even with the word,$NEWLINE$This hand, which for thy love did kill thy love,$NEWLINE$Shall for thy love kill a far truer love.$NEWLINE$To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You said it when you were furious. Say it again—just one word, and my hand, which killed your lover out of love, will kill your far truer lover. You will be an accessory to both crimes.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$I would I knew thy heart.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I wish I knew what was in your heart.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$'Tis figured in my tongue.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I’ve told you.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$I fear me both are false.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I fear that your words and your heart are both false.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then never man was man true.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then no man has ever been honest.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Well, well, put up your sword.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Well, then, put your sword away.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Say then my peace is made.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Tell me that you’ll accept my love.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$That shall you know hereafter.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$You’ll know about that later.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$But shall I live in hope?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$But can I have some hope?

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$All men I hope live so.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I’d like to think all men have some hope.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Vouchsafe to wear this ring.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Please wear this ring.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$To take is not to give.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I’ll take the ring, but don’t assume I’m giving you anything in return.

paragraphs.original: He places the ring on her finger
paragraphs.translated: He places the ring on her finger.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Look, how this ring encompasseth finger;$NEWLINE$Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart.$NEWLINE$Wear both of them, for both of them are thine.$NEWLINE$And if thy poor devoted servant may$NEWLINE$But beg one favor at thy gracious hand,$NEWLINE$Thou dost confirm his happiness forever.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$See how my ring encircles your finger? That’s how your heart embraces my poor heart. Wear both the ring and my heart, because both are yours. And if I, your poor devoted servant, may ask you for one small favor, you will guarantee my happiness forever.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$What is it?
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$What’s that?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That it would please you leave these sad designs$NEWLINE$To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,$NEWLINE$And presently repair to Crosby House,$NEWLINE$Where, after I have solemnly interred$NEWLINE$At Chertsey monast'ry this noble king$NEWLINE$And wet his grave with my repentant tears,$NEWLINE$I will with all expedient duty see you.$NEWLINE$For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you,$NEWLINE$Grant me this boon.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Please leave it to me to take care of the burial, as I have more reason to mourn than you do. Meanwhile go to my estate at Crosby Place. After I have performed the solemn burial rites for this noble king at Chertsey monastery and cried with regret at his grave, I’ll hurry to meet you. For various reasons that must remain secret, please do this for me.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$With all my heart, and much it joys me too$NEWLINE$To see you are become so penitent.—$NEWLINE$Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I’ll do it with all my heart. I’m happy to see you’ve come to repent for what you’ve done. Tressel and Berkeley, come with me.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Bid me farewell.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Say goodbye to me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$'Tis more than you deserve;$NEWLINE$But since you teach me how to flatter you,$NEWLINE$Imagine I have said “farewell” already.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$It’s more than you deserve. But since you’re already teaching me how to flatter you, pretend I’ve said goodbye already.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Lady ANNE and two others$NEWLINE$ANNE
paragraphs.translated: ANNE and two others exit.$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sirs, take up the corse.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sirs, take up the corpse.

paragraphs.original: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
paragraphs.translated: GENTLEMAN$NEWLINE$Toward Chertsey, noble lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No, to Whitefriars. There attend my coming.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No, to the Whitefriars monastery. Wait for me there.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except RICHARD.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: Was ever woman in this humor wooed?$NEWLINE$Was ever woman in this humor won?$NEWLINE$I’ll have her, but I will not keep her long.$NEWLINE$What, I that killed her husband and his father,$NEWLINE$To take her in her heart’s extremest hate,$NEWLINE$With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,$NEWLINE$The bleeding witness of my hatred by,$NEWLINE$Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me,$NEWLINE$And I no friends to back my suit at all$NEWLINE$But the plain devil and dissembling looks?$NEWLINE$And yet to win her, all the world to nothing!$NEWLINE$Ha!$NEWLINE$Hath she forgot already that brave prince,$NEWLINE$Edward, her lord, whom I some three months since$NEWLINE$Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewkesbury?$NEWLINE$A sweeter and a Lovellier gentleman,$NEWLINE$Framed in the prodigality of nature,$NEWLINE$Young, valiant, wise, and, no doubt, right royal,$NEWLINE$The spacious world cannot again afford.
paragraphs.translated: Has anyone ever courted a woman in this state of mind? And has anyone ever won her, as I’ve done? I’ll get her, but I won’t keep her long. What! I, who killed her husband and his father, managed to win her over when her hatred for me was strongest, while she’s swearing her head off, sobbing her eyes out, and the bloody corpse, proof of why she should hate me, right in front of her? She has God, her conscience, and my own acts against me, and I have nothing on my side but the ugly devil and my false looks. And yet, against all odds, I win her over! Ha! Has she already forgotten her brave husband, Prince Edward, whom I stabbed on the battlefield three months ago in my anger? The world will never again produce such a sweet, lovely gentleman. He was graced with lots of natural gifts, he was young, valiant, wise, and no doubt meant to be king.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And will she yet abase her eyes on me,$NEWLINE$That cropped the golden prime of this sweet prince$NEWLINE$And made her widow to a woeful bed?$NEWLINE$On me, whose all not equals Edward’s moiety?$NEWLINE$On me, that halts and am misshapen thus?$NEWLINE$My dukedom to a beggarly denier,$NEWLINE$I do mistake my person all this while!$NEWLINE$Upon my life, she finds, although I cannot,$NEWLINE$Myself to be a marv'lous proper man.$NEWLINE$I’ll be at charges for a looking glass$NEWLINE$And entertain a score or two of tailors$NEWLINE$To study fashions to adorn my body.$NEWLINE$Since I am crept in favor with myself,$NEWLINE$I will maintain it with some little cost.$NEWLINE$But first I’ll turn yon fellow in his grave$NEWLINE$And then return lamenting to my love.$NEWLINE$Shine out, fair sun, till I have bought a glass,$NEWLINE$That I may see my shadow as I pass.
paragraphs.translated: And yet she cheapens herself by turning her gaze on me, who cut her sweet prince’s life short and made her a widow? On me, though I am barely half the man that Edward was? On me, though I am limping and deformed? I bet I’ve been wrong about myself all this time. Even though I don’t see it, this lady thinks I’m a marvelously good-looking man. Time to buy myself a mirror and employ a few dozen tailors to dress me up in the current fashions. Since I’m suddenly all the rage, it will be worth the cost. But first, I’ll dump this fellow in his grave, then return to my love weeping with grief. Come out, beautiful sun—until I’ve bought a mirror to admire my reflection in, I’ll watch my shadow as I stroll along.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, Lord Marquess of DORSET, Lord RIVERS, and Lord GREY$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$GREY
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH, the lord marquess of DORSET, RIVERS, and Lord GREY enter.$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$GREY

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Have patience, madam. There’s no doubt his majesty$NEWLINE$Will soon recover his accustomed health.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Be patient, madam. I’m sure his majesty will recover his health soon.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$In that you brook it ill, it makes him worse.$NEWLINE$Therefore, for God’s sake, entertain good comfort$NEWLINE$And cheer his grace with quick and merry eyes.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$You’ll only make him worse with all your worry. For God’s sake, let people comfort you. Then you’ll be able to cheer him up.$NEWLINE$him

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$If he were dead, what would betide on me?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$If he were dead, what would happen to me?

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$No other harm but loss of such a lord.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$Nothing more than that you’d lose your husband.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The loss of such a lord includes all harms.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Losing this husband will cause me all sorts of harm.$NEWLINE$this

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$The heavens have blessed you with a goodly son$NEWLINE$To be your comforter when he is gone.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$You have been blessed with an excellent son, who will comfort you when the king is dead.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Ah, he is young, and his minority$NEWLINE$Is put unto the trust of Richard Gloucester,$NEWLINE$A man that loves not me nor none of you.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$But he’s young, and as long as he’s too young to become king, Richard, the duke of Gloucester, has power over him. Richard loves neither me nor any of you.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Is it concluded that he shall be Protector?
paragraphs.translated:
RIVERS$NEWLINE$Has it been decided that Richard will be
Protector?$NEWLINE$Protector$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$It is determined, not concluded yet;$NEWLINE$But so it must be if the king miscarry.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$It’s been decided, though not yet officially announced. But that’s what will happen if the king dies.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BUCKINGHAM and Lord STANLEY, Earl of Derby$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: The duke of BUCKINGHAM and Lord STANLEY, Earl of Derby, enter.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$Here comes the lord of Buckingham, and Derby.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$Here come Lord Buckingham and Lord Derby.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Good time of day unto your royal Grace.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Good afternoon, your royal Highness!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$God make your Majesty joyful, as you have been.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I hope God makes you happy again, like you once were.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The countess Richmond, good my lord of Derby,$NEWLINE$To your good prayer will scarcely say amen.$NEWLINE$Yet, Derby, notwithstanding she’s your wife$NEWLINE$And loves not me, be you, good lord, assured$NEWLINE$I hate not you for her proud arrogance.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$My good Lord Derby, the countess Richmond would hardly say
“amen” to your kind words. But don’t worry. I don’t hold it against you, even though she’s your wife, that she’s so unfriendly and arrogant.$NEWLINE$“amen”$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I do beseech you either not believe$NEWLINE$The envious slanders of her false accusers,$NEWLINE$Or if she be accused in true report,$NEWLINE$Bear with her weakness, which I think proceeds$NEWLINE$From wayward sickness and no grounded malice.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Please don’t believe the false rumors you’ve heard about her feelings toward you, or if they’re true, then forgive her, since she’s only acting that way because she’s sick, not because she hates you.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Saw you the king today, my lord of Derby?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Did you see the king today, Lord Derby?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$But now the duke of Buckingham and I$NEWLINE$Are come from visiting his majesty.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Yes, the duke of Buckingham and I have just returned from visiting him.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$What likelihood of his amendment, lords?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$What are the chances of his getting better, lords?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Madam, good hope. His grace speaks cheerfully.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Madam, keep up hope. He seems cheerful.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$God grant him health. Did you confer with him?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$God give him health. Did you talk with him?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Ay, madam. He desires to make atonement$NEWLINE$Betwixt the duke of Gloucester and your brothers,$NEWLINE$And betwixt them and my Lord Chamberlain,$NEWLINE$And sent to warn them to his royal presence.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Yes, madam. He wants to patch things up between Richard and your brothers, and between your brothers and Hastings. He has summoned them all.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Would all were well—but that will never be.$NEWLINE$I fear our happiness is at the height.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$I wish I could believe you that all was well! But I’m worried that things can only go downhill from here.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD, Duke of Gloucester, and HASTINGS$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, HASTINGS, and DORSET enter.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$DORSET

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$They do me wrong, and I will not endure it!$NEWLINE$Who is it that complains unto the king$NEWLINE$That I, forsooth, am stern and love them not?$NEWLINE$By holy Paul, they love his grace but lightly$NEWLINE$That fill his ears with such dissentious rumors.$NEWLINE$Because I cannot flatter and look fair,$NEWLINE$Smile in men’s faces, smooth, deceive and cog,$NEWLINE$Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,$NEWLINE$I must be held a rancorous enemy.$NEWLINE$Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,$NEWLINE$But thus his simple truth must be abused$NEWLINE$With silken, sly, insinuating jacks?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$They’re out to get me, and I won’t stand for it! Which of you has been complaining to the king that I don’t like them? By God, whoever is worrying the king with these lies doesn’t love him very much. Just because I don’t know how to flatter and act nice, to smile in men’s faces and, as soon as their backs are turned, spread rumors about them, to bow and scrape like a nobleman trained in the French court, people have to think I’m their enemy. Can’t a plain man live and do no harm to anyone without being taken advantage of by a bunch of slick, sneaky lowlifes?

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Which of us are you referring to?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.$NEWLINE$When have I injured thee? When done thee wrong?—$NEWLINE$Or thee?—Or thee? Or any of your faction?$NEWLINE$A plague upon you all! His royal grace,$NEWLINE$Whom God preserve better than you would wish,$NEWLINE$Cannot be quiet scarce a breathing while$NEWLINE$But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You, who are neither honest nor good. When did I ever do you any harm? Or you? Or you? Or any of you? Damn you all! The king—whom I hope God will protect better than you would like—can’t get a minute’s rest without you bothering him with your outrageous complaints.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Brother of Gloucester, you mistake the matter.$NEWLINE$The king, on his own royal disposition,$NEWLINE$And not provoked by any suitor else,$NEWLINE$Aiming belike at your interior hatred$NEWLINE$That in your outward actions shows itself$NEWLINE$Against my children, brothers, and myself,$NEWLINE$Makes him to send, that he may learn the ground.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Brother, you’ve made a mistake. The king himself noticed your hatred toward my children, my brothers, and myself. No one had to point it out to him—it’s obvious. He asked people to visit him. He wanted to find out the reason for your ill will, so he could do something about it.$NEWLINE$asked

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I cannot tell. The world is grown so bad$NEWLINE$That wrens make prey where eagles dare not perch.$NEWLINE$Since every jack became a gentleman,$NEWLINE$There’s many a gentle person made a jack.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I can’t tell what’s going on. The world has become so bad that now little wrens have settled where eagles used to roost. Since every peasant has been made into a nobleman, many noblemen have been dragged down to the level of peasants.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Come, come, we know your meaning, brother Gloucester.$NEWLINE$You envy my advancement, and my friends'.$NEWLINE$God grant we never may have need of you.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Come, come, I know what you’re referring to, Richard. You resent my friends' rise in society, and my own. Let’s hope we never need your help for anything.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Meantime God grants that we have need of you.$NEWLINE$Our brother is imprisoned by your means,$NEWLINE$Myself disgraced, and the nobility$NEWLINE$Held in contempt, while great promotions$NEWLINE$Are daily given to ennoble those$NEWLINE$That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Meanwhile, we’re the ones who need you. My brother is imprisoned because of you, I am disgraced, and the nobility are held in contempt while those who two days ago weren’t worth a dime have suddenly been promoted.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$By Him that raised me to this careful height$NEWLINE$From that contented hap which I enjoyed,$NEWLINE$I never did incense his majesty$NEWLINE$Against the duke of Clarence, but have been$NEWLINE$An earnest advocate to plead for him.$NEWLINE$My lord, you do me shameful injury$NEWLINE$Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$By the Lord who raised me to this weighty post from the happy and carefree life I used to enjoy, I promise you I never did anything to get the king to turn against the duke of Clarence. In fact, I’ve always been on his side and have pleaded for him. My lord, you’re doing me a huge injustice to suggest otherwise.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You may deny that you were not the mean$NEWLINE$Of my Lord Hastings' late imprisonment.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh, and I’ll bet you’ll also deny you were responsible for Lord Hastings’s recent stay in prison.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$She may, my lord, for—
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$She may deny that, my lord, because—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$She may, Lord Rivers. Why, who knows not so?$NEWLINE$She may do more, sir, than denying that.$NEWLINE$She may help you to many fair preferments$NEWLINE$And then deny her aiding hand therein,$NEWLINE$And lay those honors on your high desert.$NEWLINE$What may she not? She may, ay, marry, may she—
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$She may, Lord Rivers? Everybody knows she may. She may do a lot more than that, sir. She may help you to get many nice promotions, and then deny she helped you, claiming you won them on your own merits. What can’t she do? She could even—$NEWLINE$may

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$What, marry, may she?
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$She could even what?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What, marry, may she? Marry with a king,$NEWLINE$A bachelor, a handsome stripling too.$NEWLINE$I wis, your grandam had a worser match.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$She could even what? She could marry a king, a bachelor, a handsome young lad. Certainly, your grandmother had a worse match.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$My Lord of Gloucester, I have too long borne$NEWLINE$Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs.$NEWLINE$By heaven, I will acquaint his majesty$NEWLINE$With those gross taunts that oft I have endured.$NEWLINE$I had rather be a country servant-maid$NEWLINE$Than a great queen with this condition,$NEWLINE$To be so baited, scorned, and stormèd at.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$My lord of Gloucester, I have suffered your blunt upbraidings and your bitterness toward me for too long. By God, I will tell the king about these taunts. I would rather be a country serving maid than a great queen if it meant I could escape your scorn and constant harassment.

paragraphs.original: Enter old QUEEN MARGARET, apart from others$NEWLINE$QUEEN MARGARET
paragraphs.translated: Old QUEEN MARGARET enters without being seen.$NEWLINE$QUEEN MARGARET

paragraphs.original: Small joy have I in being England’s queen.
paragraphs.translated: I’ve had very little joy as England’s queen.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) And lessened be that small, God I beseech Him!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Thy honor, state, and seat is due to me.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) God, give her even less joy, I beg you! Elizabeth, your honor, your high rank, and your position as
queen are all owed to me.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)$NEWLINE$queen$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) What, threat you me with telling of the king?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Tell him, and spare not. Look, what I have said,$NEWLINE$I will avouch ’t in presence of the king;$NEWLINE$I dare adventure to be sent to th' Tower.$NEWLINE$'Tis time to speak. My pains are quite forgot.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) What! You’re threatening to tell the king? Go ahead, and don’t spare a single detail. Look, what I have said to you I will repeat in the presence of the king. If it means I’ll be sent to the Tower, so be it. It’s time for me to speak the truth. All the pains I took on King Edward’s behalf have been forgotten.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) Out, devil! I do remember them too well:$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Thou killed’st my husband Henry in the Tower,$NEWLINE$And Edward, my poor son, at Tewkesbury.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) You devil! I remember these pains all too well. You killed my husband, Henry, in the Tower and my poor son, Edward, at Tewksbury.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Ere you were queen, ay, or your husband king,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I was a packhorse in his great affairs,$NEWLINE$A weeder-out of his proud adversaries,$NEWLINE$A liberal rewarder of his friends.$NEWLINE$To royalize his blood, I spent mine own.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Before you were queen—in fact, before your husband was king—I was a packhorse for his great affairs, a weeder-out of his proud enemies, a generous rewarder of his friends. In order to make his blood royal, I spent my own blood.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) Ay, and much better blood than his or thine.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) Yes, and you spent
better blood than his or your own.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)$NEWLINE$better$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) In all which time, you and your husband Grey$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Were factious for the house of Lancaster.—$NEWLINE$And, Rivers, so were you. —Was not your husband$NEWLINE$In Margaret’s battle at Saint Albans slain?$NEWLINE$Let me put in your minds, if you forget,$NEWLINE$What you have been ere this, and what you are;$NEWLINE$Withal, what I have been, and what I am.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) In all that time, you and your first husband, Sir John Grey, were fighting for the Lancasters.—And so were you, Rivers.—Elizabeth, wasn’t your first husband killed while fighting in Queen Margaret’s army at Saint Alban’s? In case you’ve forgotten, I want to remind you where you come from and what side you were on before you arrived here. And I want you to remember whom I fought for, who I have been, and who I am.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) A murd'rous villain, and so still thou art.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) You were a murderous villain, and you still are.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Poor Clarence did forsake his father Warwick,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Ay, and forswore himself—which Jesu pardon!—
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to ELIZABETH) Poor
Clarence abandoned his father-in-law, a Lancaster, and broke his own oath—may Jesus forgive him!—$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Clarence$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) Which God revenge!$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) May God take revenge on him!$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$To fight on Edward’s party for the crown;$NEWLINE$And for his meed, poor lord, he is mewed up.$NEWLINE$I would to God my heart were flint, like Edward’s,$NEWLINE$Or Edward’s soft and pitiful, like mine.$NEWLINE$I am too childish-foolish for this world.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) —in order to fight on Edward’s side to help him win the crown. And now he is rewarded by being thrown in prison! I wish to God my heart were made of stone, like Edward’s is. Or I wish Edward’s were soft and full of feeling, as mine is, so that he would let Clarence go. I am too childish, too innocent, for this world.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) Hie thee to hell for shame, and leave the world,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Thou cacodemon! There thy kingdom is.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) Hurry to hell, then, and leave the world alone, you demon! Hell is where your kingdom is.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days$NEWLINE$Which here you urge to prove us enemies,$NEWLINE$We followed then our lord, our sovereign king.$NEWLINE$So should we you, if you should be our king.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$My Lord of Gloucester, in those busy days, which you’re bringing up now to prove we’re your enemies, we followed the lawful king. If you were king, we would do the same.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If I should be? I had rather be a peddler.$NEWLINE$Far be it from my heart, the thought thereof.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If I were king? I’d rather be a peddler. The thought of being king doesn’t appeal to me in the least.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$As little joy, my lord, as you suppose$NEWLINE$You should enjoy were you this country’s king,$NEWLINE$As little joy may you suppose in me$NEWLINE$That I enjoy, being the queen thereof.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$You’re right to imagine that being this country’s leader brings no pleasure. As queen, I have felt none.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(aside) As little joy enjoys the queen thereof,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$For I am she, and altogether joyless.$NEWLINE$I can no longer hold me patient.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear) No pleasure for the queen, indeed: I am the real queen, and the experience is completely joyless. I can no longer hold my tongue.$NEWLINE$(speaking so no one else can hear)

paragraphs.original: She steps forward
paragraphs.translated: She moves forward so that everyone can see her.

paragraphs.original: Hear me, you wrangling pirates, that fall out$NEWLINE$In sharing that which you have pilled from me!$NEWLINE$Which of you trembles not that looks on me?$NEWLINE$If not, that I am queen, you bow like subjects,$NEWLINE$Yet that, by you deposed, you quake like rebels.—$NEWLINE$Ah, gentle villain, do not turn away.
paragraphs.translated: Hear me, you wrangling pirates. You’re quarreling over what doesn’t even belong to you—you stole it from me! Which of you does not tremble when you see me? If you aren’t trembling because you know I am queen and you are my subjects, then you’re shaking because you threw me from the throne! (to RICHARD) Oh highborn villain, do not turn away!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Foul, wrinkled witch, what mak’st thou in my sight?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ugly, wrinkled witch, what are you doing here?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$But repetition of what thou hast marred.$NEWLINE$That will I make before I let thee go.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Only describing what you have ruined. Or at least that’s what I plan to do before I let you go.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Wert thou not banishèd on pain of death?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Weren’t you banished on pain of death?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I was, but I do find more pain in banishment$NEWLINE$Than death can yield me here by my abode.$NEWLINE$A husband and a son thou ow’st to me;$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And thou a kingdom; —all of you, allegiance.$NEWLINE$The sorrow that I have by right is yours,$NEWLINE$And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I was. But I felt more pain from exile than I would have from being dead here at home. You, Richard, owe me a husband and a son. The rest of you owe me a kingdom. And all of you owe me allegiance. The sorrow that I feel actually belongs to you, and the high life you enjoy actually belongs to me. You stole it from me.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The curse my noble father laid on thee$NEWLINE$When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper,$NEWLINE$And with thy scorns drew’st rivers from his eyes,$NEWLINE$And then, to dry them, gav’st the duke a clout$NEWLINE$Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland—$NEWLINE$His curses then, from bitterness of soul$NEWLINE$Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee,$NEWLINE$And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$The curse my noble
warrior-father laid on you when you set a paper crown on his head just before slaying him has finally borne fruit. Your scorn for him was so shocking that he cried rivers.$NEWLINE$warrior-father$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$To stop up his tears, you handed him a rag soaked with the blood of his own child. God, not us, is responsible for punishing you for your bloody deed.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$So just is God to right the innocent.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$God is just. He rewards the innocent.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$O, ’twas the foulest deed to slay that babe,$NEWLINE$And the most merciless that e'er was heard of!
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Oh, killing that child was the dirtiest, most merciless deed there ever was!

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Tyrants themselves wept when they heard about it.

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$No man but prophesied revenge for it.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$Everyone understood there would be a heavy payback.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Northumberland, then present, wept to see it.
paragraphs.translated:
BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Even
Northumberland wept to see it.$NEWLINE$Northumberland$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$What, were you snarling all before I came,$NEWLINE$Ready to catch each other by the throat,$NEWLINE$And turn you all your hatred now on me?$NEWLINE$Did York’s dread curse prevail so much with heaven$NEWLINE$That Henry’s death, my Lovelly Edward’s death,$NEWLINE$Their kingdom’s loss, my woeful banishment,$NEWLINE$Could all but answer for that peevish brat?$NEWLINE$Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?$NEWLINE$Why then, give way, dull clouds, to my quick curses!$NEWLINE$Though not by war, by surfeit die your king,$NEWLINE$As ours by murder to make him a king.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$What, were you all snarling before I arrived, ready to catch each other by the throat like dogs, but now that I’m here, you turn your hatred toward me? Did the duke of York’s terrible curse have so much weight with God that God repaid him not only with Henry’s death and my lovely Edward’s death but with the loss of their kingdom and with my banishment, too? All because of what happened to that brat Rutland? If curses can pierce the clouds and enter heaven that easily, then open up, thick clouds, and listen to my curses!$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT
