paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Edward thy son, that now is Prince of Wales,$NEWLINE$For Edward our son, that was Prince of Wales,$NEWLINE$Die in his youth by like untimely violence.$NEWLINE$Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen,$NEWLINE$Outlive thy glory, like my wretched self.$NEWLINE$Long mayst thou live to wail thy children’s death$NEWLINE$And see another, as I see thee now,$NEWLINE$Decked in thy rights, as thou art stalled in mine.$NEWLINE$Long die thy happy days before thy death,$NEWLINE$And, after many lengthened hours of grief,$NEWLINE$Die neither mother, wife, nor England’s queen.—$NEWLINE$Rivers and Dorset, you were standers-by,$NEWLINE$And so wast thou, Lord Hastings, when my son$NEWLINE$Was stabbed with bloody daggers. God I pray Him$NEWLINE$That none of you may live his natural age,$NEWLINE$But by some unlooked accident cut off.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Though your king did not die in battle, let him die from overindulging his appetites, as my husband was murdered to make your husband king. May your son Edward, who is currently the prince of Wales, die young and violently, as payback for the death of my son Edward, the former prince of Wales. And may you outlive your glory just as miserably as I have, to make up for taking my position as queen. May you live long enough to mourn your children’s deaths and watch another woman enjoy the throne, as I now watch you. Let your happy days die long before you do. After many extended hours of grief, may you die neither a mother, a wife, nor England’s queen. Rivers, Dorset, and Lord Hastings, you all stood by as my son was stabbed. For his sake, I pray to God that none of you die a natural death but have your lives cut short by some unforeseen accident.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Have done thy charm, thou hateful, withered hag.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Enough of your magic spells, you hateful, withered hag.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$And leave out thee? Stay, dog, for thou shalt hear me.$NEWLINE$If heaven have any grievous plague in store$NEWLINE$Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,$NEWLINE$O, let them keep it till thy sins be ripe$NEWLINE$And then hurl down their indignation$NEWLINE$On thee, the troubler of the poor world’s peace.$NEWLINE$The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul.$NEWLINE$Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou liv’st,$NEWLINE$And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends.$NEWLINE$No sleep close up that deadly eye of thine,$NEWLINE$Unless it be while some tormenting dream$NEWLINE$Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$And leave you out? Don’t move, dog. It’s your turn now. If heaven has any plagues beyond what I can drum up, let it wait until your
sins are piled high and then hurl them down on you, you destroyer of a whole world of peace! May conscience eat away at your soul constantly. May you suspect your true friends of being traitors and take the worst traitors as your closest friends. May you never sleep a wink except to dream of a hell full of ugly devils.$NEWLINE$sins$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Thou elvish-marked, abortive, rooting hog,$NEWLINE$Thou that wast sealed in thy nativity$NEWLINE$The slave of nature and the son of hell,$NEWLINE$Thou slander of thy heavy mother’s womb,$NEWLINE$Thou loathèd issue of thy father’s loins,$NEWLINE$Thou rag of honor, thou detested—
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$You deformed, prematurely born, rooting hog, you evil birth defect, you insult to your mother’s womb, you hated disgrace to your father’s sperm, you disgusting—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Margaret.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Margaret.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Richard!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Richard.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ha?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I call thee not.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I didn’t call you.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I cry thee mercy, then, for I did think$NEWLINE$That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon—I thought it was me whom you were calling all those terrible names.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Why, so I did, but looked for no reply.$NEWLINE$O, let me make the period to my curse!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Yes, I was, but I don’t want an answer from you. Let me finish my curse.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$'Tis done by me, and ends in “Margaret.”
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I’ve finished it for you, and it ends in “Margaret.”

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN MARGARET)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$He’s turned your curse against you, Margaret.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Poor painted queen, vain flourish of my fortune,$NEWLINE$Why strew’st thou sugar on that bottled spider,$NEWLINE$Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?$NEWLINE$Fool, fool, thou whet’st a knife to kill thyself.$NEWLINE$The day will come that thou shalt wish for me$NEWLINE$To help thee curse that poisonous bunch-backed toad.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Poor imitation queen, why do you align yourself with this humpbacked spider when he’s got you trapped in his deadly web? Fool! You’re sharpening a knife to cut yourself. The day will come when you’ll wish I could help you cast spells against this poisonous, hunchbacked toad.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,$NEWLINE$Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Woman, stop your frantic curses and false prophesies before we run out of patience and do something bad to you.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Shame on you; I’ve already run out of patience with you all.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Were you well served, you would be taught your duty.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$If you got what you deserved, you would learn some respect.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$To serve me well, you all should do me duty:$NEWLINE$Teach me to be your queen, and you my subjects.$NEWLINE$O, serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$What I deserve is that you treat me like a queen, and what you deserve is to act like my subjects. Give me what I deserve, and do your duty!

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to RIVERS) Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to RIVERS) Don’t argue with her. She’s crazy.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Peace, Master Marquess, you are malapert.$NEWLINE$Your fire-new stamp of honor is scarce current.$NEWLINE$O, that your young nobility could judge$NEWLINE$What ’twere to lose it and be miserable!$NEWLINE$They that stand high have many blasts to shake them,$NEWLINE$And if they fall, they dash themselves to pieces.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Enough from you, mister, you’re being impertinent. Unlike those born into nobility, your claim to royalty is so recent that you hardly even know what it means to lose it. People in high positions are shaken by many blasts of wind, and when they fall, they shatter into pieces.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good counsel, marry. —Learn it, learn it, marquess.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good advice, indeed. Take it to heart, Dorset.

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$It touches you, my lord, as much as me.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$It applies to you as much as to me, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ay, and much more; but I was born so high.$NEWLINE$Our aerie buildeth in the cedar’s top,$NEWLINE$And dallies with the wind and scorns the sun.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes, and much more so. But I was born that high. Like an eagle, which builds its nest at the top of a high tree, I play in the wind and am not afraid to look at the sun.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$And turns the sun to shade. Alas, alas,$NEWLINE$Witness my son, now in the shade of death,$NEWLINE$Whose bright out-shining beams thy cloudy wrath$NEWLINE$Hath in eternal darkness folded up.$NEWLINE$Your aerie buildeth in our aerie’s nest.$NEWLINE$O God, that seest it, do not suffer it!$NEWLINE$As it was won with blood, lost be it so.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$But you turn that sun into a shadow. Take my son, for example. He is dead now. You put out his bright life forever. You are building your nest in our nest. Oh God who’s watching, don’t let him get away with this! He won his position violently. Let him lose it that way, too.$NEWLINE$our

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Peace, peace, for shame, if not for charity.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Stop—if you can’t be kind, at least have some shame.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Urge neither charity nor shame to me.$NEWLINE$(addressing the others)$NEWLINE$(addressing the others)$NEWLINE$Uncharitably with me have you dealt,$NEWLINE$And shamefully my hopes by you are butchered.$NEWLINE$My charity is outrage, life my shame,$NEWLINE$And in that shame still live my sorrows' rage.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$How dare you talk about kindness or shame. (to the others) You have only been unkind to me, and you have shamefully butchered my hopes. My kindness to you is to be outraged at what has happened, and my sad, sad shame is in what you have done to my life.$NEWLINE$(to the others)

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Have done, have done.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Enough, enough.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$O princely Buckingham, I’ll kiss thy hand$NEWLINE$In sign of league and amity with thee.$NEWLINE$Now fair befall thee and thy noble house!$NEWLINE$Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,$NEWLINE$Nor thou within the compass of my curse.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$Oh noble Buckingham, I’ll kiss your hand to show my friendship and support for you. I wish only good things upon you and your noble family! Your clothes aren’t spattered with my family’s blood, and you aren’t affected by my curse.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Nor no one here, for curses never pass$NEWLINE$The lips of those that breathe them in the air.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$No one here is affected by your curse, because curses are just words with no power.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I will not think but they ascend the sky,$NEWLINE$And there awake God’s gentle-sleeping peace.$NEWLINE$(aside to BUCKINGHAM)$NEWLINE$(aside to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$O Buckingham, take heed of yonder dog!$NEWLINE$Look when he fawns, he bites; and when he bites,$NEWLINE$His venom tooth will rankle to the death.$NEWLINE$Have not to do with him. Beware of him.$NEWLINE$Sin, death, and hell have set their marks on him,$NEWLINE$And all their ministers attend on him.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$I think they rise up to heaven and arouse God from his gentle sleep. (so that only BUCKINGHAM hears) Oh Buckingham, watch out for that dog, Richard! When he seems to be fawning on you, he’s actually about to bite. And his poisonous bite kills. Have nothing to do with him. Beware of him. All the powers of sin, death, and hell are doing his bidding.$NEWLINE$(so that only$NEWLINE$hears)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What doth she say, my lord of Buckingham?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What is she saying, my lord?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Nothing that I respect, my gracious lord.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Nothing that interests me, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$What, dost thou scorn me for my gentle counsel,$NEWLINE$And soothe the devil that I warn thee from?$NEWLINE$O, but remember this another day,$NEWLINE$When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,$NEWLINE$And say poor Margaret was a prophetess.—$NEWLINE$Live each of you the subjects to his hate,$NEWLINE$And he to yours, and all of you to God’s.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN MARGARET$NEWLINE$What, you ignore my kind advice and try to please the devil I’m warning you about? Oh, just remember this another day, when he splits your heart in two with sorrow. Then you’ll say poor Margaret was a prophet. Richard will come to hate everyone here, as you will come to hate him—and as God will come to hate you all.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$My hair doth stand an end to hear her curses.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Her curses have made my hair stand on end.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$And so doth mine. I muse why she’s at liberty.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Mine, too. I don’t understand why she’s not locked up.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I cannot blame her. By God’s holy mother,$NEWLINE$She hath had too much wrong, and I repent$NEWLINE$My part thereof that I have done to her.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I can’t blame her. She has been wronged too often. I regret what I have done to hurt her.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$I never did her any, to my knowledge.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$I never caused her any harm, as far as I know.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yet you have all the vantage of her wrong.$NEWLINE$I was too hot to do somebody good$NEWLINE$That is too cold in thinking of it now.$NEWLINE$Marry, as for Clarence, he is well repaid;$NEWLINE$He is franked up to fatting for his pains.$NEWLINE$God pardon them that are the cause thereof.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$But you have all the advantages from the harm done. For my part, I was too eager to do King Edward good. He doesn’t even seem to notice now. And look how he’s repaid poor Clarence for his loyalty—penned him up like a pig being fattened for slaughter. God pardon those who are responsible for Clarence’s troubles.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion$NEWLINE$To pray for them that have done scathe to us.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$That’s very virtuous and Christian of you, Richard, to pray for those who have done us harm.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$So do I ever (aside) being well-advised,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I always pray for them (to himself) because “they” are none other than myself. If I cursed Clarence’s wrongdoers, I’d be cursing myself.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY enters.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Madam, his majesty doth call for you,—$NEWLINE$And for your Grace, —and yours, my gracious lords.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Madam, his majesty asks for you, and for you, Duke of Gloucester, and for you, my noble lords.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Catesby, I come. —Lords, will you go with me?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Catesby, we’ll be there soon.—Lords, will you come with me?

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$We wait upon your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$We will wait on you, your majesty.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but RICHARD, Duke of Gloucester$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but RICHARD exits.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I do the wrong, and first begin to brawl.$NEWLINE$The secret mischiefs that I set abroach$NEWLINE$I lay unto the grievous charge of others.$NEWLINE$Clarence, whom I indeed have cast in darkness,$NEWLINE$I do beweep to many simple gulls,$NEWLINE$Namely, to Derby, Hastings, Buckingham,$NEWLINE$And tell them ’tis the queen and her allies$NEWLINE$That stir the king against the duke my brother.$NEWLINE$Now they believe it and withal whet me$NEWLINE$To be revenged on Rivers, Dorset, Grey;$NEWLINE$But then I sigh and, with a piece of scripture,$NEWLINE$Tell them that God bids us do good for evil;$NEWLINE$And thus I clothe my naked villainy$NEWLINE$With odd old ends stolen out of Holy Writ,$NEWLINE$And seem a saint when most I play the devil.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Incredible. I do the wrong and am the first to start quarrels. What I did in secret I blame on others. I cry about Clarence, whom I had imprisoned, in front of these simple fools—namely, Hastings, Derby and Buckingham—and tell them that the queen and her allies roused the king against my brother Clarence. They believe me and urge me to take revenge on Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey. But then I sigh and quote a chunk of the Bible—how God says do good in return for evil. Ha! Dressing my out-and-out wickedness in scraps of Scripture, I look like a saint exactly when I’m most like the devil.

paragraphs.original: Enter two MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: Two MURDERERS enter.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: But, soft! here come my executioners.—$NEWLINE$How now, my hardy, stout, resolvèd mates?$NEWLINE$Are you now going to dispatch this thing?
paragraphs.translated: But quiet. Here come the murderers I’ve hired. How’s it going, hardy, reliable friends! Are you going to take care of this thing now?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We are, my lord, and come to have the warrant$NEWLINE$That we may be admitted where he is.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We are, my lord. We’ve come to get the warrant so we can be let into his cell.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Well thought upon. I have it here about me.$NEWLINE$He gives a paper$NEWLINE$He gives a paper$NEWLINE$When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.$NEWLINE$But, sirs, be sudden in the execution,$NEWLINE$Withal obdurate; do not hear him plead,$NEWLINE$For Clarence is well-spoken and perhaps$NEWLINE$May move your hearts to pity if you mark him.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good thinking. I have it on me here. (he hands over the warrant) When you’re done, go to Crosby Place. But, sirs, do the job fast. And stick to your mission. Don’t let him plead for his life, because Clarence is a good talker and may make you pity him if you let him get started.$NEWLINE$(he hands over the warrant)

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Tut, tut, my lord, we will not stand to prate.$NEWLINE$Talkers are no good doers. Be assured$NEWLINE$We go to use our hands and not our tongues.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Tut, tut, my lord, we’re not going to stand around chit-chatting. Talkers aren’t good doers. Rest assured that we’re going there to use our hands, not our tongues.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Your eyes drop millstones, when fools' eyes drop tears.$NEWLINE$I like you lads. About your business straight.$NEWLINE$Go, go, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$When fools cry, you remain stony. I like you guys. Go straight to work. Hurry now, get the job done.

paragraphs.original: MURDERERS$NEWLINE$We will, my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: MURDERERS$NEWLINE$We will, my noble lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter CLARENCE and KEEPER$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$KEEPER
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE and the KEEPER enter.$NEWLINE$CLARENCE$NEWLINE$KEEPER

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$Why looks your grace so heavily today?
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$Why do you look so depressed today, your Grace?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$O, I have passed a miserable night,$NEWLINE$So full of ugly dreams, of ugly sights,$NEWLINE$That, as I am a Christian faithful man,$NEWLINE$I would not spend another such a night$NEWLINE$Though ’twere to buy a world of happy days,$NEWLINE$So full of dismal terror was the time.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, I had a miserable night. I had such dark and terrifying dreams that I swear I wouldn’t spend another night like that if it guaranteed me a whole lifetime of happy days.

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$What was your dream, my lord? I pray you tell me.
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$What was your dream? Tell me.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Methoughts that I had broken from the Tower$NEWLINE$And was embarked to cross to Burgundy,$NEWLINE$And in my company my brother Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Who from my cabin tempted me to walk$NEWLINE$Upon the hatches. Thence we looked toward England$NEWLINE$And cited up a thousand fearful times,$NEWLINE$During the wars of York and Lancaster$NEWLINE$That had befall'n us. As we paced along$NEWLINE$Upon the giddy footing of the hatches,$NEWLINE$Methought that Gloucester stumbled, and in falling$NEWLINE$Struck me, that thought to stay him, overboard$NEWLINE$Into the tumbling billows of the main.$NEWLINE$O Lord, methought what pain it was to drown,$NEWLINE$What dreadful noise of waters in my ears,$NEWLINE$What sights of ugly death within my eyes.$NEWLINE$Methoughts I saw a thousand fearful wracks,$NEWLINE$A thousand men that fishes gnawed upon,$NEWLINE$Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,$NEWLINE$Inestimable stones, unvalued jewels,$NEWLINE$All scattered in the bottom of the sea.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I thought I had escaped from the Tower and was on a ship to France with my brother Richard, who persuaded me to leave my cabin and walk on deck with him. Looking toward England, we reminisced about the countless frightening experiences we’d had in the wars between the Yorks and the Lancasters. As we were pacing the deck, which was tipping heavily, Richard seemed to stumble, and as I tried to grab hold of him and keep him from falling, he knocked me overboard into the crashing waves. Lord, how painful it was to drown. The sound of the rushing water was terrible, and so were the sights. I saw a thousand shipwrecks, a thousand men whom fish had gnawed to the bone, huge anchors, chunks of gold, heaps of pearls, and precious jewels—all scattered on the bottom of the sea.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Some lay in dead men’s skulls, and in the holes$NEWLINE$Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept—$NEWLINE$As ’twere in scorn of eyes—reflecting gems,$NEWLINE$That wooed the slimy bottom of the deep$NEWLINE$And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Some of the gems had wedged themselves like imitation eyes into the dead men’s skulls. The fake eyes gazed dully at the bones scattered around.

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$Had you such leisure in the time of death$NEWLINE$To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$So you had time as you were dying to look around?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Methought I had, and often did I strive$NEWLINE$To yield the ghost, but still the envious flood$NEWLINE$Stopped in my soul and would not let it forth$NEWLINE$To find the empty, vast, and wand'ring air,$NEWLINE$But smothered it within my panting bulk,$NEWLINE$Who almost burst to belch it in the sea.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I thought I did, and I often tried to die. But the terrible water always held me back. It wouldn’t let my soul find its way to air but smothered it inside my gasping body. My body wanted so badly to vomit up my spirit that it almost burst.

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$Awaked you not in this sore agony?
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$And didn’t you wake up during this terrible agony?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$No, no, my dream was lengthened after life.$NEWLINE$O, then began the tempest to my soul.$NEWLINE$I passed, methought, the melancholy flood,$NEWLINE$With that sour ferryman which poets write of,$NEWLINE$Unto the kingdom of perpetual night.$NEWLINE$The first that there did greet my stranger-soul$NEWLINE$Was my great father-in-law, renownèd Warwick,$NEWLINE$Who spake aloud, “What scourge for perjury$NEWLINE$Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence?”$NEWLINE$And so he vanished. Then came wand'ring by$NEWLINE$A shadow like an angel, with bright hair$NEWLINE$Dabbled in blood, and he shrieked out aloud
paragraphs.translated:
CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, no, my dream went on even after I died. In fact, the real nightmare had only just begun. With the help of the grim
ferryman that poets like to write about, my soul crossed the river into the kingdom of endless night.$NEWLINE$ferryman$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$The first to greet me there was my great
father-in-law, the famous earl of Warwick. He cried aloud, “What terrible punishment can this dark realm devise for the oath-breaker Clarence?” And he vanished. Then a ghost like an angel with its hair spattered in blood wandered by, and shieked,$NEWLINE$father-in-law$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$“Clarence is come—false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,$NEWLINE$That stabbed me in the field by Tewkesbury.$NEWLINE$Seize on him, furies. Take him unto torment.”$NEWLINE$With that, methoughts, a legion of foul fiends$NEWLINE$Environed me and howlèd in mine ears$NEWLINE$Such hideous cries that with the very noise$NEWLINE$I trembling waked, and for a season after$NEWLINE$Could not believe but that I was in hell,$NEWLINE$Such terrible impression made my dream.
paragraphs.translated:
CLARENCE$NEWLINE$“Clarence has arrived—lying, cowardly
Clarence, who stabbed me at Tewksbury. Grab him, avenging spirits, and torment him.” With that, a legion of ugly demons surrounded me and howled so loudly in my ears that I woke up trembling and for a long time thought I was still in hell.$NEWLINE$Clarence$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$No marvel, lord, though it affrighted you.$NEWLINE$I am afraid, methinks, to hear you tell it.
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$I’m not surprised it scared you, my lord. It scares me just to hear you talk about it.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Ah keeper, keeper, I have done those things,$NEWLINE$That now give evidence against my soul,$NEWLINE$For Edward’s sake, and see how he requites me.—$NEWLINE$O God, if my deep prayers cannot appease thee,$NEWLINE$But thou wilt be avenged on my misdeeds,$NEWLINE$Yet execute thy wrath in me alone!$NEWLINE$O, spare my guiltless wife and my poor children!—$NEWLINE$Keeper, I prithee sit by me awhile.$NEWLINE$My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Oh, keeper, keeper, the bad things I’ve done are finally taking their toll. I did them for Edward’s sake—and look how he rewards me.—Oh God, if my prayers don’t satisfy you, and you have to avenge the wrongs I’ve done, at least punish me alone! Please spare my innocent wife and children!—Kind warden, please stay with me for a while. I’m feeling very low, and I need to sleep.

paragraphs.original: KEEPER$NEWLINE$I will, my lord. God give your Grace good rest.
paragraphs.translated: KEEPER$NEWLINE$I’ll stay, my lord. May God bring you sleep!

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE sleeps$NEWLINE$CLARENCE
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE sleeps$NEWLINE$CLARENCE

paragraphs.original: Enter BRAKENBURY the lieutenant$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY the lieutenant enters.$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$Sorrow breaks seasons and reposing hours,$NEWLINE$Makes the night morning, and the noontide night.$NEWLINE$Princes have but their titles for their glories,$NEWLINE$An outward honor for an inward toil,
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$Sorrow interrupts all hours and seasons. It turns everything around—the night into morning and noon into night. The only glory princes have are their titles.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: And, for unfelt imaginations,$NEWLINE$They often feel a world of restless cares,$NEWLINE$So that betwixt their titles and low name$NEWLINE$There’s nothing differs but the outward fame.
paragraphs.translated: Instead of the pleasures we think they’re enjoying, they experience a whole world of worries. It turns out the only difference between them and peasants is their fame.

paragraphs.original: Enter the two MURDERERS$NEWLINE$MURDERERS
paragraphs.translated: The two MURDERERS enter.$NEWLINE$MURDERERS

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Ho, who’s here?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Ho! Who’s there?

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$What wouldst thou, fellow? And how cam’st thou hither?
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$What do you want, fellow? And how did you get in here?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I want to speak with Clarence, and I came here on my legs.

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$What, so brief?
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$That’s it? Nothing to add?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$'Tis better, sir, to be brief than tedious.—Let him see our commission, and talk no more.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Well, sir, it’s better to say little than to be tedious. (to SECOND MURDERER) Show him our orders and keep your mouth shut.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY reads the paper$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY reads the paper$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I am in this commanded to deliver$NEWLINE$The noble duke of Clarence to your hands.$NEWLINE$I will not reason what is meant hereby$NEWLINE$Because I will be guiltless from the meaning.$NEWLINE$There lies the duke asleep, and there the keys.$NEWLINE$He hands them the keys$NEWLINE$He hands them the keys$NEWLINE$I’ll to the king and signify to him$NEWLINE$That thus I have resigned my charge to you.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$It orders me to hand the noble duke of Clarence over to you. I won’t ask why because I’d rather not know than feel guilty if you’re doing something you shouldn’t be. Here are the keys, and there is the duke, sleeping. (he hands them the keys) I’ll go to the king to let him know I’ve handed my prisoner over to you.$NEWLINE$(he hands them the keys)

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You may, sir. 'Tis a point of wisdom. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You may, sir. That’s a wise idea. Goodbye.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit BRAKENBURY and KEEPER$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$KEEPER
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY and the KEEPER exit.$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$KEEPER

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$What, shall I stab him as he sleeps?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$What, should I stab him while he sleeps?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$No. He’ll say ’twas done cowardly, when he wakes.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$No. When he wakes up, he’ll say we killed him like cowards.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Why, he shall never wake until the great Judgment Day.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$When he wakes up! Why, he won’t wake up till Judgment Day.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Why, then he’ll say we stabbed him sleeping.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Okay, so that’s when he’ll say we stabbed him in his sleep.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$The urging of that word “judgment” hath bred a kind of remorse in me.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$That word “judgment” makes me feel a bit guilty.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What, art thou afraid?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What, are you afraid?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Not to kill him, having a warrant, but to be damned for killing him, from the which no warrant can defend me.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Not of killing him, because I have a warrant for it, but of being damned for killing him, which no warrant can protect me from.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I thought thou hadst been resolute.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I thought you were resolved to do this.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$So I am—to let him live.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I am resolved—to let him live.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’ll back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’ll go back to the duke of Gloucester and tell him so.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Nay, I prithee stay a little. I hope this passionate humor of mine will change. It was wont to hold me but while one tells twenty.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Please, just wait a minute. I’m hoping my holy mood will pass. It usually only lasts about twenty seconds.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$How dost thou feel thyself now?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$How are you feeling now?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Faith, some certain dregs of conscience are yet within me.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Actually, I’m still feeling some pangs of conscience.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Remember our reward when the deed’s done.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Remember the reward we’re getting when the deed’s done.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Zounds, he dies! I had forgot the reward.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Jesus, let’s kill him! I forgot about the reward.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Where’s thy conscience now?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Where’s your conscience now?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$O, in the duke of Gloucester’s purse.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Oh, in the duke of Gloucester’s wallet.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$So when he opens his purse to give us our reward, thy conscience flies out.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$When he opens his wallet to give us our pay, your conscience will fly out?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$'Tis no matter. Let it go. There’s few or none will entertain it.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$It won’t matter. Let it fly out. No one will listen to it.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What if it come to thee again?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$And what will you do if it returns to you?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’ll not meddle with it. It makes a man a coward: a man cannot steal but it accuseth him; a man cannot swear but it checks him; a man cannot lie with his neighbor’s wife but it detects him. 'Tis a blushing, shamefaced spirit that mutinies in a man’s bosom. It fills a man full of obstacles. It made me once restore a purse of gold that by chance I found. It beggars any man that keeps it. It is turned out of towns and cities for a dangerous thing, and every man that means to live well endeavors to trust to himself and live without it.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I won’t bother with it. Conscience makes a man a coward. If he steals, it accuses him. If he wants to swear, it restrains him. If he sleeps with his neighbor’s wife, it exposes him. It blushes, is easily embarrassed, and stages regular uprisings in a man’s heart. It’s just too much trouble. It once made me return a purse full of money that I found—it turns anyone who treats it decently into a beggar. It has been thrown out of all sorts of towns and cities it visits, and anyone who wants to live well should learn to trust only himself and live without it.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Zounds, ’tis even now at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$My God, now the thing is at my elbow, persuading me not to kill the duke.$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not. He would insinuate with thee but to make thee sigh.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Stop your conscience and don’t listen to him. He wants to take over your thoughts and make you sad.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I am strong-framed. He cannot prevail with me.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’m strong-willed. He won’t get the better of me.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Spoke like a tall man that respects thy reputation. Come, shall we fall to work?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Spoken like a brave man who respects his reputation. Shall we get to work?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Take him on the costard with the hilts of thy sword, and then throw him into the malmsey butt in the next room.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We’ll hit him on the head with the handles of our swords, then throw him in the wine barrel in the next room.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$O excellent device— and make a sop of him.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$What an excellent idea—he’ll soak up the wine!

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Soft, he wakes.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Wait a moment. He’s waking up.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Strike!
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Strike!

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$No, we’ll reason with him.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$No, first let’s talk to him.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE wakes$NEWLINE$CLARENCE
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE wakes$NEWLINE$CLARENCE

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Where art thou, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Where are you, keeper? Give me a cup of wine.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$You shall have wine enough, my lord, anon.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$You’ll have wine enough, my lord, soon.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$In God’s name, what art thou?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$In God’s name, who are you?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$A man, as you are.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$A man, like you.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$But not, as I am, royal.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$But not a member of the royal family, like me.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Nor you, as we are, loyal.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$And you’re not loyal, like us.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Your voice is loud and commanding, but you look like a working man.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$My voice is now the king’s, my looks mine own.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’m speaking for the king, but I look like myself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$How darkly and how deadly dost thou speak!$NEWLINE$Your eyes do menace me. Why look you pale?$NEWLINE$Who sent you hither? Wherefore do you come?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$The things you say scare me! Your eyes look threatening. And why are you so pale? Who sent you here? Why are you here?

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$To, to, to—
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$To, to, to—

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$To murder me?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$To murder me?

paragraphs.original: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$Ay, ay.
paragraphs.translated: BOTH MURDERERS$NEWLINE$Yes.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,$NEWLINE$And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.$NEWLINE$Wherein, my friends, have I offended you?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$You barely have the heart to tell me, so you can’t possibly have the nerve to do it. Besides, how have I offended you, my friends?

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Offended us you have not, but the king.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$You didn’t offend us, you offended the king.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$I shall be reconciled to him again.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$He and I will make up.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Never, my lord. Therefore prepare to die.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Never, my lord. So prepare to die.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Are you drawn forth among a world of men$NEWLINE$To slay the innocent? What is my offense?$NEWLINE$Where is the evidence that doth accuse me?$NEWLINE$What lawful quest have given their verdict up$NEWLINE$Unto the frowning judge? Or who pronounced$NEWLINE$The bitter sentence of poor Clarence' death$NEWLINE$Before I be convict by course of law?$NEWLINE$To threaten me with death is most unlawful.$NEWLINE$I charge you, as you hope to have redemption,$NEWLINE$By Christ’s dear blood shed for our grievous sins,$NEWLINE$That you depart, and lay no hands on me.$NEWLINE$The deed you undertake is damnable.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$It’s your job in life to kill the innocent? What did I do wrong? Where’s the evidence against me? Where’s the jury, the judge, the lawful proceedings, the verdict? Who pronounced this death sentence before a court of law could even convict me? For you to threaten to kill me is most unlawful. If you hope to have your sins forgiven by Christ’s dear blood, which He shed for our terrible sins, you must leave and keep your hands off me. You’ll go to Hell for the deed you’re planning to do.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What we will do, we do upon command.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What we do we have been commanded to do.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$And he that hath commanded is our king.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$And the one who commands us is our king.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Erroneous vassals, the great King of kings$NEWLINE$Hath in the tables of His law commanded$NEWLINE$That thou shalt do no murder. Will thou then$NEWLINE$Spurn at His edict and fulfill a man’s?$NEWLINE$Take heed, for He holds vengeance in His hand$NEWLINE$To hurl upon their heads that break His law.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Wrong-headed slaves, the King of kings says in his Ten Commandments, “Thou shalt not murder.” Will you defy God and obey a man? Be careful. God takes revenge on those who break His laws.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$And that same vengeance doth He hurl on thee$NEWLINE$For false forswearing and for murder too.$NEWLINE$Thou didst receive the sacrament to fight$NEWLINE$In quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$He does, and now he’s taking revenge on you—for breaking promises and for murder, too. You took a holy oath to fight for King Henry VI.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$And, like a traitor to the name of God,$NEWLINE$Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade$NEWLINE$Unrippedst the bowels of thy sovereign’s son.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$And like a traitor to God, you broke that oath and savagely murdered King Henry’s young son.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Whom you swore you would protect and defend.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$How canst thou urge God’s dreadful law to us$NEWLINE$When thou hast broke it in such dear degree?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$How dare you tell us about God’s laws when you have broken them so savagely yourself?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Alas! For whose sake did I that ill deed?$NEWLINE$For Edward, for my brother, for his sake.$NEWLINE$He sends you not to murder me for this,$NEWLINE$For in that sin he is as deep as I.$NEWLINE$If God will be avengèd for this deed,$NEWLINE$O, know you yet He doth it publicly!$NEWLINE$Take not the quarrel from His powerful arm;$NEWLINE$He needs no indirect or lawless course$NEWLINE$To cut off those that have offended Him.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$But for whose sake did I do that sick deed? For my brother Edward’s sake. He couldn’t be sending you to murder me for that sin, because he’s the one who asked me to commit it. He is as guilty as I am. If God will be revenged for this deed, he will do it publicly. God doesn’t need to use indirect or illegal means to kill those who have offended him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Who made thee then a bloody minister$NEWLINE$When gallant-springing, brave Plantagenet,$NEWLINE$That princely novice, was struck dead by thee?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Then who were you working for when you killed brave, young Prince Edward?

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$My brother’s love, the devil, and my rage.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$My brother’s love, the devil, and my own anger made me do it.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Thy brother’s love, our duty, and thy faults$NEWLINE$Provoke us hither now to slaughter thee.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Well, your brother’s love, our duty, and your own crimes make us kill you.$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$If you do love my brother, hate not me.$NEWLINE$I am his brother, and I love him well.$NEWLINE$If you are hired for meed, go back again,$NEWLINE$And I will send you to my brother Gloucester,$NEWLINE$Who shall reward you better for my life$NEWLINE$Than Edward will for tidings of my death.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$If you love my brother, don’t hate me. I am his brother, and I love him very much. If you’re doing this for pay, go to my brother Richard. He will pay you more for saving my life than Edward will for killing me.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$You are deceived. Your brother Gloucester hates you.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$You’re mistaken. Richard, the duke of Gloucester, hates you.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$O, no, he loves me, and he holds me dear.$NEWLINE$Go you to him from me.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$No, he loves and cherishes me. Go to him from me.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Ay, so we will.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$We will.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Tell him, when that our princely father York$NEWLINE$Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm,$NEWLINE$He little thought of this divided friendship.$NEWLINE$Bid Gloucester think of this, and he will weep.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Tell him that when our noble father, the duke of York, gave his three sons his blessing, he never imagined that our friendship would come to this. Remind Richard of this, and he will weep.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Ay, millstones, as he lessoned us to weep.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Yes, he’ll weep stones, as he taught us to do.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$O, do not slander him, for he is kind.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Don’t lie about my brother. He is kind.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Right, as snow in harvest. Come, you deceive yourself.$NEWLINE$'Tis he that sends us to destroy you here.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Yes, as kind as snow to a harvest. Come on, you’re fooling yourself. It’s Richard who sent us here to slaughter you.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$It cannot be, for he bewept my fortune,$NEWLINE$And hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobs$NEWLINE$That he would labor my delivery.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$It cannot be. When I left him, he hugged me in his arms and swore between sobs that he would work to set me free.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Why, so he doth, when he delivers you$NEWLINE$From this earth’s thralldom to the joys of heaven.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Well, that’s what he’s doing—making you free to enjoy heaven.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Make peace with God, for you must die, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Have you that holy feeling in your souls$NEWLINE$To counsel me to make my peace with God,$NEWLINE$And art you yet to your own souls so blind$NEWLINE$That thou will war with God by murd'ring me?$NEWLINE$O sirs, consider: they that set you on$NEWLINE$To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$You have enough holy feeling to advise me to “make peace with God,” but you’re willing to go to war with God by murdering me? Oh sirs, consider this: those who sent you to do this deed will hate you for doing it.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$(to FIRST MURDERER) What shall we do?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$(to FIRST MURDERER) What should we do?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Relent, and save your souls.$NEWLINE$Which of you—if you were a prince’s son$NEWLINE$Being pent from liberty, as I am now—$NEWLINE$If two such murderers as yourselves came to you,$NEWLINE$Would not entreat for life? Ay, you would beg,$NEWLINE$Were you in my distress.
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Relent, and save your souls. If either of you were a prince’s son, and you were imprisoned as I am now, and two murderers like yourselves came to you—wouldn’t you beg for your life? Yes, you would beg, if you were in my position.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Relent? No. 'Tis cowardly and womanish.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Relent? No. That’s cowardly and womanish.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$Not to relent is beastly, savage, devilish.$NEWLINE$(to SECOND MURDERER)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks.$NEWLINE$O, if thine eye be not a flatterer,$NEWLINE$Come thou on my side and entreat for me.$NEWLINE$A begging prince what beggar pities not?
paragraphs.translated: CLARENCE$NEWLINE$No, sticking to your plan is beastly, savage, devilish. (to SECOND MURDERER) My friend, I detect some pity in your eyes. Please, please take my side and argue for my life. What beggar wouldn’t have sympathy for a prince reduced to begging?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Look behind you, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$Look behind you, my lord.

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Take that, and that. (stabs CLARENCE)$NEWLINE$(stabs$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$If all this will not do,$NEWLINE$I’ll drown you in the malmsey butt within.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$Take that, and that. (he stabs CLARENCE) If this won’t do the job, I’ll drown you in the wine barrel in the next room.$NEWLINE$(he stabs$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit with the body
paragraphs.translated: He exits with the body.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$A bloody deed, and desperately dispatched.$NEWLINE$How fain, like Pilate, would I wash my hands$NEWLINE$Of this most grievous murder.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$A
bloody deed, and desperately executed. I wish I could wash my hands of this terrible murder, like Pilate.$NEWLINE$bloody deed$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER returns.$NEWLINE$FIRST MURDERER

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$How now? What mean’st thou, that thou help’st me not?$NEWLINE$By heavens, the duke shall know how slack you have been.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$What’s going on? What did you mean by not helping me? By God, I’m going to tell the duke how slack you’ve been.

paragraphs.original: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I would he knew that I had saved his brother.$NEWLINE$Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say,$NEWLINE$For I repent me that the duke is slain.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND MURDERER$NEWLINE$I wish you could tell him I saved his brother. Take the money yourself and tell him what I said. I’m sorry this duke was killed.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$So do not I. Go, coward as thou art.$NEWLINE$Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole$NEWLINE$Till that the duke give order for his burial.$NEWLINE$And when I have my meed, I will away,$NEWLINE$For this will out, and then I must not stay.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST MURDERER$NEWLINE$I’m not. Go, coward that you are. Well, I’ll go hide the body in some hole until the duke gives orders for his burial. And when I get my reward, I’ll get out of here. The truth about this will come out, and I can’t stick around then.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter KING EDWARD IV, sick, QUEEN ELIZABETH, Lord Marquess DORSET, RIVERS, HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others$NEWLINE$KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$GREY
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets sound. KING EDWARD IV enters, sick, accompanied by QUEEN ELIZABETH, DORSET, RIVERS, HASTINGS, BUCKINGHAM, GREY, and others.$NEWLINE$KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$GREY

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Why, so. Now have I done a good day’s work.$NEWLINE$You peers, continue this united league.$NEWLINE$I every day expect an embassage$NEWLINE$From my Redeemer to redeem me hence,$NEWLINE$And more in peace my soul shall part to heaven$NEWLINE$Since I have made my friends at peace on earth$NEWLINE$Rivers and Hastings, take each other’s hand.$NEWLINE$Dissemble not your hatred. Swear your love.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Well. Now I’ve done a good day’s work. You must all keep up this united front. Every day I expect a message from God to bring me away from here. Now my soul can depart for heaven peacefully, since my friends have made peace here on earth. Rivers and Hastings, take each other’s hand. Don’t simply hide your hatred. Swear your love for each other.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$(taking HASTINGS’s hand) By heaven, my soul is purged from grudging hate,$NEWLINE$(taking$NEWLINE$hand)$NEWLINE$And with my hand I seal my true heart’s love.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$(taking HASTINGS’s hand) I swear I have cleansed my heart of all hate. With this handshake, I guarantee my love.$NEWLINE$(taking$NEWLINE$hand)

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$So thrive I as I truly swear the like.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$On my honor, I feel the same.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Take heed you dally not before your king,$NEWLINE$Lest He that is the supreme King of kings$NEWLINE$Confound your hidden falsehood, and award$NEWLINE$Either of you to be the other’s end.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Make sure you mean what you say. Otherwise God, the ultimate King, will uncover your lies and cause you to be the death of each other.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$So prosper I as I swear perfect love.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$On my honor, I swear I love Rivers with all my heart.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$And I as I love Hastings with my heart.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$And I love Hastings with all my heart.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Madam, yourself is not exempt in this,—$NEWLINE$Nor you, son Dorset, —Buckingham, nor you.$NEWLINE$You have been factious one against the other.—$NEWLINE$Wife, love Lord Hastings. Let him kiss your hand,$NEWLINE$And what you do, do it unfeignedly.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Madam, you’re not exempt from this—nor are you, Dorset— nor you, Buckingham. You have had too many separate factions among you. My dear wife, let Lord Hastings kiss your hand. And don’t do it merely for appearance’s sake.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$There, Hastings, I will never more remember$NEWLINE$Our former hatred, so thrive I and mine.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Take my hand, Hastings. From now on, I’ll forget the hatred I used to feel for you.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS kisses her hand$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS kisses her hand.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Dorset, embrace him.—Hastings, love Lord Marquess.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Dorset, embrace Hastings.—Hastings, express your affection for the marquess of Dorset.

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$This interchange of love, I here protest,$NEWLINE$Upon my part shall be inviolable.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$I swear I will never break this promise of love.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And so swear I.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And so do I, my lord.

paragraphs.original: They embrace
paragraphs.translated: They embrace.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Now, princely Buckingham, seal thou this league$NEWLINE$With thy embracements to my wife’s allies$NEWLINE$And make me happy in your unity.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Now, noble Buckingham, seal this alliance by embracing my wife’s friends, and make me happy in your unity.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate$NEWLINE$Upon your Grace, but with all duteous love$NEWLINE$Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me$NEWLINE$When I have most need to employ a friend,$NEWLINE$With hate in those where I expect most love.$NEWLINE$And most assurèd that he is a friend,$NEWLINE$Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile$NEWLINE$Be he unto me: this do I beg of God$NEWLINE$When I am cold in love to you or yours.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) If I ever turn my hatred toward your majesty, and do not love and cherish you and yours, may God punish me. May I find hatred where I most expect love. When I most need a friend, and when I’m sure I have one, make him treacherous and deceitful to me. I beg God to do all this whenever I fail to show love to you or yours.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: They embrace
paragraphs.translated: They embrace.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$A pleasing cordial, princely Buckingham,$NEWLINE$Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart.$NEWLINE$There wanteth now our brother Gloucester here$NEWLINE$To make the blessèd period of this peace.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Noble Buckingham, your promise is like medicine to my ailing heart. All we need to put the final touches on this future peace is for Richard to appear.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$And in good time,$NEWLINE$Here comes Sir Richard Ratcliffe and the duke.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$And just in time, here he comes with Sir Richard Ratcliffe.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD and RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD and RATCLIFFE enter.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good morrow to my sovereign king and queen,$NEWLINE$And, princely peers, a happy time of day.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good morning to my sovereign king and queen. Noble peers, how nice to see you.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Happy indeed, as we have spent the day.$NEWLINE$Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity,$NEWLINE$Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,$NEWLINE$Between these swelling, wrong-incensèd peers.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Happy indeed, the way we have spent the day. Gloucester, we have done deeds of charity, turning enmity into peace and hate into love among these mistakenly angry nobles.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A blessèd labor, my most sovereign lord.$NEWLINE$Amongst this princely heap, if any here$NEWLINE$By false intelligence, or wrong surmise$NEWLINE$Hold me a foe,$NEWLINE$If I unwittingly, or in my rage,$NEWLINE$Have aught committed that is hardly borne$NEWLINE$By any in this presence, I desire$NEWLINE$To reconcile me to his friendly peace.$NEWLINE$'Tis death to me to be at enmity;$NEWLINE$I hate it, and desire all good men’s love.$NEWLINE$First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,$NEWLINE$Which I will purchase with my duteous service;—$NEWLINE$Of you, my noble cousin Buckingham,$NEWLINE$If ever any grudge were lodged between us;—$NEWLINE$Of you and you, Lord Rivers and of Dorset,$NEWLINE$That all without desert have frowned on me;—$NEWLINE$Of you, Lord Woodeville and Lord Scales;— of you,$NEWLINE$Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.$NEWLINE$I do not know that Englishman alive$NEWLINE$With whom my soul is any jot at odds$NEWLINE$More than the infant that is born tonight.$NEWLINE$I thank my God for my humility.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What blessed work, my king. If there’s anyone among this princely group who mistakes me for an enemy—if by accident or in anger I have done anything to offend you—I want to join with you in peaceful friendship. It kills me to be enemies with you. I hate it and want all good men’s love. (to QUEEN ELIZABETH) First, madam, I want there to be peace between you and me, which I will buy with my obedient service to you. And peace with you, my noble cousin Buckingham, if you ever felt any grudge against me; and with you, Lord Rivers, and, Lord Grey, with you. In fact, I want to get along with everyone who has frowned on me without good cause—dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen, everyone. There is not an Englishman alive with whom I’m at odds, anymore than a newborn baby would be. I thank God for my humbleness.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$A holy day shall this be kept hereafter.$NEWLINE$I would to God all strifes were well compounded.$NEWLINE$My sovereign lord, I do beseech your Highness$NEWLINE$To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Today shall always be remembered as a holy day. If only all struggles ended this well. One more thing, my dear majesty. Please pardon our brother Clarence.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, madam, have I offered love for this,$NEWLINE$To be so flouted in this royal presence?$NEWLINE$Who knows not that the gentle duke is dead?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, madam, have I offered you my love only to be flouted in front of the king? Who doesn’t know that the good duke is dead?

paragraphs.original: They all start
paragraphs.translated: They all start.

paragraphs.original: You do him injury to scorn his corse.
paragraphs.translated: You do him wrong to laugh at his corpse.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Who knows not he is dead! Who knows he is?
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Who doesn’t know he’s dead? Who says he is?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$All-seeing heaven, what a world is this!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Oh my God, what a terrible world this is!

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Look I so pale, Lord Dorset, as the rest?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Do I look as pale as everyone else does, Lord Dorset?

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord, and no one in the presence$NEWLINE$But his red color hath forsook his cheeks.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$You do, my good lord. Everyone here has turned white.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Is Clarence dead? The order was reversed.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Is Clarence dead? But I reversed the death sentence.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$But he, poor man, by your first order died,$NEWLINE$And that a wingèd Mercury did bear.$NEWLINE$Some tardy cripple bear the countermand,$NEWLINE$That came too lag to see him burièd.$NEWLINE$God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,$NEWLINE$Nearer in bloody thoughts, and not in blood,$NEWLINE$Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,$NEWLINE$And yet go current from suspicion.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Well, the poor man died by your first order, which was carried by a winged messenger. Some tardy cripple must have taken the counter-order, who came after Clarence was already buried. It’s clear that someone less noble, less loyal, more bloody-minded than Clarence but not a blood relation, deserves as bad an end as my brother, but he goes free.

paragraphs.original: Enter Lord STANLEY, Earl of Derby$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: Lord STANLEY, Earl of Derby, enters.$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(kneeling) A boon, my sovereign, for my service done.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(kneeling) I ask a favor of you in return for the service I’ve done, my king.$NEWLINE$(kneeling)

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$I prithee, peace. My soul is full of sorrow.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Please be quiet. My soul is full of sorrow.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I will not rise unless your Highness hear me.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I will not rise until your Highness hears me.

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Then say at once what is it thou requests.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Then hurry up and tell me what you want.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$The forfeit, sovereign, of my servant’s life,$NEWLINE$Who slew today a riotous gentleman$NEWLINE$Lately attendant on the duke of Norfolk.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$That you lift the death sentence on my servant, who killed a rowdy and belligerent former servant of the duke of Norfolk.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$Have I a tongue to doom my brother’s death,$NEWLINE$And shall the tongue give pardon to a slave?$NEWLINE$My brother killed no man; his fault was thought,$NEWLINE$And yet his punishment was bitter death.$NEWLINE$Who sued to me for him? Who, in my wrath,$NEWLINE$Kneeled at my feet, and bade me be advised?$NEWLINE$Who spoke of brotherhood? Who spoke of love?$NEWLINE$Who told me how the poor soul did forsake$NEWLINE$The mighty Warwick and did fight for me?$NEWLINE$Who told me, in the field by Tewkesbury,$NEWLINE$When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,$NEWLINE$And said “Dear brother, live, and be a king”?$NEWLINE$Who told me, when we both lay in the field$NEWLINE$Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me$NEWLINE$Even in his garments and did give himself,$NEWLINE$All thin and naked, to the numb-cold night?$NEWLINE$All this from my remembrance brutish wrath$NEWLINE$Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you$NEWLINE$Had so much grace to put it in my mind.$NEWLINE$But when your carters or your waiting vassals$NEWLINE$Have done a drunken slaughter and defaced$NEWLINE$The precious image of our dear Redeemer,$NEWLINE$You straight are on your knees for pardon, pardon,$NEWLINE$And I, unjustly too, must grant it you.$NEWLINE$Stanley rises$NEWLINE$Stanley rises$NEWLINE$But for my brother, not a man would speak,$NEWLINE$Nor I, ungracious, speak unto myself$NEWLINE$For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all$NEWLINE$Have been beholding to him in his life,$NEWLINE$Yet none of you would once beg for his life.$NEWLINE$O God, I fear Thy justice will take hold$NEWLINE$On me and you, and mine and yours for this!—$NEWLINE$Come, Hastings, help me to my closet.—$NEWLINE$Ah, poor Clarence.
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$I was willing to condemn my brother to death, but you want me to pardon a peasant? My brother didn’t kill anyone. He was only to blame for some thoughts he had. But his punishment was bitter death. Who pleaded with me to pardon his life? Who, when I was in a rage, kneeled at my feet and told me to reconsider? Who talked about brotherhood? Who talked about love? Who told me how the poor man abandoned the mighty earl of Warwick to fight for me? Who told me how he rescued me in the field at Tewksbury, when Oxford had me down, saying, “Dear brother, live and be a king”? Who told me how, when we both lay in the field freezing to death, he wrapped me in his own clothes and spent a numbingly cold night naked? I forgot all of this in my brutish anger, and not one of you had the grace to remind me. But when your servants get drunk and kill someone, you go right down on your knees for “pardon, pardon.” And, though he doesn’t deserve it, I have to grant your request. But not one of you would speak up for my brother. And I didn’t speak to myself on his behalf, either. The best of you owed something to him in his lifetime, but none of you would plead for his life. Oh God, I fear your justice will destroy me and all of these men, and their families and mine, because of this! Come, Hastings, help me to my room. Oh, poor Clarence.$NEWLINE$his

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt some with KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH
paragraphs.translated: KING EDWARD IV and QUEEN ELIZABETH exit with several others.$NEWLINE$KING EDWARD IV$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$This is the fruits of rashness. Marked you not$NEWLINE$How that the guilty kindred of the queen$NEWLINE$Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence' death?$NEWLINE$O, they did urge it still unto the king.$NEWLINE$God will revenge it. Come, lords, will you go$NEWLINE$To comfort Edward with our company?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$This is what happens when you act rashly. Did you notice how the queen’s guilty relatives turned pale when they heard about Clarence’s death? Oh, they continually urged the king to do it. God will revenge it. But come, lords, will you come with me to Edward’s room to comfort him?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$We wait upon your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$We’ll come with you, your Grace.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the old DUCHESS of York, with the two children of Clarence$NEWLINE$DUCHESS
paragraphs.translated: The old DUCHESS OF YORK enters with CLARENCE’s two children.$NEWLINE$DUCHESS OF YORK$NEWLINE$CLARENCE’s

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Good grandam, tell us, is our father dead?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Tell me, good grandmother, is our father dead?

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$No, boy.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$No, boy.

paragraphs.original: GIRL$NEWLINE$Why do you weep so oft, and beat your breast,$NEWLINE$And cry, “O Clarence, my unhappy son?”
paragraphs.translated: GIRL$NEWLINE$Then why do you weep so often, and beat your breast, and cry, “Oh Clarence, my unlucky son”?

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Why do you look on us and shake your head,$NEWLINE$And call us orphans, wretches, castaways,$NEWLINE$If that our noble father were alive?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Why do you look at us and shake your head, and call us orphans, wretches, castaways, if our noble father is still alive?

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$My pretty cousins, you mistake me both.$NEWLINE$I do lament the sickness of the king,$NEWLINE$As loath to lose him, not your father’s death.$NEWLINE$It were lost sorrow to wail one that’s lost.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$My pretty children, both of you misunderstand me. I’m lamenting the sickness of the king, because I’d hate to lose him—I’m not mourning your father’s death. What would be the point of crying over someone who was already dead?

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Then, you conclude, my grandam, he is dead.$NEWLINE$The king mine uncle is to blame for it.$NEWLINE$God will revenge it, whom I will importune$NEWLINE$With earnest prayers, all to that effect.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$So you’re admitting Clarence, my father, is dead. My uncle the king is to blame for this. God will take revenge. I will pray every day that he does.

paragraphs.original: GIRL$NEWLINE$And so will I.
paragraphs.translated: GIRL$NEWLINE$And so will I.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Peace, children, peace. The king doth love you well.$NEWLINE$Incapable and shallow innocents,$NEWLINE$You cannot guess who caused your father’s death.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Quiet, children, quiet. The king loves you very much. Innocent sweethearts, you have no idea who’s responsible for your father’s death.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Grandam, we can, for my good uncle Gloucester$NEWLINE$Told me the king, provoked to it by the queen,$NEWLINE$Devised impeachments to imprison him;$NEWLINE$And when my uncle told me so, he wept,$NEWLINE$And pitied me, and kindly kissed my cheek,$NEWLINE$Bade me rely on him as on my father,$NEWLINE$And he would love me dearly as a child.
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$Yes we do, grandmother, because my good uncle Richard told me. He said the king was forced by the queen to make up charges against my father that would send him to prison. When my uncle explained this to me, he wept and hugged and kissed me. He told me I could rely on him as if he were my father, and he said he would love me as if I were his child.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Ah, that deceit should steal such gentle shape,$NEWLINE$And with a virtuous visor hide deep vice.$NEWLINE$He is my son, ay, and therein my shame,$NEWLINE$Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Ah, it’s a shame that a liar can seem so nice, hiding his wicked intentions under a mask of goodness. He is my son, yes, and I’m ashamed of him. But he didn’t get his deceitfulness from my breast.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$Think you my uncle did dissemble, grandam?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$You think my uncle was lying, grandmother?

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Ay, boy.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Yes, boy.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$I cannot think it. Hark, what noise is this?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$I can’t believe that. Wait! What’s that noise?

paragraphs.original: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, with her hair about her ears, RIVERS, and DORSET after her$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$DORSET
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH enters with her hair undone. RIVERS, and DORSETfollow.$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$DORSET

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Ah, who shall hinder me to wail and weep,$NEWLINE$To chide my fortune and torment myself?$NEWLINE$I’ll join with black despair against my soul$NEWLINE$And to myself become an enemy.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$No one can stop me now from wailing and weeping about my terrible luck. I don’t care if it kills me. I plan to fall into the blackest despair.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What means this scene of rude impatience?
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Why are you making such a scene?

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$To make an act of tragic violence.$NEWLINE$Edward, my lord, thy son, our king, is dead.$NEWLINE$Why grow the branches when the root is gone?$NEWLINE$Why wither not the leaves that want their sap?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$I’m simply performing the violent tragedy that is my life: Edward—my husband, your son, our king—is dead. Why should we live now that our leader is dead? Why are the branches still living when the root is gone? Why aren’t the leaves withering now that the sap is all dried up?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: If you will live, lament. If die, be brief,$NEWLINE$That our swift-wingèd souls may catch the king’s,$NEWLINE$Or, like obedient subjects, follow him$NEWLINE$To his new kingdom of ne'er-changing night.
paragraphs.translated: If you do intend to live, then mourn. If you’re going to die, be quick about it so you can catch the king’s departing soul or follow him, like obedient subjects, to his new kingdom of endless night.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Ah, so much interest have I in thy sorrow$NEWLINE$As I had title in thy noble husband.$NEWLINE$I have bewept a worthy husband’s death$NEWLINE$And lived with looking on his images;$NEWLINE$But now two mirrors of his princely semblance$NEWLINE$Are cracked in pieces by malignant death,$NEWLINE$And I, for comfort, have but one false glass$NEWLINE$That grieves me when I see my shame in him.$NEWLINE$Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother,$NEWLINE$And hast the comfort of thy children left,$NEWLINE$But death hath snatched my husband from mine arms$NEWLINE$And plucked two crutches from my feeble hands,$NEWLINE$Clarence and Edward. O, what cause have I,$NEWLINE$Thine being but a moiety of my moan,$NEWLINE$To overgo thy woes and drown thy cries!
