paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$As the king’s mother, I have a large share in your grief. I have wept at my own good husband’s death and only kept myself alive by looking at his sons, the mirror images of him. But now these two mirrors of their princely father have cracked to pieces: my sons are dead. And my only comfort is Richard, who is nothing like his father and only causes me shame. You may be a widow, but you’re also a mother. You have your children as comfort. But death has snatched my husband from my arms and plucked my two crutches, Edward and Clarence, from my feeble hands. Since your woes are only a portion of mine, I have every reason to surpass your lamentations and drown out your cries with my own.

paragraphs.original: BOY$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Ah, aunt, you wept not for our$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$father’s death.$NEWLINE$How can we aid you with our kindred tears?
paragraphs.translated: BOY$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Ah, Aunt, you didn’t weep at our father’s death. How can we help you by crying for your sorrow?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GIRL$NEWLINE$Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned.$NEWLINE$Your widow-dolor likewise be unwept!
paragraphs.translated: GIRL$NEWLINE$You didn’t sympathize with us when we became orphans; we won’t cry for you!

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Give me no help in lamentation.$NEWLINE$I am not barren to bring forth complaints.$NEWLINE$All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,$NEWLINE$That I, being governed by the watery moon,$NEWLINE$May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world.$NEWLINE$Ah, for my husband, for my dear lord Edward!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$I don’t need your help in grieving. I have my own sources of misery. In fact, all the world’s springs and oceans flow from my weeping eyes. I could drown the world. My poor husband, my dear Edward!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$Ah, for our father, for our dear lord Clarence!
paragraphs.translated: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$Our poor father, Clarence!

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Alas for both, both mine, Edward and Clarence!
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$My sons Edward and Clarence!

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$What stay had I but Edward? And he’s gone.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$What support did I have other than Edward? And now he’s gone.

paragraphs.original: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$What stay had we but Clarence? And he’s gone.
paragraphs.translated: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$What support did we have besides our father? And now he’s gone.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What stays had I but they? And they are gone.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What support did I have besides my two sons? And now they’re both gone.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Was never widow had so dear a loss.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$There has never been a widow who suffered such loss as me.

paragraphs.original: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$Were never orphans had so dear a loss.
paragraphs.translated: CHILDREN$NEWLINE$There have never been orphans who’ve suffered what we have.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Was never mother had so dear a loss.$NEWLINE$Alas, I am the mother of these griefs.$NEWLINE$Their woes are parceled; mine are general.$NEWLINE$She for an Edward weeps, and so do I;$NEWLINE$I for a Clarence weep; so doth not she.$NEWLINE$These babes for Clarence weep and so do I;$NEWLINE$I for an Edward weep; so do not they.$NEWLINE$Alas, you three, on me, threefold distressed,$NEWLINE$Pour all your tears. I am your sorrow’s nurse,$NEWLINE$And I will pamper it with lamentations.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$There was never a mother who suffered so much loss. Alas, I am the mother of all these others' griefs. Each of them has a single loss, while I share them all. She weeps for Edward and so do I, while she does not weep for Clarence, though I do. These young children cry for Clarence and so do I, though they don’t cry for Edward, as I do. Alas, all of you can turn to me with your sorrow, because I feel all of it. I will comfort you by adding my own grief to your sorrow.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Comfort, dear mother. God is$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$much displeased$NEWLINE$That you take with unthankfulness, his doing.$NEWLINE$In common worldly things, ’tis called ungrateful$NEWLINE$With dull unwillingness to repay a debt$NEWLINE$Which with a bounteous hand was kindly lent;$NEWLINE$Much more to be thus opposite with heaven,$NEWLINE$For it requires the royal debt it lent you.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Calm down, dear mother. God is unhappy that you’ve responded so unthankfully to his doings. In everyday life, when a person is unwilling to pay back a loan that was generously offered, he’s considered ungrateful. How much worse it is when Heaven is the lender, as in your case?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Madam, bethink you, like a careful mother,$NEWLINE$Of the young prince your son. Send straight for him.$NEWLINE$Let him be crowned. In him your comfort lives.$NEWLINE$Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward’s grave$NEWLINE$And plant your joys in living Edward’s throne.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Be a careful mother, madam, and think about your son, the young prince. Send for him right away and have him crowned. Your peace of mind depends on him. Bury your sorrows in dead Edward’s grave and plant your hopes in Prince Edward’s rise to the throne.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD, BUCKINGHAM, STANLEY, HASTINGS, and RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, BUCKINGHAM, STANLEY, HASTINGS, and RATCLIFFE enter.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sister, have comfort. All of us have cause$NEWLINE$To wail the dimming of our shining star,$NEWLINE$But none can help our harms by wailing them.—$NEWLINE$Madam, my mother, I do cry you mercy;$NEWLINE$I did not see your Grace. Humbly on my knee$NEWLINE$I crave your blessing.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sister, calm down. All of us have reason to mourn the dimming of our shining star the king. But no good comes from all this wailing. Oh, mother, forgive me. I didn’t see you there. On my knee, I humbly ask your blessing.

paragraphs.original: He kneels
paragraphs.translated: He kneels

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$God bless thee, and put meekness in thy breast,$NEWLINE$Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$God bless you and make you obedient, loving, and kind.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(standing) Amen. (aside) And make me die a good old man!$NEWLINE$(standing)$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$That is the butt end of a mother’s blessing;$NEWLINE$I marvel that her Grace did leave it out.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(he stands) Amen. (to himself) And make me die a good old man! That should be the point of a mother’s blessing. I’m surprised my mother forgot to make it.$NEWLINE$(he stands)$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You cloudy princes and heart-sorrowing peers$NEWLINE$That bear this heavy mutual load of moan,$NEWLINE$Now cheer each other in each other’s love.$NEWLINE$Though we have spent our harvest of this king,$NEWLINE$We are to reap the harvest of his son.$NEWLINE$The broken rancor of your high-swoll'n hates,$NEWLINE$But lately splintered, knit, and joined together,$NEWLINE$Must gently be preserved, cherished, and kept.$NEWLINE$Meseemeth good that with some little train$NEWLINE$Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fet$NEWLINE$Hither to London, to be crowned our king.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You mournful princes and grieving gentlemen who have been sharing this burden of grief, now it’s time to cheer each other up with love. Though we have lost a generous king, we are about to enjoy the benefits of a new king. We must preserve our goodwill toward each other and not break into factions again. I think a few members of the court should fetch the young prince from Wales and bring him to London to be crowned our king.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Why “with some little train,” my Lord of Buckingham?
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Why only a few courtiers, my lord of Buckingham?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Marry, my lord, lest by a multitude$NEWLINE$The new-healed wound of malice should break out,$NEWLINE$Which would be so much the more dangerous$NEWLINE$By how much the estate is green and yet ungoverned.$NEWLINE$Where every horse bears his commanding rein$NEWLINE$And may direct his course as please himself,$NEWLINE$As well the fear of harm as harm apparent,$NEWLINE$In my opinion, ought to be prevented.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Because if many of us go there, the hostility between us may break out again, which would be very dangerous with the young prince so newly crowned. When you have a situation where everyone seems free to take off on his or her own, it’s important that the heads of state keep a low profile. We wouldn’t want the prince or his new authority to be undermined by squabbling factions.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I hope the king made peace with all of us;$NEWLINE$And the compact is firm and true in me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The king made peace among all of us. I, at least, intend to stick to our agreement to get along.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$And so in me, and so, I think, in all.$NEWLINE$Yet since it is but green, it should be put$NEWLINE$To no apparent likelihood of breach,$NEWLINE$Which haply by much company might be urged.$NEWLINE$Therefore I say with noble Buckingham$NEWLINE$That it is meet so few should fetch the prince.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$And so do I. I think we all do. But, since our agreement is a recent development, it shouldn’t be put to the test, which could happen if the coronation turned into a huge ceremony. So, I agree with noble Buckingham—only a few should go to meet the prince.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And so say I.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I think so too.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then be it so, and go we to determine$NEWLINE$Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow.—$NEWLINE$Madam, and you, my sister, will you go$NEWLINE$To give your censures in this business?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then we’re agreed. Now we need to figure out which of us will go to meet him. Madam and mother, will you go to offer your support to this weighty business?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but BUCKINGHAM and RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but BUCKINGHAM and RICHARD exits.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$My lord, whoever journeys to the prince,$NEWLINE$For God’s sake let not us two at home.$NEWLINE$For by the way I’ll sort occasion,$NEWLINE$As index to the story we late talked of,$NEWLINE$To part the queen’s proud kindred from the prince.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$For God’s sake, my lord, let’s be sure to be part of the group that meets the prince. Along the way, I’ll find an opportunity to separate him from the queen’s proud relatives, as step one in the plan we’ve discussed.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My other self, my council’s consistory,$NEWLINE$My oracle, my prophet, my dear cousin,$NEWLINE$I, as a child, will go by thy direction$NEWLINE$Toward Ludlow then, for we’ll not stay behind.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You are my other self, my oracle, my prophet, my dear brother! I plan to act like a child and do exactly what you say. To Wales then, for we will not be left out.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter one CITIZEN at one door, and another at the other$NEWLINE$CITIZEN
paragraphs.translated: Two CITIZENS enter through different doors.$NEWLINE$CITIZENS

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Good morrow, neighbor, whither away so fast?

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$I promise you I scarcely know myself.$NEWLINE$Hear you the news abroad?
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$I’m telling you, I hardly know myself. Did you hear the news that’s going around?

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Yes, that the king is dead.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Yes, that the king is dead.

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Ill news, by 'r Lady. Seldom comes the better.$NEWLINE$I fear, I fear, ’twill prove a giddy world.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Bad news, by God. The news is always bad. But this news is bound to make the world go mad.

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$THIRD CITIZEN
paragraphs.translated: A THIRD CITIZEN enters.$NEWLINE$THIRD CITIZEN

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Neighbors, God speed.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Neighbors, hello.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Give you good morrow, sir.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Good day to you, sir.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Doth this news hold of good King Edward’s death?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Is it true that good King Edward has died?

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Ay, sir, it is too true, God help the while.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Yes, sir, it’s all too true, God help us.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Then, masters, look to see a troublous world.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Then, gentlemen, we can count on trouble.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$No, no, by God’s good grace, his son shall reign.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$No, no, with God’s help, his son will be king.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Woe to the land that’s governed by a child.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$It’s bad news when a country is ruled by a child.

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$In him there is a hope of government,$NEWLINE$Which, in his nonage, council under him,$NEWLINE$And, in his full and ripened years, himself,$NEWLINE$No doubt shall then, and till then, govern well.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$His counselors will govern as long as he’s a minor, and then he’ll take over. It shouldn’t go so badly.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$So stood the state when Henry the Sixth$NEWLINE$Was crowned in Paris but at nine months old.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$That’s how it was with Henry the Sixth, who was crowned in Paris when he was only nine months old.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Stood the state so? No, no, good friends, God wot,$NEWLINE$For then this land was famously enriched$NEWLINE$With politic grave counsel; then the king$NEWLINE$Had virtuous uncles to protect his Grace.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Really? But at that point, the king had the benefit of excellent counselors. His uncles were good men and protected him.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Why, so hath this, both by the father and mother.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Well, this king has uncles too, on both his father and mother’s side.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Better it were they all came by his father,$NEWLINE$Or by the father there were none at all,$NEWLINE$For emulation who shall now be nearest$NEWLINE$Will touch us all too near if God prevent not.$NEWLINE$O, full of danger is the duke of Gloucester,$NEWLINE$And the queen’s sons and brothers haught and proud,$NEWLINE$And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,$NEWLINE$This sickly land might solace as before.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$It would be better if they were all on his father’s side, or that there were none at all on his father’s side. As it is, the rivalry between his father’s and mother’s relatives over who will be closest to the king is likely to endanger everyone, if we’re not lucky.As it stands, there’s a struggle between the two sides for the prince’s attention. Richard, the duke of Gloucester, is very dangerous, and the queen’s sons and brothers are haughty and proud—it would be better for this ailing country if they were subjects, not rulers.

paragraphs.original: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Come, come, we fear the worst. All will be well.
paragraphs.translated: FIRST CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Come, come, we’re worrying about the worst-case scenario. I’m sure everything will be fine.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$When clouds are seen, wise men put on their cloaks;$NEWLINE$When great leaves fall, then winter is at hand;$NEWLINE$When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?$NEWLINE$Untimely storms make men expect a dearth.$NEWLINE$All may be well; but if God sort it so,$NEWLINE$'Tis more than we deserve or I expect.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$When the day turns cloudy, wise men put on their coats. When leaves fall from the trees, it means winter has arrived. When the sun sets, who’s too stupid to recognize it’s night? When storms arrive early, you can expect the harvest will be damaged. So, if all turns out fine, as you say, it’s more than we deserve or I expect.

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Truly, the hearts of men are full of fear.$NEWLINE$Ye cannot reason almost with a man$NEWLINE$That looks not heavily and full of dread.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$It’s true, people are really worried. It’s hard to find a person who isn’t.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Before the days of change, still is it so.$NEWLINE$By a divine instinct, men’s minds mistrust$NEWLINE$Ensuing dangers, as by proof we see$NEWLINE$The water swell before a boist'rous storm.$NEWLINE$But leave it all to God. Whither away?
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$It’s always like this in times of change. By some sort of deep instinct, we always know when danger is approaching, just as we know that a storm is coming when the sea swells. But leave it all to God. Where are you all off to?

paragraphs.original: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$Marry, we were sent for to the justices.
paragraphs.translated: SECOND CITIZEN$NEWLINE$The court has sent for us.

paragraphs.original: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$And so was I. I’ll bear you company.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD CITIZEN$NEWLINE$For me, too. I’ll go with you.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the ARCHBISHOP of York, the young duke of YORK, QUEEN ELIZABETH, and the old DUCHESS of York$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DUCHESS$NEWLINE$York
paragraphs.translated: The ARCHBISHOP of York, QUEEN ELIZABETH, her son, the young duke of YORK, and the DUCHESSofYorkenter.$NEWLINE$ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$York$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$DUCHESS$NEWLINE$York

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Last night, I hear, they lay at Stony Stratford,$NEWLINE$And at Northampton they do rest tonight.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow or next day they will be here.
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Last night, I hear, they stayed in Stony Stratford. Tonight they will rest in Northhampton. They’ll be here tomorrow or the next day.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I long with all my heart to see the prince.$NEWLINE$I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I’m dying to see the prince. I hope he’s grown a lot since I last saw him.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$But I hear no; they say my son of York$NEWLINE$Has almost overta'en him in his growth.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$But I hear he hasn’t. They say my son York has almost passed him in height.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Ay, mother, but I would not have it so.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Yes, mother, but I wish I hadn’t.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Why, my young cousin? It is good to grow.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Why, dear child? It’s good to grow.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,$NEWLINE$My uncle Rivers talked how I did grow$NEWLINE$More than my brother: “Ay,” quoth my uncle Gloucester,$NEWLINE$“Small herbs have grace; great weeds do grow apace.”$NEWLINE$And since, methinks I would not grow so fast$NEWLINE$Because sweet flowers are slow and weeds make haste.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Grandmother, one night when we were eating dinner, my uncle Rivers mentioned that I had grown more than my brother. “Yes,” said my uncle Gloucester, “Small plants are graceful, while ugly weeds grow fast.” And since then, I’ve wished I wouldn’t grow so fast, because sweet flowers are slow while the weeds grow in a hurry.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold$NEWLINE$In him that did object the same to thee!$NEWLINE$He was the wretched’st thing when he was young,$NEWLINE$So long a-growing and so leisurely,$NEWLINE$That if this rule were true, he should be gracious.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Well, it certainly wasn’t true for Richard! As a child, he took such a long time to grow up that, according to his rule, he should have grown up into a gracious adult.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$And so no doubt he is, my gracious madam.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$And no doubt he is, gracious madam.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I hope he is, but yet let mothers doubt.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I hope he is, but mothers get to have their doubts.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Now, by my troth, if I had been remembered,$NEWLINE$I could have given my uncle’s grace a flout$NEWLINE$To touch his growth nearer than he touched mine.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Hey, if I’d remembered something about him, I could have had a good comeback for my uncle, touching on his growth worse than he touched on mine.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$How, my pretty York? I prithee let me hear it.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What would you have said, my young York? Do tell.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Marry, they say my uncle grew so fast$NEWLINE$That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old.$NEWLINE$'Twas full two years ere I could get a tooth.$NEWLINE$Grandam, this would have been a biting jest.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Indeed, they say my uncle grew so fast that he could gnaw on a crust of bread when he was two hours old. It took me two years before I had a single tooth. Grandmother, this would have been a biting joke.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I prithee, pretty York, who told thee this?
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Pretty York, who told you about his teeth?

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Grandam, his nurse.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$His nurse, grandmother.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$His nurse? Why, she was dead ere thou wast born.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$His nurse? Why, she was dead before you were even born.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$If ’twere not she, I cannot tell who told me.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Well, if it wasn’t her, I don’t know.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$A parlous boy! Go to, you are too shrewd.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$A mischievous child. Come, come, you are too clever for your own good.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Good madam, be not angry with the child.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Good lady, don’t be angry with the child.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Pitchers have ears.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Little pitchers have big ears.

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Here comes a messenger. —What news?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$Here comes a messenger. What’s the news?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Such news, my lord, as grieves me to report.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, it’s news I wish I didn’t have to report.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$How doth the prince?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$How’s the prince?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Well, madam, and in health.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$He’s fine and healthy, madam.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What is thy news then?
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$What is your news?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Lord Rivers and Lord Grey are sent to Pomfret,$NEWLINE$And, with them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.
paragraphs.translated:
MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Lord Rivers and Lord Grey have been imprisoned in
Pomfret. So has Sir Thomas Vaughan.$NEWLINE$Pomfret.$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Who hath committed them?
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Who sent them there?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The mighty dukes, Gloucester and Buckingham.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The powerful dukes Gloucester and Buckingham.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$For what offence?
paragraphs.translated: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$What did they do wrong?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The sum of all I can, I have disclosed.$NEWLINE$Why, or for what, the nobles were committed$NEWLINE$Is all unknown to me, my gracious lord.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’ve told you everything I know. Why the nobles were imprisoned, and on what charges, I don’t know, my gracious lord.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Ay me! I see the ruin of my house.$NEWLINE$The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind.$NEWLINE$Insulting tyranny begins to jut$NEWLINE$Upon the innocent and aweless throne.$NEWLINE$Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre.$NEWLINE$I see, as in a map, the end of all.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Oh no! I see the downfall of my family. The tiger has seized the gentle deer: a tyrant has begun to attack the weak, innocent king. Welcome, destruction, blood, and massacre! I can see how all this will end as clearly as if I was looking at a map.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Accursèd and unquiet wrangling days,$NEWLINE$How many of you have mine eyes beheld?$NEWLINE$My husband lost his life to get the crown,$NEWLINE$And often up and down my sons were tossed$NEWLINE$For me to joy, and weep, their gain and loss.$NEWLINE$And being seated, and domestic broils$NEWLINE$Clean overblown, themselves the conquerors$NEWLINE$Make war upon themselves, brother to brother,$NEWLINE$Blood to blood, self against self. O, preposterous$NEWLINE$And frantic outrage, end thy damnèd spleen,$NEWLINE$Or let me die, to look on death no more.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$How many times have I had to live through cursed times of violent struggle? My husband lost his life to get the crown, and my sons' fortunes have been tossed up and down, leaving me to rejoice over their victories and weep over their losses. And once one of them achieved the throne and had taken care of domestic quarrels, they made war among themselves. It’s a preposterous outrage. Let it end, or let me die so I won’t have to watch any more of it.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$(to YORK) Come, come, my boy. We will to sanctuary.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Madam, farewell.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$(to YORK) Come, my boy, let’s go to
sanctuary. Madam, farewell.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$sanctuary$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Stay, I will go with you
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Wait, I’ll go with you.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$You have no cause.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$You have no reason to.

paragraphs.original: ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$My gracious lady, go,$NEWLINE$And thither bear your treasure and your goods.$NEWLINE$For my part, I’ll resign unto your Grace$NEWLINE$The seal I keep; and so betide to me$NEWLINE$As well I tender you and all of yours.$NEWLINE$Go. I’ll conduct you to the sanctuary.
paragraphs.translated:
ARCHBISHOP$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) My gracious lady, go, and take your money and
belongings with you. For my part, I’ll reassign the Great Seal of England to you and will take it upon myself to protect you. Come, I’ll conduct you to the sanctuary.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$belongings$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: The trumpets sound. Enter the young PRINCE theCARDINAL, CATESBY, and others$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$CARDINAL$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: The trumpets sound. The young PRINCE theCARDINAL, CATESBY, and others$NEWLINE$PRINCE$NEWLINE$CARDINAL$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Welcome, sweet prince, to London, to your chamber.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Welcome, sweet prince, to London, the capital of the king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE) Welcome, dear cousin, my thoughts' sovereign.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The weary way hath made you melancholy.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Welcome, dear nephew, king of all my thoughts. The tiring journey seems to have made you gloomy.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$No, uncle, but our crosses on the way$NEWLINE$Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy.$NEWLINE$I want more uncles here to welcome me.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$It wasn’t the journey itself, uncle, but the troubles we encountered that made it wearisome and dull. I want more uncles here to welcome me.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sweet prince, the untainted virtue of your years$NEWLINE$Hath not yet dived into the world’s deceit;$NEWLINE$Nor more can you distinguish of a man$NEWLINE$Than of his outward show, which, God He knows,$NEWLINE$Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart.$NEWLINE$Those uncles which you want were dangerous.$NEWLINE$Your Grace attended to their sugared words$NEWLINE$But looked not on the poison of their hearts.$NEWLINE$God keep you from them, and from such false friends.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sweet prince, you’re just an innocent child. You don’t really understand how capable people are of trickery. All you know is what a man shows you, which has little to do with what he’s really thinking. Those uncles that you wish were here were dangerous. Your Grace heard their saccharine words, but didn’t take note of their poisonous intentions. God protect you from them and from other false friends!

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$God keep me from false friends, but they were none.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$God should keep me from false friends, but they weren’t false.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My lord, the mayor of London comes to greet you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My lord, the mayor of London is here to greet you.

paragraphs.original: Enter the LORD MAYOR and his train$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR
paragraphs.translated: The LORD MAYOR and his train enter.$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$God bless your Grace with health and happy days.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$God bless your Grace with health and happy days.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$I thank you, good my lord, and thank you all.—$NEWLINE$I thought my mother and my brother York$NEWLINE$Would long ere this have met us on the way.$NEWLINE$Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not$NEWLINE$To tell us whether they will come or no!
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Thank you, my good lord, thank you all. I thought my mother and my brother, York, would have met us on our way here long before now. And what a slug Hastings is that he hasn’t even arrived to tell us whether they’re coming!

paragraphs.original: Enter HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS enters.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$And in good time here comes the sweating lord.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$And, just in time, here comes the sweaty lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Welcome, my lord. What, will our mother come?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Welcome, my lord. What, isn’t my mother coming?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$On what occasion God He knows, not I,$NEWLINE$The queen your mother and your brother York$NEWLINE$Have taken sanctuary. The tender prince$NEWLINE$Would fain have come with me to meet your Grace,$NEWLINE$But by his mother was perforce withheld.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$God knows why, but your mother and your brother have taken sanctuary in Westminster Abbey. Your sweet brother wanted to come meet you, but his mother wouldn’t let him.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Fie, what an indirect and peevish course$NEWLINE$Is this of hers! —Lord Cardinal, will your Grace$NEWLINE$Persuade the queen to send the duke of York$NEWLINE$Unto his princely brother presently?—$NEWLINE$If she deny, Lord Hastings, go with him,$NEWLINE$And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Damn, what a sneaky and spiteful course your mother is taking!—Lord Cardinal, will you please persuade the queen to hurry and send the duke of York here?—Go with him, Lord Hastings, and if she refuses, take the boy from her by force.

paragraphs.original: CARDINAL$NEWLINE$My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak oratory$NEWLINE$Can from his mother win the duke of York,$NEWLINE$Anon expect him here; but if she be obdurate$NEWLINE$To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid$NEWLINE$We should infringe the holy privilege$NEWLINE$Of blessèd sanctuary! Not for all this land$NEWLINE$Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.
paragraphs.translated: CARDINAL$NEWLINE$My Lord of Buckingham, if my weak skills of persuasion convince his mother to part with the duke of York, you can expect him here shortly. But if she resists my mild pleas, let God in heaven forbid us from disobeying the holy laws of the sanctuary and taking the child from her. I wouldn’t commit so serious a crime for anything.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You are too senseless obstinate, my lord,$NEWLINE$Too ceremonious and traditional.$NEWLINE$Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,$NEWLINE$You break not sanctuary in seizing him.$NEWLINE$The benefit thereof is always granted$NEWLINE$To those whose dealings have deserved the place$NEWLINE$And those who have the wit to claim the place.$NEWLINE$This prince hath neither claimed it nor deserved it$NEWLINE$And therefore, in mine opinion, cannot have it.$NEWLINE$Then taking him from thence that is not there,$NEWLINE$You break no privilege nor charter there.$NEWLINE$Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,$NEWLINE$But sanctuary children, ne'er till now.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You are too inexplicably stubborn, my lord, too stuck on ceremony. In these less dainty times, you’re not breaking the laws of sanctuary to seize him. It’s only a sanctuary for those who really need protection or those who are smart enough to claim they do. The prince has done neither; therefore, in my opinion, he isn’t really protected by sanctuary. You’re not breaking any holy laws to take him away. Often I have heard of “sanctuary men,” but until now I’ve never heard of “sanctuary children.”

paragraphs.original: CARDINAL$NEWLINE$My lord, you shall o'errule my mind for once.—$NEWLINE$Come on, Lord Hastings, will you go with me?
paragraphs.translated: CARDINAL$NEWLINE$My lord, you’ve won me over this time. Lord Hastings, will you go with me?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I go, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I’m coming, my lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Good lords, make all the speedy haste you may.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Go as fast as you can.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CARDINAL and HASTINGS$NEWLINE$CARDINAL$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: CARDINAL and HASTINGS exit.$NEWLINE$CARDINAL$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: Say, uncle Gloucester, if our brother come,$NEWLINE$Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
paragraphs.translated: Say, uncle Richard, if my brother comes, where will I stay till my coronation?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Where it seems best unto your royal self.$NEWLINE$If I may counsel you, some day or two$NEWLINE$Your Highness shall repose you at the Tower;$NEWLINE$Then where you please and shall be thought most fit$NEWLINE$For your best health and recreation.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Whatever seems best to you. If I can give you some advice, if I were you, I would stay in the Tower for a day or two. Then you can stay wherever best suits your health and entertainment needs.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$I do not like the Tower, of any place.—$NEWLINE$Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE$NEWLINE$Of all places, I don’t like the
Tower. Didn’t Julius Caesar build it, my lord?$NEWLINE$Tower$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$He did, my gracious lord, begin that place,$NEWLINE$Which, since, succeeding ages have re-edified.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$He started it, my noble lord, and succeeding generations rebuilt it.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Is it upon record, or else reported$NEWLINE$Successively from age to age, he built it?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Is it on record that he built it, or is it just word of mouth?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Upon record, my gracious lord.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$On record, my gracious lord.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$But say, my lord, it were not registered,$NEWLINE$Methinks the truth should live from age to age,$NEWLINE$As ’twere retailed to all posterity,$NEWLINE$Even to the general all-ending day.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Well, I think that even if it weren’t on record, the truth would be remembered from one generation to the next—all the way to Doomsday.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(aside) So wise so young, they say, do never live long.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to himself) As the saying goes, “Those that are this wise when they’re this young won’t live long.”$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What say you, uncle?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$What did you say, uncle?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I say, without characters fame lives long.$NEWLINE$(aside) Thus, like the formal Vice, Iniquity,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$I moralize two meanings in one word.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$I said, “When there are no written records, a person’s fame lasts for a long time.” (to himself) Like
Injustice, I get two meanings out of one word.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$Injustice$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$That Julius Caesar was a famous man.$NEWLINE$With what his valor did enrich his wit,$NEWLINE$His wit set down to make his valor live.$NEWLINE$Death makes no conquest of this conqueror,$NEWLINE$For now he lives in fame, though not in life.$NEWLINE$I’ll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham—
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$That Julius Caesar was a famous man. His courage helped his cleverness, and his cleverness made sure that his reputation for being courageous outlived him. Death didn’t conquer this conqueror, for he lives on in his fame, even though he’s dead. I’ll tell you what, my cousin Buckingham—$NEWLINE$this

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What, my gracious lord?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What, my dear lord?

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$An if I live until I be a man,$NEWLINE$I’ll win our ancient right in France again$NEWLINE$Or die a soldier, as I lived a king.
paragraphs.translated:
PRINCE$NEWLINE$If I live to be a man, I’ll win
France again or die a soldier, as honorably as I lived as a king.$NEWLINE$France$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(aside) Short summers lightly have a forward spring.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to himself) As the saying goes, “Short summers often have an early spring.” This smarty-pants won’t live long.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$CARDINAL
paragraphs.translated: Young YORK, HASTINGS, and the CARDINAL enter.$NEWLINE$YORK$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$CARDINAL

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Now in good time here comes the duke of York.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Making good time, here’s the duke of York.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Richard of York, how fares our loving brother?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Richard of York, how are you doing, my loving brother?

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Well, my dread lord—so must I call you now.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Very well, my supreme lord—that’s what I have to call you now.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Ay, brother, to our grief, as it is yours.$NEWLINE$Too late he died that might have kept that title,$NEWLINE$Which by his death hath lost much majesty.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Yes, brother, I feel bad about that, too. The man who might have kept that title died too soon, and now it isn’t worth nearly as much.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$How fares our cousin, noble Lord of York?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$How’s my nephew doing, noble lord of York?

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$I thank you, gentle uncle. O, my lord,$NEWLINE$You said that idle weeds are fast in growth.$NEWLINE$The prince my brother hath outgrown me far.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Thank you for asking, uncle. Oh, my lord, you once said that lazy weeds grow fast. The prince has far outgrown me.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He hath, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He has, my lord.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$And therefore is he idle?
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Does that mean he’s lazy?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$O, my fair cousin, I must not say so.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh, my handsome nephew, I must not say that.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Then is he more beholding to you than I.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$In that case, he’s more obliged to you than I am.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He may command me as my sovereign,$NEWLINE$But you have power in me as in a kinsman.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He may command me as my king, but you still have power over me as a relative.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$I pray you, uncle, give me this dagger.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Uncle, please give me your dagger.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My dagger, little cousin? With all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My dagger, little nephew? With all my heart.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$A beggar, brother?
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Are you begging, brother?

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Of my kind uncle, that I know will give,$NEWLINE$And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$From my kind uncle, who I know will give it to me, especially as it’s not worth much.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A greater gift than that I’ll give my cousin.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I’ll give you a greater gift than that, nephew.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$A greater gift? O, that’s the sword to it.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$A greater gift? That must mean a sword.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ay, gentle cousin, were it light enough.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Yes, gentle cousin, if it were light enough for you.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$O, then I see you will part but with light gifts.$NEWLINE$In weightier things you’ll say a beggar nay.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$Oh, I see, you will only part with lightweight presents. For more important things, you’ll say no.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A sword’s too heavy for you to wear.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$I weigh it lightly, were it heavier.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$I wouldn’t think much of it even if it were heavier.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What, would you have my weapon, little lord?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What, do you want to wear my weapon, little lord?$NEWLINE$my

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$I would, that I might thank you as you call me.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$I do, so I can thank you for what you called me.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$How?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What’s that?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Little.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$“Little.”

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$My lord of York will still be cross in talk.$NEWLINE$Uncle, your Grace knows how to bear with him.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$The lord of York is always a bit perverse in his chatter. But, uncle, you know how to bear with him.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me.—$NEWLINE$Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me.$NEWLINE$Because that I am little, like an ape,$NEWLINE$He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.
paragraphs.translated:
YORK$NEWLINE$You mean, to bear me, not to bear with me. Uncle, my brother makes fun of both of us. Because I’m little, like an
ape, he thinks you should bear me on your shoulders, like a fool.$NEWLINE$with$NEWLINE$ape$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(aside) With what a sharp-provided wit he reasons!$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,$NEWLINE$He prettily and aptly taunts himself.$NEWLINE$So cunning and so young is wonderful.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to himself) What a sharp mind this boy has! To make up for his scorn toward his uncle, he makes fun of himself as well. It’s amazing that he’s so cunning at his age.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE) My lord, will ’t please you pass along?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Myself and my good cousin Buckingham$NEWLINE$Will to your mother, to entreat of her$NEWLINE$To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE) My lord, will you please continue on your way to the Tower? My good cousin Buckingham and I will go to your mother and ask her to meet you there.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE) What, will you go unto the Tower, my lord?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$(to PRINCE) What, you’re going to the Tower, my lord?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$My lord protector needs will have it so.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$My protector, Richard, insists on it.

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$I shall not sleep in quiet at the Tower.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$I can’t sleep quietly in the Tower.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, what should you fear?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, what are you afraid of?

paragraphs.original: YORK$NEWLINE$Marry, my uncle Clarence' angry ghost.$NEWLINE$My grandam told me he was murdered there.
paragraphs.translated: YORK$NEWLINE$My uncle Clarence’s angry ghost. My grandmother told me he was murdered there.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$I fear no uncles dead.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$I’m not afraid of dead uncles.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Nor none that live, I hope.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Nor living ones, I hope.

paragraphs.original: PRINCE$NEWLINE$An if they live, I hope I need not fear.$NEWLINE$(to YORK) But come, my lord. With a heavy heart,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Thinking on them, go I unto the Tower.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE$NEWLINE$Well, I hope not. (to YORK) But come, my lord. With a heavy heart, thinking about my dead uncles, I will go to the Tower.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: A sennet. Exeunt all but RICHARD, BUCKINGHAM, and CATESBY$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: A trumpet sounds. Everyone except RICHARD, BUCKINGHAM, and CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Think you, my lord, this little prating York$NEWLINE$Was not incensèd by his subtle mother$NEWLINE$To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Richard, don’t you think this chattering little York was encouraged to taunt you by his sneaky mother in that outrageous way?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No doubt, no doubt. O, ’tis a parlous boy,$NEWLINE$Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable.$NEWLINE$He is all the mother’s, from the top to toe.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No doubt, no doubt. Oh, he’s a dangerously clever boy—bold, quick-witted, capable. He’s his mother’s child from head to toe.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Well, let them rest.—Come hither, Catesby.$NEWLINE$Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend$NEWLINE$As closely to conceal what we impart.$NEWLINE$Thou knowest our reasons, urged upon the way.$NEWLINE$What thinkest thou? Is it not an easy matter$NEWLINE$To make William Lord Hastings of our mind$NEWLINE$For the installment of this noble duke$NEWLINE$In the seat royal of this famous isle?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Well, enough about them.—Come here, Catesby. You’ve sworn to participate in our plot and to keep it a secret. What do you think: wouldn’t it be easy to convince Lord Hastings to join us in installing Richard as king of England?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$He, for his father’s sake, so loves the prince$NEWLINE$That he will not be won to aught against him.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Hastings loved the prince’s father so much that we won’t be able to persuade him to do anything against the prince.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What think’st thou then of Stanley? Will not he?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What about Stanley? Won’t he join us?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$He will do all in all as Hastings doth.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$He’ll do whatever Hastings does.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Well then, no more but this: go, gentle Catesby,$NEWLINE$And, as it were far off, sound thou Lord Hastings$NEWLINE$How he doth stand affected to our purpose$NEWLINE$And summon him tomorrow to the Tower$NEWLINE$To sit about the coronation.$NEWLINE$If thou dost find him tractable to us,$NEWLINE$Encourage him and show him all our reasons.$NEWLINE$If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling,$NEWLINE$Be thou so too, and so break off the talk,$NEWLINE$And give us notice of his inclination;$NEWLINE$For we tomorrow hold divided councils,$NEWLINE$Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Okay, just do this, noble Catesby: sound out Lord Hastings, but make it seem as if you’re just mulling over the idea, that it hasn’t been firmed up yet. Invite him to come to the Tower tomorrow for the coronation ceremony. If he seems game to our plan, encourage him to join us and explain all our reasons. But if he’s resistant and chilly, then be like that too and break off the conversation. Let us know how he responds. Tomorrow we’re going to hold two separate meetings, one for those who are with us and one for those who aren’t. You’ll have a lot to do in these meetings.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Commend me to Lord William. Tell him, Catesby,$NEWLINE$His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries$NEWLINE$Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret castle,$NEWLINE$And bid my lord, for joy of this good news,$NEWLINE$Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$Give my regards to Hastings, Catesby. Tell him the nest of dangerous enemies that plagued him for years will die tomorrow at Pomfret. And tell him to give
Mistress Shore one extra kiss to celebrate this good news.$NEWLINE$Mistress$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Good Catesby, go effect this business soundly.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Good Catesby, do your work well.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My good lords both, with all the heed I can.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My good lords, I plan to.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Shall we hear from you, Catesby, ere we sleep?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Will we hear from you before bedtime, Catesby?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$You shall, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$You will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$At Crosby Place, there shall you find us both.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You’ll find us both at Crosby Place.

paragraphs.original: Exit CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Now, my lord, what shall we do, if we perceive$NEWLINE$Lord Hastings will not yield to our complots?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Now, my lord, what are we going to do if we find that Lord Hastings won’t go along with our plans?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Chop off his head. Something we will determine.$NEWLINE$And look when I am king, claim thou of me$NEWLINE$The earldom of Hereford, and all the moveables$NEWLINE$Whereof the king my brother was possessed.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Chop off his head. Whatever we decide to do. And when I’m king, remember to ask me for the earldom of Hereford and all the possessions that go with it, which my brother the king used to own.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I’ll claim that promise at your Grace’s hands.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I look forward to that present.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$And look to have it yielded with all kindness.$NEWLINE$Come, let us sup betimes, that afterwards$NEWLINE$We may digest our complots in some form.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$You’ll find I’ll give it to you very willingly. Come, let’s have an early dinner so that we have time to work out our plans.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER at door of HASTINGS$NEWLINE$MESSENGER$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters and goes to Hastings’s door.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$(knocking) My lord, my lord.$NEWLINE$(knocking)
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$(knocking) My lord, my lord.$NEWLINE$(knocking)

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(within) Who knocks?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(offstage) Who’s knocking?$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$One from the Lord Stanley.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$A messenger from Lord Stanley.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(within) What is ‘t o’clock?$NEWLINE$(within)
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(offstage)What time is it?$NEWLINE$(offstage)

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Upon the stroke of four.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Four o'clock in the morning.

paragraphs.original: Enter HASTINGS$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS Enter$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Cannot my Lord Stanley sleep these tedious nights?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Can’t Lord Stanley sleep?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$So it appears by that I have to say.$NEWLINE$First, he commends him to your noble self.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I guess not—for good reason, as you’ll soon hear. First, he sends his regards.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$What then?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And then?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Then certifies your Lordship that this night$NEWLINE$He dreamt the boar had razèd his helm$NEWLINE$Besides, he says there are two councils kept,$NEWLINE$And that may be determined at the one$NEWLINE$Which may make you and him to rue at th' other.$NEWLINE$Therefore he sends to know your Lordship’s pleasure,$NEWLINE$If you will presently take horse with him$NEWLINE$And with all speed post with him toward the north$NEWLINE$To shun the danger that his soul divines.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$And then he said to tell you that tonight he dreamed the duke of Gloucester cut off his helmet—that is, his head. Besides that, he says that two meetings are going to be held tomorrow, and something may be decided at one of them that may make you and him, who are at the other, sorry. He wants to know if instead of going to the meeting, you’ll get on your horse and ride north with him to get out of harm’s way.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go, fellow, go. Return unto thy lord.$NEWLINE$Bid him not fear the separated council.$NEWLINE$His Honor and myself are at the one,$NEWLINE$And at the other is my good friend Catesby,$NEWLINE$Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us$NEWLINE$Whereof I shall not have intelligence.$NEWLINE$Tell him his fears are shallow, without instance.$NEWLINE$And for his dreams, I wonder he’s so simple$NEWLINE$To trust the mock'ry of unquiet slumbers.$NEWLINE$To fly the boar before the boar pursues$NEWLINE$Were to incense the boar to follow us$NEWLINE$And make pursuit where he did mean no chase.$NEWLINE$Go, bid thy master rise and come to me,$NEWLINE$And we will both together to the Tower,$NEWLINE$Where he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.
paragraphs.translated:
HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go, man, return to your lord and tell him not to worry about the separate meetings. While he and I are at one, my loyal servant Catesby will be at the other, so nothing will happen that we won’t find out about. Tell your master there is no sound basis for his worries. And as for his dreams, I’m surprised he’s so foolish as to trust the fantasies of a restless night. If we flee from the boar before the boar even pursues us, we’ll only make the boar angry and suspicious, causing him to chase us when he never intended to. Tell your master to get up and come here, and we’ll go together to the Tower to meet the
boar, who will treat us well, as he’ll see.$NEWLINE$boar$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’ll go, my lord, and tell him what you say.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$I’ll go, my lord, and tell him what you say.

paragraphs.original: Exits.
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY enters.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Many good morrows to my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Good morning, my noble lord.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Catesby. You are early stirring.$NEWLINE$What news, what news in this our tott'ring state?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Good day, Catesby. You’re up early. What news can you tell me in this fast-moving, unsteady state of ours?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$It is a reeling world indeed, my lord,$NEWLINE$And I believe will never stand upright$NEWLINE$Till Richard wear the garland of the realm.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Our world sure is spinning fast, my lord. I believe it won’t stop moving and stand upright till Richard wears the wreath of the realm.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$How “wear the garland”? Dost thou mean the crown?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$What do you mean, “wears the wreath”? Are you talking about the crown?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I’ll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders$NEWLINE$Before I’ll see the crown so foul misplaced.$NEWLINE$But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I’ll have my head cut from my shoulders before I’ll see the crown so misplaced. But do you think that’s what he’s aiming for?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Ay, on my life, and hopes to find you forward$NEWLINE$Upon his party for the gain thereof;$NEWLINE$And thereupon he sends you this good news,$NEWLINE$That this same very day your enemies,$NEWLINE$The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Yes, I swear, and he hopes you’ll join his party to help. For that reason he sends you this good news—that this very day your enemies, the queen’s relatives, will die at Pomfret.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Indeed, I am no mourner for that news,$NEWLINE$Because they have been still my adversaries.$NEWLINE$But that I’ll give my voice on Richard’s side$NEWLINE$To bar my master’s heirs in true descent,$NEWLINE$God knows I will not do it, to the death.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Well, I’m not sorry to hear that, because they have always been my enemies. But the idea that I’d give my support to Richard and keep my master King Edward IV’s true heirs from the crown—never. God knows I’d die before I’d do that.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$God keep your Lordship in that gracious mind.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Well, let’s hope you stay in that noble frame of mind.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence,$NEWLINE$That they which brought me in my master’s hate,$NEWLINE$I live to look upon their tragedy.$NEWLINE$Well, Catesby, ere a fortnight make me older$NEWLINE$I’ll send some packing that yet think not on ’t.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$In a year, when things have calmed down, I’ll laugh about how those who got King Edward IV to hate me are now brought low. But as for now—before two weeks have gone by, I’m going to send some people packing. They have no idea what’s coming.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord,$NEWLINE$When men are unprepared and look not for it.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$It’s a horrible thing to die when you’re not prepared for it, my gracious lord.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$O monstrous, monstrous! And so falls it out$NEWLINE$With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey; and so ’twill do$NEWLINE$With some men else that think themselves as safe$NEWLINE$As thou and I, who, as thou know’st, are dear$NEWLINE$To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Yes, monstrous, monstrous! That’s how it will be for Rivers, Vaughan, and Grey. That’s how it will be for some other men, too, who think they’re as safe as you and I, who are well-loved by noble Richard and Buckingham.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$The princes both make high account of you— (aside) For they account his head upon the Bridge.$NEWLINE$(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
CATESBY$NEWLINE$Richard and Buckingham have a high opinion of you. (to himself) So high they’ll stick your head on the
Bridge.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$Bridge$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I know they do, and I have well deserved it.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I know they do, and I certainly deserve it.

paragraphs.original: Enter STANLEY$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY enters.$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: Come on, come on. Where is your boar-spear, man?$NEWLINE$Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
paragraphs.translated: Come on, come on, where is your spear for the boar, man? You’re afraid of the boar but you go around without your spear?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$My lord, good morrow. —Good morrow, Catesby.—$NEWLINE$You may jest on, but, by the Holy Rood,$NEWLINE$I do not like these several councils, I.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$My lord, good morning. Good morning, Catesby. Go ahead and laugh at me, but by Jesus, I don’t like these separate meetings—I really don’t.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours,$NEWLINE$And never in my days, I do protest,$NEWLINE$Was it so precious to me as ’tis now.$NEWLINE$Think you but that I know our state secure,$NEWLINE$I would be so triumphant as I am?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$My lord, my life is as important to me as yours is to you, and it was never as precious to me as it is now. Do you think I would be feeling as triumphant as I am if I didn’t know that our situation was secure?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London,$NEWLINE$Were jocund and supposed their states were sure,$NEWLINE$And they indeed had no cause to mistrust;$NEWLINE$But yet you see how soon the day o'ercast.$NEWLINE$This sudden stab of rancor I misdoubt.$NEWLINE$Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward!$NEWLINE$What, shall we toward the Tower? The day is spent.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$When the lords who are imprisoned at Pomfret left London, they also were in a good mood and supposed their situation was secure. And they also had no reason to worry. But you see how soon the day got cloudy for them. Richard’s sudden, hateful attack on them makes me worry. I hope to God I’m proven wrong! Well, should we head to the Tower? The day is well on its way.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Come, come. Have with you. Wot you what, my lord?$NEWLINE$Today the lords you talked of are beheaded.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Come on, let’s get going. You know what, my lord? Those men you just mentioned will be beheaded today.

paragraphs.original: LORD STANLEY$NEWLINE$They, for their truth, might better wear their heads$NEWLINE$Than some that have accused them wear their hats.$NEWLINE$But come, my lord, let’s away.
paragraphs.translated: LORD STANLEY$NEWLINE$They deserved to keep their heads more than some people who have managed to keep their positions. But come, my lord, let’s go.

paragraphs.original: Enter a PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$PURSUIVANT
paragraphs.translated:
A
PURSUIVANT enters.$NEWLINE$PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go on before. I’ll talk with this good fellow.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Go on ahead. I’ll talk with this good man.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt STANLEY and CATESBY$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY and CATESBY exit.$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: How now, sirrah! How goes the world with thee?
paragraphs.translated: What’s up, man? How’s it going?

paragraphs.original: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$The better that your Lordship please to ask.
paragraphs.translated: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$Better, since your lordship was nice enough to ask.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I tell thee, man, ’tis better with me now$NEWLINE$Than when thou met’st me last where now we meet.$NEWLINE$Then was I going prisoner to the TowerBy the suggestion of the queen’s allies.$NEWLINE$But now, I tell thee—keep it to thyself—$NEWLINE$This day those enemies are put to death,$NEWLINE$And I in better state than e'er I was.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I tell you, man, it’s better for me, too, than the last time we met here. Then I was on my way to the Tower, where I was going to be locked up thanks to the false charges of the queen’s allies. But now, I tell you—keep it to yourself, though—those enemies of mine are being put to death today, and I’m better than I’ve ever been.

paragraphs.original: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$God hold it, to your Honor’s good content!
paragraphs.translated: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$Well, let’s hope your good fortune continues!

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Gramercy, fellow. There, drink that for me.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Thanks a lot, mister. Here, drink to me.

paragraphs.original: Throws him his purse
paragraphs.translated: He throws the PURSUIVANT some money.$NEWLINE$PURSUIVANT

paragraphs.original: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$I thank your Honor.
paragraphs.translated: PURSUIVANT$NEWLINE$God be good to you!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a PRIEST$NEWLINE$PRIEST
paragraphs.translated: A PRIEST enters.$NEWLINE$PRIEST

paragraphs.original: PRIEST$NEWLINE$Well met, my lord. I am glad to see your Honor.
paragraphs.translated: PRIEST$NEWLINE$A nice coincidence, my lord. I’m glad to see you.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart.$NEWLINE$I am in your debt for your last exercise.$NEWLINE$Come the next sabbath, and I will content you.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I thank you, Sir John, with all my heart. I am indebted to you for your last sermon. By next week, I’ll be able to pay you.

paragraphs.original: PRIEST$NEWLINE$I’ll wait upon your Lordship
paragraphs.translated: PRIEST$NEWLINE$I’ll come to you, your Lordship.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS whispers in his ear.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS whispers in his ear.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: Exit PRIEST$NEWLINE$PRIEST
paragraphs.translated: The PRIEST exits.$NEWLINE$PRIEST

paragraphs.original: Enter BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM enters.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What, talking with a priest, Lord Chamberlain?$NEWLINE$Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest;$NEWLINE$Your Honor hath no shriving work in hand.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$What, talking with a priest, Hastings? Your friends at Pomfret, they’re the ones who need a priest. You, on the other hand, don’t have any confessions you have to make.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Good faith, and when I met this holy man,$NEWLINE$The men you talk of came into my mind.$NEWLINE$What, go you toward the Tower?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$When I ran into this holy man, those men you mentioned did come to mind, in fact. Are you headed to the Tower?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I do, my lord, but long I shall not stay there.$NEWLINE$I shall return before your Lordship thence.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I am, my lord. But I won’t be there for long. I’ll be off before you are.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Nay, like enough, for I stay dinner there.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Yes, probably, because I’m staying for lunch.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(aside) And supper too, although thou know’st it not.—$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Come, will you go?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to himself) And for dinner, too, though you don’t know it. (to HASTINGS) Come, are you going?$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I’ll wait upon your Lordship.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I’ll follow you, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter Sir Richard RATCLIFFE, with halberds, carrying RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN to death at Pomfret.$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$GREY$NEWLINE$VAUGHAN
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE, enters with armed guards. He leads RIVERS, GREY, and VAUGHAN, to death at Pomfret.$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$GREY$NEWLINE$VAUGHAN

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell thee this:$NEWLINE$Today shalt thou behold a subject die$NEWLINE$For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Sir Richard Ratcliffe, let me tell you this. Today you will witness a person die for truth, duty, and loyality.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$(to RATCLIFFE)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$God bless the prince from all the pack of you!$NEWLINE$A knot you are of damnèd bloodsuckers.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$(to RATCLIFFE) God protect the prince from all of you. You’re a group of damned bloodsuckers!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: VAUGHAN$NEWLINE$(to RATCLIFFE) You live that shall cry woe for this hereafter.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: VAUGHAN$NEWLINE$(to RATCLIFFE) You’ll live to regret this.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Dispatch. The limit of your lives is out.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Hurry up. Your lives are over.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$O Pomfret, Pomfret! O thou bloody prison,$NEWLINE$Fatal and ominous to noble peers!$NEWLINE$Within the guilty closure of thy walls,$NEWLINE$Richard the Second here was hacked to death,$NEWLINE$And, for more slander to thy dismal seat,$NEWLINE$We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Oh, Pomfret, Pomfret! Oh, you bloody prison, fatal and threatening to noble lords! Within these guilty walls, Richard II was hacked to death. And now, to add more blood to its name, we’re losing our innocent lives here.

paragraphs.original: GREY$NEWLINE$Now Margaret’s curse is fall'n upon our heads,$NEWLINE$When she exclaimed on Hastings, you, and I,$NEWLINE$For standing by when Richard stabbed her son.
paragraphs.translated: GREY$NEWLINE$Now Margaret’s curse has fallen on our heads, for standing by and doing nothing when Richard stabbed her son.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Then cursed she Richard, then cursed she Buckingham.$NEWLINE$Then cursed she Hastings. O, remember, God,$NEWLINE$To hear her prayer for them, as now for us!$NEWLINE$And for my sister and her princely sons,$NEWLINE$Be satisfied, dear God, with our true blood,$NEWLINE$Which, as thou know’st, unjustly must be spilt.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$She cursed Richard then. She cursed Buckingham then. She cursed Hastings then. Oh God, remember to hear her prayer for them, just as for us! But don’t kill my sister and her royal sons, be satisfied, dear God, with our blood, which is being spilled unjustly, as you know.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Make haste. The hour of death is expiate.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Hurry up. The hour of death is approaching.

paragraphs.original: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Come, Grey. Come, Vaughan. Let us all embrace.$NEWLINE$They embrace$NEWLINE$They embrace$NEWLINE$Farewell until we meet in heaven.
paragraphs.translated: RIVERS$NEWLINE$Come, Grey. Come, Vaughan. Let’s embrace (They embrace) and say goodbye until we meet again in heaven.$NEWLINE$(They embrace)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BUCKINGHAM, STANLEY, HASTINGS, the bishop of ELY, RATCLIFFE, LOVELL, with others, at a table$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$ELY$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM, STANLEY, HASTINGS, the bishop of ELY, RATCLIFFE, and LOVELL, enter with others and take their seats at a table.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$ELY$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Now, noble peers. the cause why we are met$NEWLINE$Is to determine of the coronation.$NEWLINE$In God’s name, speak. When is the royal day?
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Now, noble lords, the reason we’re meeting is to determine the day the prince will be crowned. In God’s name, speak. When should the royal day be?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Is all things ready for the royal time?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Is everything ready for that event?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$It is, and wants but nomination.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$It is. All we have to do is name the day.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, then, I judge a happy day.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Tomorrow’s a good day.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Who knows the Lord Protector’s mind herein?$NEWLINE$Who is most inward with the noble duke?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Who knows what the Lord Protector thinks? Who’s closest to him?

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$Your Grace, we think, should soonest know his mind.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$You, I think, would best know what he’s thinking.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$We know each other’s faces; for our hearts,$NEWLINE$He knows no more of mine than I of yours,$NEWLINE$Or I of his, my lord, than you of mine.—$NEWLINE$Lord Hastings, you and he are near in love.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$We know each other’s faces, but as for our thoughts, he doesn’t know any more about my thinking than I do about yours or his—or you do about mine. Lord Hastings, you and he are close.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I thank his Grace.
