I know he loves me well.$NEWLINE$But for his purpose in the coronation,$NEWLINE$I have not sounded him, nor he delivered$NEWLINE$His gracious pleasure any way therein.$NEWLINE$But you, my honorable lords, may name the time,$NEWLINE$And in the duke’s behalf I’ll give my voice,$NEWLINE$Which I presume he’ll take in gentle part.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Thank you. I know he holds me dear, but I haven’t asked him about the coronation, and he hasn’t told me. But you, my noble lords, may name a time, and I’ll second it on the duke’s behalf, which I don’t think he’ll mind.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, enters.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$In happy time here comes the duke himself.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Right on cue, here’s the duke himself.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My noble lords and cousins all, good morrow.$NEWLINE$I have been long a sleeper; but I trust$NEWLINE$My absence doth neglect no great design$NEWLINE$Which by my presence might have been concluded.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My noble lords and relatives, good morning. I slept in. But I hope I didn’t delay any important decisions.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Had you not come upon your cue, my lord,$NEWLINE$William Lord Hastings had pronounced your part—$NEWLINE$I mean your voice for crowning of the king.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$If you hadn’t shown up on cue, my lord, Lord Hastings was going to take your part—I mean, he was going to speak for you—in the crowning of the king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Than my Lord Hastings no man might be bolder.$NEWLINE$His Lordship knows me well, and loves me well.—$NEWLINE$My lord of Ely, when I was last in Holborn$NEWLINE$I saw good strawberries in your garden there;$NEWLINE$I do beseech you, send for some of them.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$No one may be bolder than my Lord Hastings. He knows me well and loves me well.—Ely, when I was last at your palace, I saw some great strawberries in your garden. I beg you, send someone to bring some of them.

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$Marry and will, my lord, with all my heart.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. With pleasure.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He Exits.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.$NEWLINE$They move aside$NEWLINE$They move aside$NEWLINE$Catesby hath sounded Hastings in our business$NEWLINE$And finds the testy gentleman so hot$NEWLINE$As he will lose his head ere give consent$NEWLINE$His master’s child, as worshipfully he terms it,$NEWLINE$Shall lose the royalty of England’s throne.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Buckingham, I need to have a word with you. (drawing him aside) Catesby has sounded Hastings out and found the prickly gentleman so opposed to our plan that he actually said he would die before he’d agree to have his “master’s son,” as he put it so devotedly, lose the crown.$NEWLINE$(drawing him aside)

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Withdraw yourself awhile. I’ll go with you.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Move to the other room, my lord. I’ll come soon.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD exits, with BUCKINGHAM following him.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$We have not yet set down this day of triumph.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, in my judgement, is too sudden,$NEWLINE$For I myself am not so well provided$NEWLINE$As else I would be, were the day prolonged.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$We have not yet set the coronation day. Tomorrow, in my opinion, is too soon. I myself am not as well-equipped as I would be if the day were put off a bit.

paragraphs.original: Enter Bishop of ELY,$NEWLINE$ELY
paragraphs.translated: ELY returns.$NEWLINE$ELY

paragraphs.original: ELY$NEWLINE$Where is my lord the duke of Gloucester?$NEWLINE$I have sent for these strawberries.
paragraphs.translated: ELY$NEWLINE$Where is my lord, the duke of Gloucester? I have sent for the strawberries.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$His grace looks cheerfully and smooth this morning.$NEWLINE$There’s some conceit or other likes him well$NEWLINE$When that he bids good morrow with such spirit.$NEWLINE$I think there’s never a man in Christendom$NEWLINE$Can lesser hide his love or hate than he,$NEWLINE$For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Richard is looking cheerful today. You always know he’s got some plan that pleases him when he says good morning with such gusto. I don’t think there’s a man under the sun who’s worse at hiding his love or hate than Richard. You know his feelings immediately just by looking at his face.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$What of his heart perceive you in his face$NEWLINE$By any livelihood he showed today?
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$And what feelings did you see in his face today?

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Marry, that with no man here he is offended,$NEWLINE$For were he, he had shown it in his looks.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$That he’s not angry with anyone here. If he were, he would have shown it.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I pray God he be not, I say.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I pray to God he isn’t.

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM return.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I pray you all, tell me what they deserve$NEWLINE$That do conspire my death with devilish plots$NEWLINE$Of damnèd witchcraft, and that have prevailed$NEWLINE$Upon my body with their hellish charms?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Tell me, all of you, what punishment does a person deserve who conspires to kill me with witchcraft and who has already plagued my body with black magic?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$The tender love I bear your Grace, my lord,$NEWLINE$Makes me most forward in this princely presence$NEWLINE$To doom th' offenders, whosoe'er they be.$NEWLINE$I say, my lord, they have deservèd death.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Because I love your Grace, I say that whoever the offenders are deserve to die.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then be your eyes the witness of their evil.$NEWLINE$(shows his arm)$NEWLINE$(shows his arm)$NEWLINE$Look how I am bewitched! Behold mine arm$NEWLINE$Is like a blasted sapling withered up;$NEWLINE$And this is Edward’s wife, that monstrous witch,$NEWLINE$Consorted with that harlot, strumpet Shore,$NEWLINE$That by their witchcraft thus have markèd me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then see the evidence of their evil with your own eyes. (he shows his arm) Look how I’ve been bewitched! See how my arm has become like a withered tree-branch? This is the work of Edward’s wife, that monstrous witch, who is in league with that tramp Shore. They have used witchcraft to harm me.$NEWLINE$(he shows his arm)

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$If they have done this deed, my noble lord—
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$If they have done this thing, my noble lord—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If? Thou protector of this damnèd strumpet,$NEWLINE$Talk’st thou to me of “ifs”? Thou art a traitor—$NEWLINE$Off with his head. Now by Saint Paul I swear$NEWLINE$I will not dine until I see the same.—$NEWLINE$Lovell and Ratcliffe, look that it be done.—$NEWLINE$The rest that love me, rise and follow me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If? You lover of that damned whore, you’re talking to me of “ifs”? You’re a traitor.—Off with his head. By Saint Paul, I swear I won’t eat lunch until I see him beheaded. Lovell and Ratcliffe, make sure it gets done. The rest of you who love me, come with me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but HASTINGS, RATCLIFFE, and LOVELL,$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL
paragraphs.translated: Everyone but HASTINGS, RATCLIFFE, and LOVELL exits.$NEWLINE$HASTINGS$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Woe, woe for England! Not a whit for me,$NEWLINE$For I, too fond, might have prevented this.$NEWLINE$Stanley did dream the boar did raze his helm,$NEWLINE$And I did scorn it and disdain to fly.$NEWLINE$Three times today my foot-cloth horse did stumble,$NEWLINE$And started when he looked upon the Tower,$NEWLINE$As loath to bear me to the slaughterhouse.$NEWLINE$O, now I need the priest that spake to me!
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I pity England, but not myself. I was too foolish. I might have prevented this. Stanley dreamed the boar beheaded him, and I laughed and refused to flee with him. Three times today my horse stumbled and started when he looked in the direction of the Tower, as if he hated to carry me to this slaughterhouse. Oh, now I really need that priest who spoke to me today!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$I now repent I told the pursuivant,$NEWLINE$As too triumphing, how mine enemies$NEWLINE$Today at Pomfret bloodily were butchered,$NEWLINE$And I myself secure in grace and favor.$NEWLINE$O Margaret, Margaret, now thy heavy curse$NEWLINE$Is lighted on poor Hastings' wretched head.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$And I regret having bragged to the messenger about how my enemies were being butchered at Pomfret while I, as I said, was in good standing with Richard. Oh Margaret, Margaret, your heavy curse has now landed on poor Hastings’s miserable head!

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Come, come, dispatch. The duke would be at dinner.$NEWLINE$Make a short shrift. He longs to see your head.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Hurry up—the duke wants to eat his dinner. Make your confession short. He’s eager to see your head.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$O momentary grace of mortal men,$NEWLINE$Which we more hunt for than the grace of God!$NEWLINE$Who builds his hopes in air of your good looks$NEWLINE$Lives like a drunken sailor on a mast,$NEWLINE$Ready with every nod to tumble down$NEWLINE$Into the fatal bowels of the deep.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$We spend more time seeking out the fleeting glories of this temporary world than looking to the permanent grace of God! Anyone who builds his hopes on air lives like a drunken sailor hanging on a mast, ready with every dizzy nod of his head to tumble to the bottom of the sea. The things we worry about, like good looks and possessions, aren’t lasting, and they don’t matter.

paragraphs.original: LOVELL$NEWLINE$Come, come, dispatch. 'Tis bootless to exclaim.
paragraphs.translated: LOVELL$NEWLINE$Come, come, hurry up. It’s pointless to talk now.

paragraphs.original: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$O bloody Richard! Miserable England,$NEWLINE$I prophesy the fearfull’st time to thee$NEWLINE$That ever wretched age hath looked upon.—$NEWLINE$Come, lead me to the block. Bear him my head.$NEWLINE$They smile at me that shortly shall be dead.
paragraphs.translated: HASTINGS$NEWLINE$Oh bloody Richard! Miserable England, I foresee for you the most frightening time you have ever experienced.—Come, lead me to the block. Bring him my head. Those who smile at it will soon be dead themselves.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM, in rotten armor, marvelous ill-favored$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM enter wearing rusty, hideous-looking armor.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Come, cousin, canst thou quake and change thy color,$NEWLINE$Murder thy breath in the middle of a word,$NEWLINE$And then begin again, and stop again,$NEWLINE$As if thou wert distraught and mad with terror?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Tell me, cousin, I need to know if you can shake like you’ve got a fever, turn pale all of a sudden, and stop speaking in the middle of a word—as if you were driven crazy with fear.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Tut, I can counterfeit the deep tragedian,$NEWLINE$Speak, and look back, and pry on every side,$NEWLINE$Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,$NEWLINE$Intending deep suspicion. Ghastly looks$NEWLINE$Are at my service, like enforcèd smiles,$NEWLINE$And both are ready in their offices,$NEWLINE$At any time to grace my stratagems.$NEWLINE$But what, is Catesby gone?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Oh please, I can imitate the best tragic actor around. I can speak and then look all around, and tremble, and start at a mere piece of straw as if I were paranoid. Frightening looks are also at my service, as are fake smiles. Anytime I need them, they’re waiting to do my bidding. But has Catesby gone?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He is; and see, he brings the mayor along.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He has. But here he is, back with the mayor.

paragraphs.original: Enter the LORD MAYOR and CATESBY$NEWLINE$LORD$NEWLINE$MAYOR$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: The LORD MAYOR and CATESBY enter.$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Lord Mayor—
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Lord Mayor—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Look to the drawbridge there!
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$Watch out for the
drawbridge over there!$NEWLINE$drawbridge$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Hark, a drum!
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Listen! A drum!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Catesby, o'erlook the walls.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Catesby, look over the top of these walls to see if anyone’s there.

paragraphs.original: Exit CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent—
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Lord Mayor, the reason we have sent—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Look back! Defend thee! Here are enemies.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Look behind you! Defend yourself! There are enemies here.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$God and our innocence defend and guard us!
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$God defend and guard us innocents against them!

paragraphs.original: Enter LOVELL and RATCLIFFE, with HASTINGS’s head$NEWLINE$LOVELL$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$HASTINGS’s
paragraphs.translated: LOVELL and RATCLIFFE enter with HASTINGS’s head.$NEWLINE$LOVELL$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$HASTINGS’s

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Be patient. They are friends, Ratcliffe and Lovell.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Stay calm. They’re friends—Ratcliffe and Lovell.

paragraphs.original: LOVELL$NEWLINE$Here is the head of that ignoble traitor,$NEWLINE$The dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.
paragraphs.translated: LOVELL$NEWLINE$Here’s the head of that notorious traitor, the dangerous and unsuspected Hastings.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$So dear I loved the man that I must weep.$NEWLINE$I took him for the plainest harmless creature$NEWLINE$That breathed upon this earth a Christian;$NEWLINE$Made him my book, wherein my soul recorded$NEWLINE$The history of all her secret thoughts.$NEWLINE$So smooth he daubed his vice with show of virtue$NEWLINE$That, his apparent open guilt omitted—$NEWLINE$I mean his conversation with Shore’s wife—$NEWLINE$He lived from all attainder of suspects.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I loved this man so much it makes me weep. I took him to be the plainest, most harmless Christian on earth. He was the book in which I recorded all of my most secret thoughts. He was so slick in covering over his plans that if it hadn’t been for his love affair with Shore’s wife, I would never have suspected him.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Well, well, he was the covert’st sheltered traitor$NEWLINE$That ever lived.—$NEWLINE$Would you imagine, or almost believe,$NEWLINE$Were ’t not that by great preservation$NEWLINE$We live to tell it, that subtle traitor$NEWLINE$This day had plotted, in the council house$NEWLINE$To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Well, well, he was the most covert traitor who ever lived. Would you believe, if we hadn’t caught him, this subtle traitor would have murdered the Lord of Gloucester and me in the council room today?

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$Had he done so?
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$He would have?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What, think you we are Turks or infidels?$NEWLINE$Or that we would, against the form of law,$NEWLINE$Proceed thus rashly in the villain’s death,$NEWLINE$But that the extreme peril of the case,$NEWLINE$The peace of England and our persons' safety$NEWLINE$Enforced us to this execution?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What, do you think we’re Turks or savages, instead of Christians? You think we would have disobeyed the law and proceeded to kill this villain if England’s peace and our own lives hadn’t been at stake?

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$Now fair befall you! He deserved his death,$NEWLINE$And your good Graces both have well proceeded$NEWLINE$To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$I hope nothing else like this ever happens to you! This man deserved his death. And you, my good lords, were right to warn other traitors from trying the same.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I never looked for better at his hands$NEWLINE$After he once fell in with Mistress Shore.$NEWLINE$Yet had we not determined he should die$NEWLINE$Until your Lordship came to see his end$NEWLINE$(Which now the loving haste of these our friends,$NEWLINE$Something against our meaning, have prevented),$NEWLINE$Because, my lord, I would have had you heard$NEWLINE$The traitor speak, and timorously confess$NEWLINE$The manner and the purpose of his treasons,$NEWLINE$That you might well have signified the same$NEWLINE$Unto the citizens, who haply may$NEWLINE$Misconstrue us in him, and wail his death.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I didn’t expect any better from him once he got involved with Mistress Shore. But we had decided that he shouldn’t die until you were able to come witness his execution. (Which was prevented by the haste of our friends, Lovell and Ratcliffe here, who went against what we intended somewhat in their hurry to protect us). If you could have heard the traitor speak for himself and confess the exact way he planned to murder us, you could have told the citizens what terrible intentions he had, though now they’re likely to misconstrue what we did and wail over his death.

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$But, my good lord, your Graces' words shall serve$NEWLINE$As well as I had seen and heard him speak;$NEWLINE$And do not doubt, right noble princes both,$NEWLINE$But I’ll acquaint our duteous citizens$NEWLINE$With all your just proceedings in this case.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$But, my good lord, the words of you and Lord Buckingham are as trustworthy to me as if I had seen and heard him speak myself. And do not doubt, you honest, noble princes, that I’ll let our citizens know how fairly you proceeded in this case.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$And to that end we wished your Lordship here$NEWLINE$T' avoid the censures of the carping world.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That is exactly why we wanted you here, your lordship—to avoid the public carping and complaints.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Which since you come too late of our intent,$NEWLINE$Yet witness what you hear we did intend.$NEWLINE$And so, my good Lord Mayor, we bid farewell.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$But since you’ve come too late to see the execution as we intended, at least let people know what you hear we intended. And so, good Lord Mayor, we bid you goodbye.$NEWLINE$hear

paragraphs.original: Exit LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR
paragraphs.translated: The LORD MAYOR exits.$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.$NEWLINE$The mayor towards Guildhall hies him in all post.$NEWLINE$There, at your meetest vantage of the time,$NEWLINE$Infer the bastardy of Edward’s children.$NEWLINE$Tell them how Edward put to death a citizen$NEWLINE$Only for saying he would make his son$NEWLINE$Heir to the Crown—meaning indeed his house,$NEWLINE$Which, by the sign thereof, was termèd so.$NEWLINE$Moreover, urge his hateful luxury$NEWLINE$And bestial appetite in change of lust,$NEWLINE$Which stretched to their servants, daughters, wives,$NEWLINE$Even where his raging eye or savage heart,$NEWLINE$Without control, lusted to make his prey.$NEWLINE$Nay, for a need, thus far come near my person:$NEWLINE$Tell them when that my mother went with child$NEWLINE$Of that insatiate Edward, noble York$NEWLINE$My princely father then had wars in France,$NEWLINE$And, by true computation of the time,$NEWLINE$Found that the issue was not his begot,$NEWLINE$Which well appearèd in his lineaments,$NEWLINE$Being nothing like the noble duke my father.$NEWLINE$Yet touch this sparingly, as ’twere far off,$NEWLINE$Because, my lord, you know my mother lives.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Follow him, Buckingham. He’s traveling at a gallop to the London meeting hall. There, as soon as you have a chance, drop the hint that Edward’s children are bastards. Tell the citizens how Edward put to death a citizen just because the citizen said he was going to make his own son “heir to the crown”—when all the citizen meant was that he owned a tavern called “the Crown” and was going to leave it to his son. And then point out what a lech Edward was and what a bestial appetite he had for women, which touched even the citizens' own servants, daughters, and wives. There was no limit to what his lustful eye and savage heart would prey on. And, if you need to, approach the subject of me: tell them that when my mother became pregnant with the insatiable Edward, my noble father was fighting in France. With a little calculating, it’s obvious that Edward is not in fact my father’s child—not a surprising revelation if you consider how my father the noble duke looked nothing like this man. But only hint at this vaguely, because, as you know, my mother’s still alive.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Doubt not, my lord. I’ll play the orator$NEWLINE$As if the golden fee for which I plead$NEWLINE$Were for myself. And so, my lord, adieu.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Don’t worry, my lord, I’ll be as eloquent as if the golden crown I’m pleading for were for myself. Goodbye, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If you thrive well, bring them to Baynard’s Castle,$NEWLINE$Where you shall find me well accompanied$NEWLINE$With reverend fathers and well-learnèd bishops.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$If things go well, bring the crowd to
Baynard’s Castle, where I’ll be surrounded by priests and learned bishops.$NEWLINE$Baynard’s$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I go; and towards three or four o'clock$NEWLINE$Look for the news that the Guildhall affords.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I’m off. Around three or four o'clock, look for news from the meeting hall.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM exits.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Go, Lovell, with all speed to Doctor Shaw.$NEWLINE$(to RATCLIFFE) Go thou to Friar Penker. Bid them both$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Meet me within this hour at Baynard’s Castle.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Lovell, go as fast as you can to Doctor Shaw. (to RATCLIFFE) Go to Friar Penker. Both of you, tell these men to meet me in less than an hour at Baynard’s Castle.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit LOVELL and RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE
paragraphs.translated: LOWELL and RADCLIFFE exits.$NEWLINE$LOWELL$NEWLINE$RADCLIFFE

paragraphs.original: Now will I go to take some privy order$NEWLINE$To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight,$NEWLINE$And to give order that no manner of person$NEWLINE$Have any time recourse unto the princes.
paragraphs.translated: Now I’ll go inside and write out a secret order to keep Clarence’s brats out of sight and to forbid anyone whatsoever from seeing King Edward’s sons.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a SCRIVENER, with paper$NEWLINE$SCRIVENER
paragraphs.translated:
A
SCRIVENER enters with a paper in his hand.$NEWLINE$SCRIVENER$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SCRIVENER$NEWLINE$This is the indictment of the good Lord Hastings,$NEWLINE$Which in a set hand fairly is engrossed,$NEWLINE$That it may be today read o'er in Paul’s.$NEWLINE$And mark how well the sequel hangs together:$NEWLINE$Eleven hours I have spent to write it over,$NEWLINE$For yesternight by Catesby was it sent me;$NEWLINE$The precedent was full as long a-doing,$NEWLINE$And yet within these five hours Hastings lived,$NEWLINE$Untainted, unexamined, free, at liberty.$NEWLINE$Here’s a good world the while. Who is so gross$NEWLINE$That cannot see this palpable device?$NEWLINE$Yet who so bold but says he sees it not?$NEWLINE$Bad is the world, and all will come to naught$NEWLINE$When such ill dealing must be seen in thought.
paragraphs.translated: SCRIVENER$NEWLINE$Here’s the indictment of the good Lord Hastings, which has been written out in a clear hand, like any legal document, so it can be read aloud in public outside St. Paul’s Cathedral. And look how well this sequence of events holds together: after Catesby brought the indictment to me last night, I spent eleven hours copying it. The original took just as long to write out. So that’s twenty-two hours. And yet five hours ago, Lord Hastings was alive, untouched, free, at liberty. What a backward world we live in! Why, who’s so stupid that he can’t see through this fraud? But who’s so blind to the consequences of speaking out that he’ll admit what he knows? The world is a bad place, where you can’t speak what you know.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM, at several doors$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD and BUCKINGHAM, enter through different doors.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$How now, how now? What say the citizens?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$So what did the citizens say?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Now, by the holy mother of our Lord,$NEWLINE$The citizens are mum, say not a word.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$It’s incredible—they didn’t say a word.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Touched you the bastardy of Edward’s children?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Did you mention that Edward’s children are bastards?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I did; with his contract with Lady Lucy$NEWLINE$And his contract by deputy in France;$NEWLINE$Th' unsatiate greediness of his desire$NEWLINE$And his enforcement of the city wives;$NEWLINE$His tyranny for trifles; his own bastardy,$NEWLINE$As being got, your father then in France,$NEWLINE$His resemblance being not like the duke.$NEWLINE$Withal, I did infer your lineaments,$NEWLINE$Being the right idea of your father,$NEWLINE$Both in your form and nobleness of mind;$NEWLINE$Laid open all your victories in Scotland,$NEWLINE$Your discipline in war, wisdom in peace,$NEWLINE$Your bounty, virtue, fair humility;$NEWLINE$Indeed, left nothing fitting for your purpose$NEWLINE$Untouched or slightly handled in discourse.$NEWLINE$And when mine oratory grew toward end,$NEWLINE$I bid them that did love their country’s good$NEWLINE$Cry “God save Richard, England’s royal king!”
paragraphs.translated:
BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I did. I talked about how he was engaged to
Lady Lucy, and how he was engaged to
Lady Bona through the help of the earl of Warwick. I spoke of the unquenchable greediness of Edward’s desires and the way he forced himself on the wives of Londoners. I mentioned the way he punished people harshly for minor offenses. I said he was not the son of the noble duke of York, because your father was in France when he was conceived, which explains why he doesn’t have anything in common with his father. And then I suggested that you were the spitting image of your father, both in the way you look and in the nobleness of your character. I went into all your victories in Scotland, your skill as a warrior, your wisdom in peacetime, your generosity, your goodness, and your exceptional modesty. Indeed, I left nothing out. And when my oration came to a close, I asked those who loved their country to cry, “God save Richard, England’s royal king!”$NEWLINE$Lady Lucy$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Lady Bona$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$And did they so?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$And did they?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$No. So God help me, they spake not a word$NEWLINE$But, like dumb statues or breathing stones,$NEWLINE$Stared each on other and looked deadly pale;$NEWLINE$Which when I saw, I reprehended them$NEWLINE$And asked the mayor what meant this willful silence.$NEWLINE$His answer was, the people were not used$NEWLINE$To be spoke to but by the recorder.$NEWLINE$Then he was urged to tell my tale again:$NEWLINE$“Thus saith the duke. Thus hath the duke inferred”—$NEWLINE$But nothing spoke in warrant from himself.$NEWLINE$When he had done, some followers of mine own,$NEWLINE$At the lower end of the hall, hurled up their caps,$NEWLINE$And some ten voices cried “God save King Richard!”$NEWLINE$And thus I took the vantage of those few.$NEWLINE$“Thanks, gentle citizens and friends,” quoth I.$NEWLINE$"This general applause and cheerful shout$NEWLINE$Argues your wisdoms and your love to Richard"—$NEWLINE$And even here brake off, and came away.
paragraphs.translated:
BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$No, God help me, they didn’t say a word. Like silent statues or stones that breathed, they just gazed at each other and turned as pale as the dead. When I saw this, I scolded them and asked the mayor what this stubborn silence meant. He said that the people weren’t used to being spoken to except by the
Recorder. So I urged the Recorder to repeat my tale—you know, “The duke of Buckingham said this, Buckingham meant that,” but nothing on his own authority. When he was done, a few followers of my own at the far end of the hall hurled their caps in the air. Some ten voices cried, “God save King Richard!” I jumped on this slender opportunity and said, “Thank you, noble citizens and friends. This widespread applause and enthusiastic shouts make clear you stand behind Richard.” And then I broke off and quickly came away.$NEWLINE$Recorder$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What tongueless blocks were they! Would not they speak?$NEWLINE$Will not the mayor then and his brethren come?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What blocks of wood! They wouldn’t say anything? Aren’t the mayor and his fellow citizens coming?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$The mayor is here at hand. Intend some fear;$NEWLINE$Be not you spoke with but by mighty suit.$NEWLINE$And look you get a prayer book in your hand$NEWLINE$And stand between two churchmen, good my lord,$NEWLINE$For on that ground I’ll make a holy descant.$NEWLINE$And be not easily won to our requests.$NEWLINE$Play the maid’s part: still answer “nay,” and take it.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$The mayor is here at hand. Pretend you’re afraid, my lord, and don’t speak until you’re pleaded with. And make sure to carry a prayer book in your hand and to stand between two priests, okay? Then I’ll have the grounds to build a holy sermon about why you should be king. But don’t be easily won over. Act like a virgin, always answering “No,” but taking it in the end.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I go. An if you plead as well for them$NEWLINE$As I can say “nay” to thee for myself,$NEWLINE$No doubt we bring it to a happy issue.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I’m going now. If you’re as good at pleading to them as I am at saying no to you, this will definitely come to a happy end.

paragraphs.original: Knocking within
paragraphs.translated: A sound of knocking from offstage.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Go, go, up to the leads. The Lord Mayor knocks.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Hurry, go up to the roof. The Lord Mayor is knocking.

paragraphs.original: Exit RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD exits.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: Enter the LORD MAYOR and CITIZENS$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$CITIZENS
paragraphs.translated: The LORD MAYOR and CITIZENS enter.$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$CITIZENS

paragraphs.original: Welcome, my lord. I dance attendance here.$NEWLINE$I think the duke will not be spoke withal.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome, my lord. I’m twiddling my thumbs waiting for the duke to show up. I don’t think he wants to be disturbed.

paragraphs.original: Enter CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY enters.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: Now, Catesby, what says your lord to my request?
paragraphs.translated: Here comes his servant. Now, Catesby, what does your lord say to my request?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$He doth entreat your Grace, my noble lord,$NEWLINE$To visit him tomorrow or next day.$NEWLINE$He is within, with two right reverend fathers,$NEWLINE$Divinely bent to meditation,$NEWLINE$And in no worldly suits would he be moved$NEWLINE$To draw him from his holy exercise.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My lord, he asks that you please visit him tomorrow or the next day. He’s inside in prayer, with two reverend fathers. He doesn’t want to be disturbed in his holy work by any worldly requests.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Return, good Catesby, to the gracious duke.$NEWLINE$Tell him myself, the mayor, and aldermen,$NEWLINE$No less importing than our general good,$NEWLINE$In deep designs, and matters of great moment$NEWLINE$Are come to have some conference with his grace.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Return to the gracious duke, good Catesby. Tell him that the mayor, some citizens, and I have come to confer with his grace in matters of great importance concerning the general good.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$I’ll signify so much unto him straight.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$I’ll tell him right away, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Ah, ha, my lord, this prince is not an Edward!$NEWLINE$He is not lolling on a lewd love bed,$NEWLINE$But on his knees at meditation;$NEWLINE$Not dallying with a brace of courtesans,$NEWLINE$But meditating with two deep divines;$NEWLINE$Not sleeping, to engross his idle body,$NEWLINE$But praying, to enrich his watchful soul.$NEWLINE$Happy were England would this virtuous prince$NEWLINE$Take on his grave the sovereignty thereof.$NEWLINE$But sure I fear we shall not win him to it.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Ah, my lord, this prince is nothing like Edward! He is not lolling in bed but on his knees in prayer. He’s not enjoying himself with a couple of prostitutes but studying with two learned priests. He’s not sleeping to fatten up his lazy body, but praying, to nourish his attentive soul. England would be lucky to have this virtuous prince as king. But I’m afraid we’ll never get him to agree to be king.

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$Marry, God defend his grace should say us nay!
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$But God forbid he says no to us!

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I fear he will. Here Catesby comes again.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I’m afraid he will. Here comes Catesby again.

paragraphs.original: Enter CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY returns.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: Now, Catesby, what says his grace?
paragraphs.translated: What’s up, Catesby, what does your master say?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$He wonders to what end you have assembled$NEWLINE$Such troops of citizens to come to him,$NEWLINE$His grace not being warned thereof before.$NEWLINE$He fears, my lord, you mean no good to him.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My lord, he wonders why you have assembled such troops of citizens to speak with him, since he had no idea they were coming. My lord, he’s afraid you mean him harm.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Sorry I am my noble cousin should$NEWLINE$Suspect me that I mean no good to him.$NEWLINE$By heaven, we come to him in perfect love,$NEWLINE$And so once more return and tell his grace.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$I’m sorry my noble brother is suspicious of me. By God, I’m here because I love him. Return and tell him so.

paragraphs.original: Exit CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: When holy and devout religious men$NEWLINE$Are at their beads, ’tis much to draw them thence,$NEWLINE$So sweet is zealous contemplation.
paragraphs.translated: When devoutly religious men are praying, it’s hard to draw them out of it, because they get lost in the wonder of their contemplation.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD aloft, between two bishops CATESBY returns$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD enters overhead, between two bishops. CATESBY returns.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$See where his Grace stands, ’tween two clergymen.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$See how he stands between two clergymen!

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Two props of virtue for a Christian prince,$NEWLINE$To stay him from the fall of vanity;$NEWLINE$And, see, a book of prayer in his hand,$NEWLINE$True ornaments to know a holy man.—$NEWLINE$Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,$NEWLINE$Lend favorable ears to our requests,$NEWLINE$And pardon us the interruption$NEWLINE$Of thy devotion and right Christian zeal.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Two props of virtue for a Christian prince, to prevent him from ever becoming vain. And, see, he has a prayer book in each hand, the signs of a holy man. Most gracious prince of the famous house of Plantagenet, pardon us for interrupting your righteous, Christian prayer. Please listen favorably to our request.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My lord, there needs no such apology.$NEWLINE$I do beseech your Grace pardon me,$NEWLINE$Who, earnest in the service of my God,$NEWLINE$Deferred the visitation of my friends.$NEWLINE$But, leaving this, what is your Grace’s pleasure?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My lord, you don’t need to apologize. I beg you to pardon me. I’ve been so intent on serving God that I’ve kept my friends waiting. In any case, what would you like?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above$NEWLINE$And all good men of this ungoverned isle.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Only what, I hope, will please God above and all good men on this island, which currently has no king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I do suspect I have done some offense$NEWLINE$That seems disgracious in the city’s eye,$NEWLINE$And that you come to reprehend my ignorance.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I suspect that I have committed some offence to the city and you have come to reprimand me for not knowing better.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You have, my lord. Would it might please your Grace,$NEWLINE$On our entreaties, to amend your fault.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$You have, my lord. I hope you’ll make up for it!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why else would I live in a Christian country, if I can’t ask forgiveness for my faults?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Know, then, it is your fault that you resign$NEWLINE$The supreme seat, the throne majestical,$NEWLINE$The sceptered office of your ancestors,$NEWLINE$Your state of fortune, and your due of birth,$NEWLINE$The lineal glory of your royal house,$NEWLINE$To the corruption of a blemished stock,$NEWLINE$Whiles in the mildness of your sleepy thoughts,$NEWLINE$Which here we waken to our country’s good,$NEWLINE$The noble isle doth want her proper limbs—$NEWLINE$Her face defaced with scars of infamy,$NEWLINE$Her royal stock graft with ignoble plants,$NEWLINE$And almost shouldered in the swallowing gulf$NEWLINE$Of dark forgetfulness and deep oblivion;$NEWLINE$Which to recure, we heartily solicit$NEWLINE$Your gracious self to take on you the charge$NEWLINE$And kingly government of this your land,$NEWLINE$Not as Protector, steward, substitute,$NEWLINE$Or lowly factor for another’s gain,$NEWLINE$But as successively, from blood to blood,$NEWLINE$Your right of birth, your empery, your own.$NEWLINE$For this, consorted with the citizens,$NEWLINE$Your very worshipful and loving friends,$NEWLINE$And by their vehement instigation,$NEWLINE$In this just suit come I to move your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Then you should know that we take fault with your resigning the supreme seat, the majestic throne, the sceptered office, of your ancestors—the power and greatness that destiny and your noble birth have handed you—to the wrong person. You aren’t respecting the lineage of your royal family. You’re lost in sleepy thoughts, and we have come to wake you to our country’s needs. This noble island has been compromised. She is scarred by the infamous deeds of King Edward IV. Her royal stock has been corrupted and nearly lost. We want that royalty remembered again. We heartily beg you, in all your goodness, to take upon yourself the responsibility and rule of this land, not merely as a servant, substitute, or other lowly agent of the king, but as the king himself. It is your birthright to be king. It’s for this reason that we are here—the citizens of England and your devoted friends. We strongly urge you on.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I cannot tell if to depart in silence$NEWLINE$Or bitterly to speak in your reproof$NEWLINE$Best fitteth my degree or your condition.$NEWLINE$If not to answer, you might haply think$NEWLINE$Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded$NEWLINE$To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,$NEWLINE$Which fondly you would here impose on me.$NEWLINE$If to reprove you for this suit of yours,$NEWLINE$So seasoned with your faithful love to me,$NEWLINE$Then on the other side I checked my friends.$NEWLINE$Therefore, to speak, and to avoid the first,$NEWLINE$And then, in speaking, not to incur the last,$NEWLINE$Definitively thus I answer you:$NEWLINE$Your love deserves my thanks, but my desert$NEWLINE$Unmeritable shuns your high request.$NEWLINE$First, if all obstacles were cut away$NEWLINE$And that my path were even to the crown$NEWLINE$As the ripe revenue and due of birth,$NEWLINE$Yet so much is my poverty of spirit,$NEWLINE$So mighty and so many my defects,$NEWLINE$That I would rather hide me from my greatness,$NEWLINE$Being a bark to brook no mighty sea,$NEWLINE$Than in my greatness covet to be hid$NEWLINE$And in the vapor of my glory smothered.$NEWLINE$But, God be thanked, there is no need of me,$NEWLINE$And much I need to help you, were there need.$NEWLINE$The royal tree hath left us royal fruit,$NEWLINE$Which, mellowed by the stealing hours of time,$NEWLINE$Will well become the seat of majesty,$NEWLINE$And make, no doubt, us happy by his reign.$NEWLINE$On him I lay what you would lay on me,$NEWLINE$The right and fortune of his happy stars,$NEWLINE$Which God defend that I should wring from him.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I can’t tell which is the better course of action, to leave in silence or to scold you. If I don’t answer, perhaps you’ll think I’m accepting the heavy responsibility you foolishly want to impose on me. But if I do speak and refuse your request, then I’m guilty of reprimanding my friends, who have been faithful and loving toward me.$NEWLINE$So, I’ll speak to make clear I don’t want the crown but also that I am grateful to you. Here is my definitive answer: thank you for your love, but I’m going to have to turn down your weighty request because I don’t deserve to be king. First of all, even if all the obstacles were eliminated and my path led straight to the crown—if it were truly my birthright—I would rather hide from my greatness than hide inside the greatness of the position itself and be smothered by it. My spirit is poor, and I have so many terrible defects that as king I would be like a little boat tossed about on a mighty sea. So, thank God, there is no real need for me, as I wouldn’t be able to help you much. The royal tree has left us other fruit, which, with time, will do just fine on the throne and make us all happy as king, I’m sure. Someone other than I has the right and the good fortune to be made king. God forbid that I snatch the crown from him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$My lord, this argues conscience in your Grace,$NEWLINE$But the respects thereof are nice and trivial,$NEWLINE$All circumstances well considerèd.$NEWLINE$You say that Edward is your brother’s son;$NEWLINE$So say we too, but not by Edward’s wife.$NEWLINE$For first was he contract to Lady Lucy—$NEWLINE$Your mother lives a witness to that vow—$NEWLINE$And afterward by substitute betrothed$NEWLINE$To Bona, sister to the king of France.$NEWLINE$These both put off, a poor petitioner,$NEWLINE$A care-crazed mother to a many sons,$NEWLINE$A beauty-waning and distressèd widow,$NEWLINE$Even in the afternoon of her best days,$NEWLINE$Made prize and purchase of his wanton eye,$NEWLINE$Seduced the pitch and height of his degree$NEWLINE$To base declension and loathed bigamy.$NEWLINE$By her in his unlawful bed he got$NEWLINE$This Edward, whom our manners term “the Prince.”$NEWLINE$More bitterly could I expostulate,$NEWLINE$Save that, for reverence to some alive,$NEWLINE$I give a sparing limit to my tongue.$NEWLINE$Then, good my lord, take to your royal self$NEWLINE$This proffered benefit of dignity,$NEWLINE$If not to bless us and the land withal,$NEWLINE$Yet to draw forth your noble ancestry$NEWLINE$From the corruption of abusing times$NEWLINE$Unto a lineal, true-derivèd course.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$My lord, what you’ve said makes clear you have a conscience, but your objections are trivial, given the circumstances. You say that Prince Edward is your brother’s son. We agree, but not by your brother’s wife. King Edward was going to marry Lady Lucy—your mother can vouch for that—and then he was betrothed to Bona, the King of France’s sister-in-law. But both of these were put off by Elizabeth Grey, a careworn mother of many children who had once been a beauty but was now a stressed-out widow$NEWLINE$long past her prime. Nevertheless, under pretence of asking a favor of him, she attracted his lustful eye and seduced him so thoroughly that he completely debased himself, committing adultery with her. It resulted in this Edward, whom we’re polite enough to call “Prince.” Out of respect for the living, I’ll restrain myself from telling you everything. But, my good lord, if you don’t care about this country, at least use your own pure lineage to rescue us from the current corruption of the royal line.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$Do, good my lord. Your citizens entreat you.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$Yes, my good lord, your citizens beg you.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Refuse not, mighty lord, this proffered love.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Don’t refuse the love we offer you.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$O, make them joyful. Grant their lawful suit.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Oh, make them joyful! Grant their law-abiding request!

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Alas, why would you heap this care on me?$NEWLINE$I am unfit for state and majesty.$NEWLINE$I do beseech you, take it not amiss;$NEWLINE$I cannot, nor I will not, yield to you.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Alas, why would you heap all these responsibilities on me? I am unfit to rule and to be king. Please, don’t take it badly, but I cannot and will not give in to you.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$If you refuse it, as in love and zeal$NEWLINE$Loath to depose the child, your brother’s son—$NEWLINE$As well we know your tenderness of heart$NEWLINE$And gentle, kind, effeminate remorse,$NEWLINE$Which we have noted in you to your kindred$NEWLINE$And equally indeed to all estates—$NEWLINE$Yet know whe'er you accept our suit or no,$NEWLINE$Your brother’s son shall never reign our king,$NEWLINE$But we will plant some other in the throne,$NEWLINE$To the disgrace and downfall of your house.$NEWLINE$And in this resolution here we leave you.—$NEWLINE$Come, citizens. Zounds, I’ll entreat no more.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Perhaps you refuse our request out of love for your brother’s son. You don’t want to depose the child. We know how tender your heart is and what gentle, kind, womanly feelings you have for your relatives, as well as for people from all walks of life.$NEWLINE$But listen, if you won’t become king, we’ll just get someone else, to the disgrace and ruin of your family. We will not have your brother’s son as king. On this note, we’re leaving. Come, citizens. Damn it, I’m not going to beg anymore!$NEWLINE$you

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$O, do not swear, my lord of Buckingham!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh, please don’t swear, my lord of Buckingham.

paragraphs.original: Exit BUCKINGHAM and some others$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM exits with CITIZENS and LORD MAYOR.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$CITIZENS$NEWLINE$LORD MAYOR

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Call them again, sweet prince. Accept their suit.$NEWLINE$If you deny them, all the land will rue it.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Call them back, my lord, and accept their request. If you refuse it, the whole country will regret it.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Will you enforce me to a world of cares?$NEWLINE$Call them again. I am not made of stones,$NEWLINE$But penetrable to your kind entreaties,$NEWLINE$Albeit against my conscience and my soul.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Would you tie me to a whole world of worries? Well, call them back again. I am not made of stone; I am affected by all these kind pleas, though it goes against my conscience and my soul.

paragraphs.original: Enter BUCKINGHAM and the rest$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM and the rest return.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: Cousin of Buckingham and sage, grave men,$NEWLINE$Since you will buckle fortune on my back,$NEWLINE$To bear her burden, whe'er I will or no,$NEWLINE$I must have patience to endure the load;$NEWLINE$But if black scandal or foul-faced reproach$NEWLINE$Attend the sequel of your imposition,$NEWLINE$Your mere enforcement shall acquittance me$NEWLINE$From all the impure blots and stains thereof,$NEWLINE$For God doth know, and you may partly see,$NEWLINE$How far I am from the desire of this.
paragraphs.translated: Buckingham, my brother, and you wise, serious men, since you intend to force me to take responsibility for these changing times, whether I want to or not, I’m going to have to be brave and endure the load. But if this imposition you’ve put on me happens to result in dark scandal or ugly reproach, the fact that you forced me to accept this should clear me from blame. God knows, and you may have noticed, I’m not to eager to take on this job.

paragraphs.original: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$God bless your Grace! We see it and will say it.
paragraphs.translated: LORD MAYOR$NEWLINE$God bless your Grace! We understand you’re just doing it for us, and we’ll be sure to say so.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$In saying so, you shall but say the truth.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$If you say that, you’ll only be telling the truth.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Then I salute you with this royal title:$NEWLINE$Long live Richard, England’s worthy king!
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Then I salute you with this royal title: long live Richard, England’s worthy king!

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$Amen.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$Amen.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Tomorrow will it please you to be crowned?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Will you be crowned tomorrow?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Even when you please, since you will have it so.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Whenever you want, since you’re the one who wants it.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, then, we will attend your Grace,$NEWLINE$And so most joyfully we take our leave.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, then, we will wait on your Grace. Now we’ll take our leave—joyfully.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to the bishops) Come, let us to our holy task again.—$NEWLINE$(to the bishops)$NEWLINE$Farewell, my cousin. Farewell, gentle friends.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to the bishops) Come, let us get back to praying.—Farewell, my cousin; farewell, noble friends.$NEWLINE$(to the bishops)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS of York, and DORSET at one door; ANNE, duchess of Gloucester with CLARENCE’s young daughter at another door$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DUCHESS$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$ANNE$NEWLINE$CLARENCE
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH, DUCHESS of York, and DORSET enter on one side, and ANNE, the duchess of Gloucester, enters on the other, leading Clarence’s young daughter, Lady Margaret Plantagenet.$NEWLINE$QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$DUCHESS$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$ANNE

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Who meets us here? My niece Plantagenet$NEWLINE$Led in the hand of her kind aunt of Gloucester?$NEWLINE$Now, for my life, she’s wandering to the Tower,$NEWLINE$On pure heart’s love, to greet the tender prince.—$NEWLINE$Daughter, well met.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$Who’s this? My granddaughter, with her kind aunt, the duchess of Gloucester, leading her by the hand? Now, on my life, the young child must be headed to the Tower to greet the young princes, whom she adores. Daughter, how nice to see you.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$God give your Graces both$NEWLINE$A happy and a joyful time of day.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Good afternoon!

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$As much to you, good sister. Whither away?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The same to you, good sister. Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$No farther than the Tower, and, as I guess,$NEWLINE$Upon the like devotion as yourselves,$NEWLINE$To gratulate the gentle princes there.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Just to the Tower—I’m guessing, for the same reason you are: to salute the noble princes who are staying there.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Kind sister, thanks. We’ll enter all together.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Yes, kind sister. We can all go together.

paragraphs.original: Enter BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY enters.$NEWLINE$BRAKENBURY

paragraphs.original: And in good time here the lieutenant comes.—$NEWLINE$Master Lieutenant, pray you, by your leave,$NEWLINE$How doth the prince and my young son of York?
paragraphs.translated: And here comes the warden, just in time. Officer, please tell us, if you will, how are the prince and my little son, York?

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$Right well, dear madam. By your patience,$NEWLINE$I may not suffer you to visit them.$NEWLINE$The king hath strictly charged the contrary.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$They’re just fine, my dear madam. But I’m sorry—I’m not allowed to let you visit them. The king has strictly forbidden it.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The king? Who’s that?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The king? Who’s that?

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I mean, the Lord Protector.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$I meant to say the Lord Protector.

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The Lord protect him from that kingly title!$NEWLINE$Hath he set bounds between their love and me?$NEWLINE$I am their mother. Who shall bar me from them?
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$The Lord keep him from the title of king! Richard has set boundaries between my love and theirs? I am their mother. Who’s going to keep me from them?

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I am their father’s mother. I will see them.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$I am their father’s mother. I will see them.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Their aunt I am in law, in love their mother.$NEWLINE$Then bring me to their sights. I’ll bear thy blame$NEWLINE$And take thy office from thee, on my peril.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I am their aunt, and I love them like a mother. So take me to see them. Officer, I’ll take the responsibility from you, and the blame too.

paragraphs.original: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$No, madam, no. I may not leave it so.$NEWLINE$I am bound by oath, and therefore pardon me.
paragraphs.translated: BRAKENBURY$NEWLINE$No, madam, no. I can’t do this. I am bound by oath, so please forgive me.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter Lord STANLEY, earl of Derby$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: Lord STANLEY, earl of Derby, enters.$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Let me but meet you ladies one hour hence,$NEWLINE$And I’ll salute your Grace of York as mother$NEWLINE$And reverend looker-on, of two fair queens.$NEWLINE$(to ANNE)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Come, madam, you must straight to Westminster,$NEWLINE$There to be crownèd Richard’s royal queen.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$In just an hour from now, Duchess of York, I’ll be saluting you as the mother of two beautiful queens. (to ANNE) Come, madam, you must go straight to Westminster Abbey, where you will be crowned Richard’s queen.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Ah, cut my lace asunder,$NEWLINE$That my pent heart may have some scope to beat,$NEWLINE$Or else I swoon with this dead-killing news!
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Oh, cut my bodice-staps so that my pent-up heart can have some room to breathe, or I’ll faint from this deadly news!

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Despiteful tidings! O, unpleasing news!
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$Cruel, cruel news!

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Be of good cheer, mother. How fares$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH) Cheer up, mother. How are you feeling?$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$O Dorset, speak not to me. Get thee gone.$NEWLINE$Death and destruction dogs thee at thy heels.$NEWLINE$Thy mother’s name is ominous to children.$NEWLINE$If thou wilt outstrip death, go, cross the seas,$NEWLINE$And live with Richmond, from the reach of hell.$NEWLINE$Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughterhouse,$NEWLINE$Lest thou increase the number of the dead$NEWLINE$And make me die the thrall of Margaret’s curse,$NEWLINE$Nor mother, wife, nor England’s counted queen.
paragraphs.translated:
QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Oh, Dorset, don’t waste your time talking to me. Leave. Death and destruction are following at your heels. Your mother’s name has become a threat to her own children. If you want to outrun death, go cross the sea to France and stay with
Richmond, out of the reach of hell. Go, get out of here, get out of this slaughterhouse. Otherwise you’ll just increase the number of the dead, and make me die the slave of Margaret’s curse, no longer a mother, a wife, or England’s queen.$NEWLINE$Richmond$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.$NEWLINE$(to DORSET) Take all the swift advantage of the hours.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$You shall have letters from me to my son$NEWLINE$In your behalf, to meet you on the way.$NEWLINE$Be not ta'en tardy by unwise delay.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Madam, your advice is wise and caring.—Dorset, take advantage of the time you have. I’ll write to my stepson Richmond on your behalf, so that he’ll meet you on the way. But don’t delay.

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$O ill-dispersing wind of misery!$NEWLINE$O my accursèd womb, the bed of death!$NEWLINE$A cockatrice hast thou hatched to the world,$NEWLINE$Whose unavoided eye is murderous.
paragraphs.translated:
DUCHESS$NEWLINE$O, this evil wind that spreads nothing but misery. O, my cursed womb—it’s a deathbed, really, since Richard came out of it. It has hatched a
cockatrice, whose gaze kills whatever it lands on.$NEWLINE$cockatrice$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(to ANNE) Come, madam, come. I in all haste was sent.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(to ANNE) Come, madam, come. I was sent in a hurry.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$And I in all unwillingness will go.$NEWLINE$O, would to God that the inclusive verge$NEWLINE$Of golden metal that must round my brow$NEWLINE$Were red-hot steel to sear me to the brains!$NEWLINE$Anointed let me be with deadly venom,$NEWLINE$And die ere men can say, “God save the Queen.”
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$I go unwillingly. I wish to God that the golden crown that I’ll have to wear were red-hot steel and burned me straight through to the brain! I wish I could be anointed queen with deadly venom, not oil, and that I would die before anyone even had a chance to say, “God save the Queen!”

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory.$NEWLINE$To feed my humor, wish thyself no harm.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Go, go, poor soul. I don’t envy your position. If you want to make me happy, don’t wish yourself harm.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$No? Why? When he that is my husband now$NEWLINE$Came to me, as I followed Henry’s corse,$NEWLINE$When scarce the blood was well washed from his hands$NEWLINE$Which issued from my other angel husband$NEWLINE$And that dear saint which then I weeping followed—$NEWLINE$O, when, I say, I looked on Richard’s face,$NEWLINE$This was my wish: be thou, quoth I, accursed$NEWLINE$For making me, so young, so old a widow;$NEWLINE$And, when thou wedd’st, let sorrow haunt thy bed;$NEWLINE$And be thy wife, if any be so mad,$NEWLINE$More miserable by the life of thee$NEWLINE$Than thou hast made me by my dear lord’s death.$NEWLINE$Lo, ere I can repeat this curse again,$NEWLINE$Within so small a time my woman’s heart$NEWLINE$Grossly grew captive to his honey words$NEWLINE$And proved the subject of mine own soul’s curse,$NEWLINE$Which hitherto hath held my eyes from rest,$NEWLINE$For never yet one hour in his bed$NEWLINE$Did I enjoyed the golden dew of sleep,$NEWLINE$But with his timorous dreams was still awaked.$NEWLINE$Besides, he hates me for my father Warwick,$NEWLINE$And will, no doubt, shortly be rid of me.
paragraphs.translated:
ANNE$NEWLINE$No? Why? The man I’m married to now came to me when he’d barely washed the blood off his hands from killing my first husband, that angel, as well as my husband’s sainted father, whose corpse I was following to burial. I’m telling you, when I looked at Richard’s face, this is what I wished: “I want you to be cursed for making me a widow so young. And when you get married, let sorrow haunt your bed. And I hope your wife—if any woman is crazy enough to marry you—is more miserable about the fact that you’re alive as you have made me by killing my husband!” And then what? Before I even had time to repeat the curse, my woman’s heart was taken captive by his sweet, slick words. I became the victim of my own curse. Since I married him, I have not had one hour’s sleep in his bed. Every night I’m awakened by his
terrified dreams. It doesn’t matter if I sleep, though. He hates me because of who my father is. He will, no doubt, get rid of me soon.$NEWLINE$terrified$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Poor heart, adieu. I pity thy complaining.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Poor dear, goodbye. I pity your situation.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$No more than from my soul I mourn for yours.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$No more than I do yours.

paragraphs.original: DORSET$NEWLINE$Farewell, thou woeful welcomer of glory.
paragraphs.translated: DORSET$NEWLINE$Goodbye. I know you’re unhappy with the glory of becoming queen.

paragraphs.original: ANNE$NEWLINE$Adieu, poor soul that tak’st thy leave of it.
paragraphs.translated: ANNE$NEWLINE$(to ELIZABETH) And goodbye to you, the poor soul who has to leave that glory behind.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$(to DORSET)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Go thou to Richmond, and good fortune guide thee.$NEWLINE$(to ANNE) Go thou to Richard, and good angels tend thee.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to QUEEN ELIZABETH)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Go thou to sanctuary, and good thoughts possess thee.$NEWLINE$I to my grave, where peace and rest lie with me.$NEWLINE$Eighty-odd years of sorrow have I seen,$NEWLINE$And each hour’s joy wracked with a week of teen.
paragraphs.translated: DUCHESS$NEWLINE$(to DORSET) Go to Richmond, and good luck. (to ANNE) You go to Richard. I hope good angels will protect you. (to QUEEN ELIZABETH) You take sanctuary in the Abbey and think good thoughts for us. I will go to my grave, where I can look forward to peace and rest. I have witnessed eighty-odd years of sorrow; for each hour of joy I’ve experienced, I’ve suffered a full week of misery.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Stay, yet look back with me unto the Tower.—$NEWLINE$Pity, you ancient stones, those tender babes$NEWLINE$Whom envy hath immured within your walls—$NEWLINE$Rough cradle for such little pretty ones.$NEWLINE$Rude ragged nurse, old sullen playfellow$NEWLINE$For tender princes, use my babies well.$NEWLINE$So foolish sorrows bids your stones farewell.
paragraphs.translated: QUEEN ELIZABETH$NEWLINE$Wait. Look back at the Tower with me. Please, you ancient building, take pity on those tender babes locked inside your walls by envious rivals! You are such a rough cradle for such little pretty ones. You are a rude, ragged nurse and an old, sullen playmate for such tender princes. Please treat my babies well. I know I must look foolish saying goodbye to a building, but I’m aching with sorrow.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Sound a sennet. Enter RICHARD in pomp; BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, RATCLIFFE, LOVELL, a page, and others$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$CATESBY$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$LOVELL
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. RICHARD enters, already crowned and dressed as a king. BUCKINGHAM, CATESBY, a PAGE, and others enter with him.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$CATESBY$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Stand all apart. —Cousin of Buckingham.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Everyone stand aside.—Cousin Buckingham.

paragraphs.original: Others move aside
paragraphs.translated: Everyone moves aside.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$My gracious sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$My gracious king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Give me thy hand.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Give me your hand.

paragraphs.original: Here he ascendeth the throne. Sound trumpets
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD ascends the throne with BUCKINGHAM at his side.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: Thus high, by thy advice$NEWLINE$And thy assistance is King Richard seated.$NEWLINE$But shall we wear these glories for a day,$NEWLINE$Or shall they last and we rejoice in them?
paragraphs.translated: Because of your advice and your help, I have a high position now. But will I wear these honors for only a day or will I enjoy them for a long time?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Still live they, and forever let them last.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Let them last forever.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ah, Buckingham, now do I play the touch,$NEWLINE$To try if thou be current gold indeed.$NEWLINE$Young Edward lives; think now what I would speak.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh Buckingham, now I’m going to test to see if you’re truly made of gold. Young Prince Edward is still alive—what do you think I’m going to say next?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Say on, my loving lord.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Go on, my loving lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, Buckingham, I say I would be king,
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, Buckingham, I say I want to be king.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Why so you are, my thrice-renownèd lord.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Why, you are king, your highness.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ha! Am I king? 'Tis so—but Edward lives.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Ha! Am I king? I guess I am. But Edward is still alive.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$True, noble prince.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$True, noble prince.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$O bitter consequence$NEWLINE$That Edward still should live “true noble prince”!$NEWLINE$Cousin, thou wast not wont to be so dull.$NEWLINE$Shall I be plain? I wish the bastards dead,$NEWLINE$And I would have it suddenly performed.$NEWLINE$What sayest thou now? Speak suddenly. Be brief.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh, how bitter it is that Edward—the real “true, noble prince”—should still be alive! Cousin, you didn’t used to be so thickheaded. Shall I put it plainly? I want the bastards dead. And I want it done right away. What do you say? Speak now and to the point.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Your Grace may do your pleasure.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Your Grace can do whatever he wants.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Tut, tut, thou art all ice; thy kindness freezes.$NEWLINE$Say, have I thy consent that they shall die?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Tut, tut, you’ve become rather icy. Your friendliness toward me seems to be freezing over. Tell me, do I have your consent to kill them?

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Give me some little breath, some pause, dear lord,$NEWLINE$Before I positively speak in this.$NEWLINE$I will resolve you herein presently.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Give me a little breathing space, my lord, a little pause to think. I’ll let you know my answer shortly.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$(aside to the other attendants)$NEWLINE$(aside to the other attendants)$NEWLINE$The king is angry. See, he gnaws his lip.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$(so only the attendant nearest him can hear) The king is angry. See, he bites his lip.$NEWLINE$(so only the attendant nearest him can hear)

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(aside) I will converse with iron-witted fools$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$And unrespective boys. None are for me$NEWLINE$That look into me with considerate eyes.$NEWLINE$High-reaching Buckingham grows circumspect.—$NEWLINE$Boy!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(to himself) I only want to deal with stupid fools and careless boys. I have no use for people who look at me insightfully. Ambitious Buckingham grows much too circumspect. Boy!$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$(coming forward) My lord?$NEWLINE$(coming forward)
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Know’st thou not any whom corrupting gold$NEWLINE$Will tempt unto a close exploit of death?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Do you know anyone who would kill someone for money?

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$I know a discontented gentleman$NEWLINE$Whose humble means match not his haughty spirit.$NEWLINE$Gold were as good as twenty orators,$NEWLINE$And will, no doubt, tempt him to anything.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$My lord, I know one unhappy gentleman who has more pride than money. Money talks, and would very likely get him to do anything.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What is his name?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What’s his name?

paragraphs.original: PAGE$NEWLINE$His name, my lord, is Tyrrel.
paragraphs.translated: PAGE$NEWLINE$His name is Tyrrel, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I partly know the man. Go, call him hither, boy
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I know the man a bit. Go, bring him here, boy.

paragraphs.original: Exit PAGE$NEWLINE$PAGE
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE exits.$NEWLINE$PAGE

paragraphs.original: (aside) The deep-revolving witty Buckingham$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$No more shall be the neighbor to my counsels$NEWLINE$Hath he so long held out with me, untired,$NEWLINE$And stops he now for breath? Well, be it so.
paragraphs.translated: (to himself) The thoughtful, witty Buckingham will no longer be privy to my innermost thoughts. Has he held out for me for so long and without a moment’s doubt only to suddenly need some “breathing room”? Well, so be it.$NEWLINE$(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter STANLEY$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY enters.$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: How now, Lord Stanley, what’s the news?
paragraphs.translated: Look who’s here! What’s the news with you?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Know, my long lord,$NEWLINE$The marquess Dorset, as I hear, is fled$NEWLINE$To Richmond, in the parts where he abides.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$You should know, my loving lord, I’ve heard that the marquess Dorset has fled to Brittany, to the earl of Richmond.

paragraphs.original: He walks aside
paragraphs.translated: He stands aside.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Come hither, Catesby. Rumor it abroad$NEWLINE$That Anne my wife is very grievous sick.$NEWLINE$I will take order for her keeping close.$NEWLINE$Inquire me out some mean poor gentleman,$NEWLINE$Whom I will marry straight to Clarence' daughter.$NEWLINE$The boy is foolish, and I fear not him.$NEWLINE$Look how thou dream’st! I say again, give out$NEWLINE$That Anne my queen is sick and like to die.$NEWLINE$About it, for it stands me much upon$NEWLINE$To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Come here, Catesby. Spread the rumor abroad that Anne, my wife, is very sick. I will make sure she’s kept out of view. And find a poverty stricken gentleman who I can marry straightaway to Clarence’s daughter. Clarence’s son is dull-witted, so I’m not worried about him. Look at you, standing there in a stupor! I repeat, spread the rumor that Anne, my wife, is sick and likely to die. Hurry up because it’s absolutely crucial that I destroy anything that may damage my position.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exit CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: (aside) I must be married to my brother’s daughter,$NEWLINE$(aside)$NEWLINE$Or else my kingdom stands on brittle glass.$NEWLINE$Murder her brothers, and then marry her—$NEWLINE$Uncertain way of gain. But I am in$NEWLINE$So far in blood that sin will pluck on sin.$NEWLINE$Tear-falling pity dwells not in this eye.
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I must get married to my brother’s
daughter. Otherwise, my kingdom stands on glass. Murdering her brothers and then marrying her isn’t the most foolproof way to secure my position. But I’m steeped so deep in blood by now that one sin has to follow the next. I have no tears of pity for anyone.$NEWLINE$(to himself)$NEWLINE$daughter$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter PAGE with TYRREL$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$TYRREL
paragraphs.translated: The PAGE returns with TYRREL.$NEWLINE$PAGE$NEWLINE$TYRREL

paragraphs.original: Is thy name Tyrrel?
paragraphs.translated: Are you Tyrrel?

paragraphs.original: TYRREL$NEWLINE$James Tyrrel, and your most obedient subject.
paragraphs.translated: TYRREL$NEWLINE$James Tyrrel—and your most obedient subject.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Art thou indeed?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Are you indeed?

paragraphs.original: TYRREL$NEWLINE$Prove me, my gracious sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: TYRREL$NEWLINE$Test me, my blessed king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Dar’st thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
