paragraphs.original: SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$In Kent, my liege, the Guilfords are in arms,$NEWLINE$And every hour more competitors$NEWLINE$Flock to the rebels, and their power grows strong.
paragraphs.translated:
SECOND MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My king, the Guildfords in
Kent have armed themselves, and every hour new associates flock to their aid, and their army increases.$NEWLINE$Kent$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A THIRD MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$THIRD MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, the army of great Buckingham—
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, the duke of Buckingham’s army—

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Out on you, owls! Nothing but songs of death.$NEWLINE$He striketh him$NEWLINE$He striketh him$NEWLINE$There, take thou that till thou bring better news.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHARD$NEWLINE$Enough, you
owls! Do you have nothing but songs of death? (he strikes the THIRD MESSENGER) Take that until you bring me better news.$NEWLINE$owls$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$(he strikes the$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The news I have to tell your Majesty$NEWLINE$Is that by sudden floods and fall of waters$NEWLINE$Buckingham’s army is dispersed and scattered,$NEWLINE$And he himself wandered away alone,$NEWLINE$No man knows whither.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$The news I have to tell your majesty is that Buckingham’s army has dispersed from sudden floods and heavy rainfall. Buckingham himself has wandered away alone to who knows where.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I cry thee mercy.$NEWLINE$There is my purse to cure that blow of thine.$NEWLINE$He gives money$NEWLINE$He gives money$NEWLINE$Hath any well-advisèd friend proclaimed$NEWLINE$Reward to him that brings the traitor in?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I beg your pardon. Here’s some money to make up for that blow I gave you. (he gives money) Has any intelligent friend of ours offered a reward to whoever catches the traitor?$NEWLINE$(he gives money)

paragraphs.original: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Such proclamation hath been made, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: THIRD MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Yes, your Highness.

paragraphs.original: Enter FOURTH MESSENGER$NEWLINE$FOURTH MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A FOURTH MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$FOURTH MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: FOURTH MESSENGER$NEWLINE$Sir Thomas Lovell and Lord Marquess Dorset,$NEWLINE$'Tis said, my liege, in Yorkshire are in arms.$NEWLINE$But this good comfort bring I to your Highness:$NEWLINE$The Breton navy is dispersed by tempest.$NEWLINE$Richmond, in Dorsetshire, sent out a boat$NEWLINE$Unto the shore to ask those on the banks$NEWLINE$If they were his assistants, yea or no—$NEWLINE$Who answered him they came from Buckingham$NEWLINE$Upon his party. He, mistrusting them,$NEWLINE$Hoisted sail and made his course for Brittany.
paragraphs.translated:
FOURTH MESSENGER$NEWLINE$It’s been reported that Sir Thomas Lovell and Lord Marquess Dorset have assembled an army in
Yorkshire, my lord. But I bring your Grace this comfort: a storm has dispersed the navy from Brittany. And Richmond, who is in
Dorsetshire, sent a boat to shore to ask the men on the banks if they were on his side, yes or no. They said they were with Buckingham. Richmond didn’t trust them. He hoisted sail again and sailed back to Brittany.$NEWLINE$Yorkshire$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$Dorsetshir$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$March on, march on, since we are up in arms,$NEWLINE$If not to fight with foreign enemies,$NEWLINE$Yet to beat down these rebels here at home.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Let’s keep marching since we’re prepared to fight. Even if we don’t fight foreign enemies, we’ll beat down these rebels at home.

paragraphs.original: Enter CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY returns.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My liege, the duke of Buckingham is taken.$NEWLINE$That is the best news. That the earl of Richmond$NEWLINE$Is with a mighty power landed at Milford,$NEWLINE$Is colder tidings, yet they must be told.
paragraphs.translated:
CATESBY$NEWLINE$Your Majesty, the duke of Buckingham has been captured—that’s the best news. The fact that the earl of Richmond has landed in
Milford with a mighty army is less good news, but it must be told.$NEWLINE$Milford$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Away towards Salisbury! While we reason here,$NEWLINE$A royal battle might be won and lost.$NEWLINE$Someone take order Buckingham be brought$NEWLINE$To Salisbury. The rest march on with me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Away toward Salisbury! While we’re talking here, a royal battle could be won and lost. Someone deliver the order that Buckingham be brought to Salisbury. Everyone else, march on with me.
A trumpet plays.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter STANLEY and Sir CHRISTOPHER.$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$CHRISTOPHER
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY and Sir CHRISTOPHER enter.$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$CHRISTOPHER

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Sir Christopher, tell Richmond this from me:$NEWLINE$That in the sty of the most deadly boar$NEWLINE$My son George Stanley is franked up in hold;$NEWLINE$If I revolt, off goes young George’s head;$NEWLINE$The fear of that holds off my present aid.$NEWLINE$So get three gone. Commend me to thy lord.$NEWLINE$Withal, say that the queen hath heartily consented$NEWLINE$He should espouse Elizabeth her daughter.$NEWLINE$But, tell me, where is princely Richmond now?
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Sir Christopher, relay this message to Richmond: My son George Stanley is penned up in the bloody boar’s sty. If I revolt, off goes young George’s head. My fear of that prevents me from helping Richmond at this time. But, tell me, where is the noble Richmond now?

paragraphs.original: CHRISTOPHER$NEWLINE$At Pembroke, or at Ha'rfordwest in Wales.
paragraphs.translated: CHRISTOPHER$NEWLINE$At Pembroke, or at Harfordwest in Wales.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$What men of name resort to him?
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Which noblemen have joined him?

paragraphs.original: CHRISTOPHER$NEWLINE$Sir Walter Herbert, a renownèd soldier;$NEWLINE$Sir Gilbert Talbot, Sir William Stanley,$NEWLINE$Oxford, redoubted Pembroke, Sir James Blunt,$NEWLINE$And Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew,$NEWLINE$And many other of great name and worth;$NEWLINE$And towards London they do bend their power,$NEWLINE$If by the way they be not fought withal.
paragraphs.translated: CHRISTOPHER$NEWLINE$Sir Walter Herbert, a renowned soldier; Sir Gilbert Talbot; Sir William Stanley; Oxford; the highly feared Pembroke; Sir James Blunt; Rice ap Thomas, with a valiant crew; and many other famous and powerful noblemen. They plan to head straight to London, assuming they don’t encounter any resistance on the way.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(gives him a paper) Well, hie thee to thy lord.$NEWLINE$(gives him a paper)$NEWLINE$I kiss his hand. My letter will resolve him of my mind.$NEWLINE$Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(giving him a paper) Return to your lord. Give him my best regards. Tell him the queen has given her heartfelt consent to his marriage to her daughter, Elizabeth. And these letters will let him know what my thinking is. Goodbye, and take care.$NEWLINE$(giving him a paper)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter BUCKINGHAM with SHERIFF and halberds, led to execution$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$SHERIFF
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM enters with SHERIFF and guards leading him to his execution.$NEWLINE$BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$SHERIFF

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Will not King Richard let me speak with him?
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Won’t King Richard let me speak with him?

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$No, my good lord. Therefore be patient.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$No, my good lord. So be calm.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Hastings and Edward’s children, Grey and Rivers,$NEWLINE$Holy King Henry and thy fair son Edward,$NEWLINE$Vaughan, and all that have miscarrièd$NEWLINE$By underhand, corrupted, foul injustice,$NEWLINE$If that your moody, discontented souls$NEWLINE$Do through the clouds behold this present hour,$NEWLINE$Even for revenge mock my destruction.—$NEWLINE$This is All Souls' Day, fellow, is it not?
paragraphs.translated:
BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Hastings and Edward’s children, Rivers and Grey, holy King Henry and your fine son Edward, Vaughan, and all who have died from underhanded, corrupt, fiendish injustice, if your angry souls are witnessing this moment through the clouds, enjoy the revenge—laugh at my ruin! This is
All-Souls’ day, fellows, isn’t it?$NEWLINE$All-Souls’$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$It is.
paragraphs.translated: SHERIFF$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Why, then All Souls' Day is my body’s doomsday.$NEWLINE$This is the day which, in King Edward’s time,$NEWLINE$I wished might fall on me when I was found$NEWLINE$False to his children and his wife’s allies.$NEWLINE$This is the day wherein I wished to fall$NEWLINE$By the false faith of him who most I trusted.$NEWLINE$This, this All Souls' Day to my fearful soul$NEWLINE$Is the determined respite of my wrongs.$NEWLINE$That high All-seer which I dallied with$NEWLINE$Hath turned my feignèd prayer on my head$NEWLINE$And given in earnest what I begged in jest.
paragraphs.translated: BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$Why, then, it’s my body’s doomsday. Today I’m going to get what I said I wished would happen to me if I was ever false to King Edward’s children or his wife’s allies. This is the day I’m going to get what I wished for when I wished that the person I most trusted would betray me. This, this All-Souls' day, is my just desserts. I tried to play games with God, and he turned my fake prayer on my head, giving me for real what I’d asked for as a joke.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men$NEWLINE$To turn their own points in their masters' bosoms.$NEWLINE$Thus Margaret’s curse falls heavy upon my neck:$NEWLINE$“When he,” quoth she, “shall split thy heart with sorrow,$NEWLINE$Remember Margaret was a prophetess.”—$NEWLINE$Come, lead me, officers, to the block of shame.$NEWLINE$Wrong hath but wrong, and blame the due of blame.
paragraphs.translated: This is how God forces wicked men to turn their swords against themselves. Margaret’s curse has come true. “When Richard has split your heart in two with grief,” she said, “you’ll know that Margaret was a prophetess.” Come, sirs, bring me to this block of shame. I have done wrong, so I will suffer wrong. I have been blamed because I deserved to be.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHMOND, OXFORD, BLUNT, HERBERT, and others, with drum and colors$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$OXFORD$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$HERBERT
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND, OXFORD, BLUNT, HERBERT, and others enter with drummers and flag bearers.$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$OXFORD$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$HERBERT

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends,$NEWLINE$Bruised underneath the yoke of tyranny,$NEWLINE$Have we marched on without impediment,$NEWLINE$Thus far into the bowels of the land$NEWLINE$And here receive we from our father Stanley$NEWLINE$Lines of fair comfort and encouragement.$NEWLINE$The wretched, bloody, and usurping boar,$NEWLINE$That spoiled your summer fields and fruitful vines,$NEWLINE$Swills your warm blood like wash, and makes his trough$NEWLINE$In your embowelled bosoms—this foul swine$NEWLINE$Is now even in the center of this isle,$NEWLINE$Near to the town of Leicester, as we learn.$NEWLINE$From Tamworth thither is but one day’s march.$NEWLINE$In God’s name, cheerly on, courageous friends,$NEWLINE$To reap the harvest of perpetual peace$NEWLINE$By this one bloody trial of sharp war.
paragraphs.translated:
RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Fellow soldiers and my loyal friends suffering under that tyrant Richard, we have marched all the way to the center of England without encountering any opposition. And now we receive encouraging news from my stepfather Stanley: Richard—that violent, greedy boar who roots through your summer fields and ripening vines, guzzles your warm blood, and makes his trough in your disemboweled bellies—is now near the town of Leicester, only one day’s march from us here in
Tamworth. In God’s name, let’s continue on in high spirits, my courageous friends. Our aim is to achieve everlasting peace from this one violent war.$NEWLINE$Tamworth$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: OXFORD$NEWLINE$Every man’s conscience is a thousand men,$NEWLINE$To fight against this guilty homicide.
paragraphs.translated: OXFORD$NEWLINE$Every man’s conscience is a thousand swords against this murderer.

paragraphs.original: HERBERT$NEWLINE$I doubt not but his friends will turn to us.
paragraphs.translated: HERBERT$NEWLINE$I suspect his friends will join us.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$He hath no friends but who are friends for fear.$NEWLINE$Which in his dearest need will fly from him.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$He has no friends except those who are too afraid to defy him. In his greatest need, even they will desert him.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$All for our vantage. Then, in God’s name, march.$NEWLINE$True hope is swift, and flies with swallow’s wings.$NEWLINE$Kings it makes gods, and meaner creatures kings.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$All to our advantage. So, in God’s name, let’s march. Hope with good cause is swift; it flies as fast as a swallow. It turns kings into gods and men of lower rank into kings.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHARD, in arms, with NORFOLK, RATCLIFFE, SURREY, and soldiers$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$SURREY
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, dressed in his armor, enters with NORFOLK, SURREY, and others.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$SURREY

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Here pitch our tent, even here in Bosworth field.—$NEWLINE$My Lord of Surrey, why look you so sad?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Let’s pitch our tents right here in Bosworth Field. My Lord of Surrey, why do you look so sad?

paragraphs.original: SURREY$NEWLINE$My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.
paragraphs.translated: SURREY$NEWLINE$My heart is ten times lighter than my looks.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My Lord of Norfolk—
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My Lord of Norfolk—

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Here, most gracious liege.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Here, most gracious king.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Norfolk, we must have knocks, ha, must we not?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Norfolk, we’re going to have a few blows, right?

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$We must both give and take, my loving lord.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$We’ve got to give them and take them, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Up with my tent!—Here will I lie tonight.$NEWLINE$But where tomorrow? Well, all’s one for that.$NEWLINE$Who hath descried the number of the traitors?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Put my tent up! I’ll lie here tonight. But where will I lie tomorrow? Well, it doesn’t matter. Does anyone know the number of the enemy’s troops?

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Six or seven thousand is their utmost power.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Six or seven thousand, at most.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, our battalia trebles that account.$NEWLINE$Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength$NEWLINE$Which they upon the adverse party want.$NEWLINE$Up with the tent!—Come, noble gentlemen,$NEWLINE$Let us survey the vantage of the ground.$NEWLINE$Call for some men of sound direction.$NEWLINE$Let’s lack no discipline, make no delay,$NEWLINE$For, lords, tomorrow is a busy day.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Why, our troops amount to three times that. Besides, the king’s name is a tower of strength; the opposition doesn’t have that advantage. Put up my tent! Come, noble gentlemen, let us look at our battle plan and get some experienced officers to help us figure out the best strategy. Let’s be disciplined and not delay, because tomorrow is a busy day.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter RICHMOND, Sir William Brandon, OXFORD, DORSET, HERBERT, BLUNT, and others. Some of the soldiers pitch RICHMOND’s tent$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$OXFORD$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$HERBERT$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$RICHMOND
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND, Sir William Brandon, OXFORD, DORSET, HERBERT, BLUNT, and others enter on the other side of the stage. Some soldiers pitch RICHMOND’s tent.$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$OXFORD$NEWLINE$DORSET$NEWLINE$HERBERT$NEWLINE$BLUNT$NEWLINE$RICHMOND

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$The weary sun hath made a golden set,$NEWLINE$And by the bright track of his fiery car,$NEWLINE$Gives token of a goodly day tomorrow.—$NEWLINE$Sir William Brandon, you shall bear my standard.—$NEWLINE$Give me some ink and paper in my tent;$NEWLINE$I’ll draw the form and model of our battle,$NEWLINE$Limit each leader to his several charge,$NEWLINE$And part in just proportion our small power.$NEWLINE$My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon,$NEWLINE$And you, Sir Walter Herbert, stay with me.$NEWLINE$The earl of Pembroke keeps his regiment—$NEWLINE$Good Captain Blunt, bear my goodnight to him,$NEWLINE$And by the second hour in the morning$NEWLINE$Desire the earl to see me in my tent.$NEWLINE$Yet one thing more, good captain, do for me.$NEWLINE$Where is Lord Stanley quartered, do you know?
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$The sunset was golden and left a bright track in the sky, which indicates that tomorrow will be a good day. Sir William Brandon, you will carry my flag. Bring some ink and paper to my tent, and I’ll draw a model of our battle, appoint each leader to his particular command, and carefully divide up our small army. My Lord of Oxford, you, Sir William Brandon, and you, Sir Walter Herbert, are going to stay with me. The earl of Pembroke will stick with his regiment. Good Captain Blunt, tell the earl goodnight from me, and tell him that by two in the morning I would like him to visit my tent. One more thing before you go, Blunt—where is Lord Stanley lodging, do you know?

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Unless I have mista'en his colors much,$NEWLINE$Which well I am assured I have not done,$NEWLINE$His regiment lies half a mile, at least,$NEWLINE$South from the mighty power of the king.
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Unless I’ve mistaken his battle flags, which I’m sure I haven’t, his regiment lies at least half a mile south of the king’s mighty army.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$If without peril it be possible,$NEWLINE$Sweet Blunt, make some good means to speak with him,$NEWLINE$And give him from me this most needful note.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$If it’s possible to do this without putting yourself in danger, dear Captain Blunt, say goodnight to him from me and give him this important note.

paragraphs.original: He hands him a paper
paragraphs.translated: He hands him a paper

paragraphs.original: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Upon my life, my lord, I’ll undertake it.$NEWLINE$And so God give you quiet rest tonight!
paragraphs.translated: BLUNT$NEWLINE$Upon my life, my lord, I’ll do it. Have a restful night!

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Good night, good Captain Blunt.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Good night, dear Captain Blunt.

paragraphs.original: BLUNT exits$NEWLINE$BLUNT
paragraphs.translated: Blunt exits.

paragraphs.original: Come, gentlemen,$NEWLINE$Let us consult upon tomorrow’s business$NEWLINE$Into my tent. The dew is raw and cold.
paragraphs.translated: Come, gentlemen, let’s discuss tomorrow’s action in my tent. The night air is too raw and cold for us to stay outdoors.

paragraphs.original: Enter, to his tent, RICHARD, NORFOLK, RATCLIFFE, CATESBY, and others$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, NORFOLK, RATCLIFFE, CATESBY, and others enter in RICHARD’s tent.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$CATESBY$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What is “t o”clock?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What time is it?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$It’s suppertime, my lord. It’s nine o'clock.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$It’s dinnertime, my lord. It’s nine o'clock.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I will not sup tonight. Give me some ink and paper.$NEWLINE$What, is my beaver easier than it was?$NEWLINE$And all my armor laid into my tent?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$I’m not going to eat dinner tonight. Give me some ink and paper. Is the visor of my helmet working better now? And has my armor been put in my tent?

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$It is, my liege, and all things are in readiness.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord. Everything’s ready.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good Norfolk, hie thee to thy charge.$NEWLINE$Use careful watch. Choose trusty sentinels.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$My good man Norfolk, hurry to your post. Be careful whom you choose as guards—make sure they’re trustworthy.

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$I go, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$I’m off, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Stir with the lark tomorrow, gentle Norfolk.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Get up early tomorrow—at the sound of the lark—noble Norfolk.

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$I warrant you, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$I will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Catesby.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Catesby.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Send out a pursuivant-at-arms$NEWLINE$To Stanley’s regiment. Bid him bring his power$NEWLINE$Before sunrising, lest his son George fall$NEWLINE$Into the blind cave of eternal night.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Send a junior officer to Stanley’s regiment to tell Stanley to bring his men here before sunrise—if he wants to see his son George alive.

paragraphs.original: Exit CATESBY$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY exits.$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: (to soldiers) Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.$NEWLINE$(to soldiers)$NEWLINE$Saddle white Surrey for the field to-morrow.$NEWLINE$Look that my staves be sound, and not too heavy.—$NEWLINE$Ratcliffe.
paragraphs.translated: (to soldiers) Get me some wine. Get a soldier to stand watch outside my tent. Saddle my white horse Surrey for battle tomorrow. Make sure the shafts of my lances are solid, but not too heavy. Ratcliffe!$NEWLINE$(to soldiers)

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Yes, my lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Sawst thou the melancholy Lord Northumberland?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Did you see the gloomy Lord Northumberland?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Thomas the earl of Surrey and himself,$NEWLINE$Much about cockshut time, from troop to troop$NEWLINE$Went through the army cheering up the soldiers.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Thomas, the earl of Surrey, and he were moving from troop to troop around twilight cheering up the soldiers.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$So, I am satisfied. Give me a bowl of wine.$NEWLINE$I have not that alacrity of spirit$NEWLINE$Nor cheer of mind that I was wont to have.$NEWLINE$Set it down. Is ink and paper ready?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Good, I’m satisfied. Give me some wine—I don’t feel as energetic as I used to. Set it down. Is my ink and paper ready?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$It is, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Bid my guard watch. Leave me.$NEWLINE$Ratcliffe, about the mid of night come to my tent$NEWLINE$And help to arm me. Leave me, I say.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Make sure my guard is on duty and leave me alone. Ratcliffe, around midnight come to my tent and help me put on my armor. Now leave me alone, as I said.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt Ratcliffe and the other attendants. RICHARD sleeps.$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE and the other attendants exit. RICHARD sleeps.$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter STANLEY to RICHMOND in his tent, lords and others attending$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$RICHMOND
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY enters and goes to RICHMOND’s tent, where lords and others are waiting on him.$NEWLINE$STANLEY$NEWLINE$RICHMOND

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Let fortune and victory be yours!

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$All comfort that the dark night can afford$NEWLINE$Be to thy person, noble father-in-law.$NEWLINE$Tell me, how fares our loving mother?
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$I wish you all the comfort that such a dark night as this can offer, noble father-in-law. Tell me, how is my mother?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$I, by attorney, bless thee from thy mother,$NEWLINE$Who prays continually for Richmond’s good.$NEWLINE$So much for that. The silent hours steal on,$NEWLINE$And flaky darkness breaks within the east.$NEWLINE$In brief, for so the season bids us be,$NEWLINE$Prepare thy battle early in the morning,$NEWLINE$And put thy fortune to the arbitrament$NEWLINE$Of bloody strokes and mortal-staring war.$NEWLINE$I, as I may—that which I would I cannot,—$NEWLINE$With best advantage will deceive the time,$NEWLINE$And aid thee in this doubtful shock of arms.$NEWLINE$But on thy side I may not be too forward,$NEWLINE$Lest, being seen, thy brother, tender George,$NEWLINE$Be executed in his father’s sight.$NEWLINE$Farewell. The leisure and the fearful time$NEWLINE$Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love$NEWLINE$And ample interchange of sweet discourse,$NEWLINE$Which so-long-sundered friends should dwell upon.$NEWLINE$God give us leisure for these rites of love!$NEWLINE$Once more, adieu. Be valiant, and speed well.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$Your mother sends her blessings. She prays continually on your behalf. Enough about that—morning will be here soon. To be brief—as the occasion requires—prepare to fight early in the morning, when your future will be decided. I can’t do everything I want to, but I’ll help you as well as I can. But I can’t be too obvious about being on your side without risking the life of your stepbrother, young George. If I’m seen helping you, George will be killed right in front of my eyes. Farewell. The lack of time and the risk I’m under will have to keep us from bonding and catching up on each other’s news the way we usually would after not seeing each other for so long. I hope we have the time some day! Again, goodbye. Be brave and do well!

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Good lords, conduct him to his regiment:$NEWLINE$I’ll strive with troubled thoughts to take a nap,$NEWLINE$Lest leaden slumber peise me down tomorrow,$NEWLINE$When I should mount with wings of victory.$NEWLINE$Once more, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Good lords, escort him to his regiment. I’m going to try to take a nap despite my racing thoughts so that exhaustion won’t get the better of me tomorrow, when I’ll need to ride as if my horse had wings.$NEWLINE$Again, good night, kind lords and gentlemen.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but RICHMOND$NEWLINE$RICHMOND
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except RICHMOND.$NEWLINE$RICHMOND

paragraphs.original: O Thou, whose captain I account myself,$NEWLINE$Look on my forces with a gracious eye.$NEWLINE$Put in their hands thy bruising irons of wrath,$NEWLINE$That they may crush down with a heavy fall$NEWLINE$The usurping helmets of our adversaries!$NEWLINE$Make us thy ministers of chastisement,$NEWLINE$That we may praise thee in the victory!$NEWLINE$To thee I do commend my watchful soul,$NEWLINE$Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes.$NEWLINE$Sleeping and waking, O, defend me still!$NEWLINE$Sleeps$NEWLINE$Sleeps
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, whose side I think I’m fighting on, look kindly on my forces. Fuel them with dangerous fury, so they can crush the enemy. Make us your agents of revenge, so we can praise you when we’re victorious! Before I fall asleep, I entrust my soul to you. Defend me, God, both when I’m asleep and when I’m awake.$NEWLINE$He sleeps.$NEWLINE$He sleeps

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD, son to KING HENRY VI$NEWLINE$GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD$NEWLINE$KING HENRY VI
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD, King Henry VI’s son, enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Let me sit heavy on thy soul tomorrow!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Think how thou stabbed’st me in my prime of youth$NEWLINE$At Tewkesbury. Despair therefore, and die!$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Be cheerful, Richmond, for the wrongèd souls$NEWLINE$Of butchered princes fight in thy behalf.$NEWLINE$King Henry’s issue, Richmond, comforts thee.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF PRINCE EDWARD$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) I will weigh heavily on your soul tomorrow. Remember how you stabbed me at Tewksbury, when I was just a young man. Despair, and die! (to RICHMOND) Be cheerful, Richmond—butchered princes fight for you. I, King Henry’s son, will provide you with comfort.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit
Enter the GHOST OF KING HENRY VI$NEWLINE$GHOST OF KING HENRY VI
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF KING HENRY VI enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF KING HENRY VI

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF KING HENRY VI$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) When I was mortal, my anointed body$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$By thee was punchèd full of deadly holes.$NEWLINE$Think on the Tower and me. Despair, and die!$NEWLINE$Harry the Sixth bids thee despair and die.$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Virtuous and holy, be thou conqueror.$NEWLINE$Harry, that prophesied thou shouldst be king,$NEWLINE$Doth comfort thee in thy sleep. Live and flourish.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF KING HENRY VI$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) When I was still alive, you punctured my body, the body of God’s blessed king, full of holes. Remember the Tower and me there. Despair, and die! Harry the Sixth commands you to despair and die! (to RICHMOND) Because you are virtuous and holy, you must be the conqueror! Harry, who prophesied that you would be king, comforts you in your sleep: live and prosper!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF CLARENCE$NEWLINE$GHOST OF CLARENCE
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF CLARENCE enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF CLARENCE

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF CLARENCE$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$I, that was washed to death with fulsome wine,$NEWLINE$Poor Clarence, by thy guile betrayed to death.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow in the battle think on me,$NEWLINE$And fall thy edgeless sword. Despair, and die!$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND) Thou offspring of the house of Lancaster,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The wrongèd heirs of York do pray for thee$NEWLINE$Good angels guard thy battle. Live and flourish.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF CLARENCE$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) I hope I weigh heavily on your soul tomorrow! It’s me, drowned to death in a nauseating barrel of wine. It’s me, poor Clarence, whom you betrayed to death! Tomorrow in battle, think of me and drop your useless sword. Despair, and die! (to RICHMOND) Offspring of the House of Lancaster, the wronged heirs of York pray for you. Good angels protect your fight! Live and prosper!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOSTS OF RIVERS, GRAY, and VAUGHAN$NEWLINE$GHOSTS OF RIVERS$NEWLINE$GRAY$NEWLINE$VAUGHAN
paragraphs.translated: The GHOSTS of RIVERS, GRAY, and VAUGHAN enter.$NEWLINE$GHOSTS$NEWLINE$RIVERS$NEWLINE$GRAY$NEWLINE$VAUGHAN

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF RIVERS$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Let me sit heavy in thy soul tomorrow,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Rivers, that died at Pomfret. Despair, and die!
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF RIVERS$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) I will weigh heavily on your soul tomorrow—I, Rivers, who died at Pomfret. Despair, and die!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF GREY$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Think upon Grey, and let thy soul despair!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF GREY$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Think about Grey, and despair!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF VAUGHAN$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Think upon Vaughan, and with guilty fear$NEWLINE$Let fall thy lance. Despair, and die!
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF VAUGHAN$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Think about Vaughan, and drop your lance from fear and guilt. Despair, and die!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: ALL$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Awake, and think our wrongs in Richard’s bosom$NEWLINE$Will conquer him! Awake, and win the day.
paragraphs.translated: ALL$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND) Awaken, and have faith that the wrongs Richard carries in his heart will defeat him! Awaken, and win the day!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOSTS OF the two young PRINCES$NEWLINE$GHOSTS OF$NEWLINE$PRINCES
paragraphs.translated: The GHOSTS OF the two young PRINCES enter.$NEWLINE$GHOSTS OF$NEWLINE$PRINCES

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: GHOSTS OF PRINCES$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Dream on thy cousins smothered in the Tower.$NEWLINE$Let us be lead within thy bosom, Richard,$NEWLINE$And weigh thee down to ruin, shame, and death.$NEWLINE$Thy nephews' souls bid thee despair and die.$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Sleep, Richmond, sleep in peace and wake in joy.$NEWLINE$Good angels guard thee from the boar’s annoy.$NEWLINE$Live, and beget a happy race of kings.$NEWLINE$Edward’s unhappy sons do bid thee flourish.
paragraphs.translated: GHOSTS OF PRINCES$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Dream about your nephews, smothered in the Tower. Let us rest in your heart as heavily as lead, Richard, and drag you down to ruin, shame, and death! Your nephews' souls command that you despair and die! (to RICHMOND) Sleep, Richmond, sleep in peace and wake in joy. Good angels will protect you from the boar’s attacks! Live, and give birth to a whole, happy race of kings! Edward’s unlucky sons want you to flourish.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF HASTINGS$NEWLINE$GHOST OF HASTINGS
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF HASTINGS enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF HASTINGS

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Bloody and guilty, guiltily awake,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$And in a bloody battle end thy days.$NEWLINE$Think on Lord Hastings. Despair and die!$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND) Quiet, untroubled soul, awake, awake.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Arm, fight, and conquer for fair England’s sake.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF HASTINGS$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) You violent, guilty man, wake up full of guilt and end your days in a bloody battle! Think about Lord Hastings. Despair, and die! (to RICHMOND) Quiet untroubled soul, wake up! Arm yourself, fight, and win for beautiful England’s sake!$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)
He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF ANNE$NEWLINE$GHOST OF ANNE
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF ANNE enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF ANNE

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF ANNE$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Richard, thy wife, that wretched Anne thy wife,$NEWLINE$That never slept a quiet hour with thee,$NEWLINE$Now fills thy sleep with perturbations.$NEWLINE$Tomorrow, in the battle, think on me,$NEWLINE$And fall thy edgeless sword: Despair and die!$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND) Thou quiet soul, sleep thou a quiet sleep.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$Dream of success and happy victory.$NEWLINE$Thy adversary’s wife doth pray for thee.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF ANNE$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) Richard, your wife, your wretched wife, Anne, who never enjoyed a quiet hour of sleep with you, now fills your sleep with disturbing thoughts. Tomorrow in battle think of me and fall on your sword: despair, and die! (to RICHMOND) You quiet soul, sleep a quiet sleep. Dream of success and happy victory. Your enemy’s wife is praying for you.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: She exits.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter the GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM
paragraphs.translated: The GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM enters.$NEWLINE$GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM

paragraphs.original: GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) The last was I that helped thee to the crown;$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$The last was I that felt thy tyranny.$NEWLINE$O, in the battle think on Buckingham,$NEWLINE$And die in terror of thy guiltiness.$NEWLINE$Dream on, dream on, of bloody deeds and death.$NEWLINE$Fainting, despair; despairing, yield thy breath.$NEWLINE$(to RICHMOND) I died for hope ere I could lend thee aid,$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$But cheer thy heart, and be thou not dismayed.$NEWLINE$God and good angels fight on Richmond’s side,$NEWLINE$And Richard fall in height of all his pride.
paragraphs.translated: GHOST OF BUCKINGHAM$NEWLINE$(to RICHARD) I was the first to help you to the crown and the last to feel the effects of your tyranny. Think of Buckingham when you’re fighting tomorrow, and die terrified of the sins you’ve committed! Tonight, dream of bloody deeds and death. Tomorrow, when you lose heart, fall into despair and then death. (to RICHMOND) I died before I could help you as I was hoping to. But be cheerful and don’t worry. God and good angels fight on your side, and Richard will fall at the height of his false pride.$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)$NEWLINE$(to$NEWLINE$)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD starts out of his dream$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD starts up out of his dream.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Give me another horse! Bind up my wounds!$NEWLINE$Have mercy, Jesu!—Soft, I did but dream.$NEWLINE$O coward conscience, how dost thou afflict me!$NEWLINE$The lights burn blue. It is now dead midnight.$NEWLINE$Cold fearful drops stand on my trembling flesh.$NEWLINE$What do I fear? Myself? There’s none else by.$NEWLINE$Richard loves Richard; that is, I and I.$NEWLINE$Is there a murderer here? No. Yes, I am.$NEWLINE$Then fly! What, from myself? Great reason why:$NEWLINE$Lest I revenge. What, myself upon myself?$NEWLINE$Alack, I love myself. Wherefore? For any good$NEWLINE$That I myself have done unto myself?$NEWLINE$O, no! Alas, I rather hate myself$NEWLINE$For hateful deeds committed by myself.$NEWLINE$I am a villain. Yet I lie. I am not.$NEWLINE$Fool, of thyself speak well. Fool, do not flatter.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Give me another horse! Bandage my wounds! Have mercy, Jesus!—Wait, I was only dreaming. Oh cowardly conscience, how you’re torturing me! The candles burn blue—that means it’s the dead of night. I’m sweating and trembling with fear. But what am I afraid of? Myself? There’s no one else here. Richard loves Richard, that is, there’s just me and myself here. Is there a murderer here? No. Yes, I am. Then run away. What, from myself? Yes, to avoid taking revenge on myself. Unfortunately, I love myself. Why? Did I do anything good to myself? Oh, no. Alas, I hate myself instead, because of the hateful deeds I’ve committed. I am a villain. But I’m lying; I’m not a villain. Fool, speak well of yourself. Fool, do not flatter yourself.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: My conscience hath a thousand several tongues,$NEWLINE$And every tongue brings in a several tale,$NEWLINE$And every tale condemns me for a villain.$NEWLINE$Perjury, perjury, in the highest degree;$NEWLINE$Murder, stern murder, in the direst degree;$NEWLINE$All several sins, all used in each degree,$NEWLINE$Throng to the bar, crying all, “Guilty! guilty!”$NEWLINE$I shall despair. There is no creature loves me,$NEWLINE$And if I die no soul will pity me.$NEWLINE$And wherefore should they, since that I myself$NEWLINE$Find in myself no pity to myself?$NEWLINE$Methought the souls of all that I had murdered$NEWLINE$Came to my tent, and every one did threat$NEWLINE$Tomorrow’s vengeance on the head of Richard.
paragraphs.translated: Give me another horse! Bandage my wounds! Have mercy, Jesus!—Wait, I was only dreaming. Oh cowardly conscience, how you’re torturing me! The candles burn blue—that means it’s the dead of night. I’m sweating and trembling with fear. But what am I afraid of? Myself? There’s no one else here. Richard loves Richard, that is, there’s just me and myself here. Is there a murderer here? No. Yes, I am. Then run away. What, from myself? Yes, to avoid taking revenge on myself. Unfortunately, I love myself. Why? Did I do anything good to myself? Oh, no. Alas, I hate myself instead, because of the hateful deeds I’ve committed. I am a villain. But I’m lying; I’m not a villain. Fool, speak well of yourself. Fool, do not flatter yourself.

paragraphs.original: Enter RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE enters.$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$My lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Zounds, who is there?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Damn it, who’s there?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Ratcliffe, my lord, ’tis I. The early village cock$NEWLINE$Hath twice done salutation to the morn.$NEWLINE$Your friends are up and buckle on their armor.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Ratcliffe, my lord, it’s me. The rooster has already crowed twice. Your friends are up and buckling on their armor.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$O Ratcliffe, I have dreamed a fearful dream!$NEWLINE$What think’st thou, will our friends prove all true?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh Ratcliffe, I had a terrifying dream! What do you think, will my friends prove loyal?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$No doubt, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$No doubt, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$O Ratcliffe, I fear, I fear.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Oh Ratcliffe, I’m afraid, I’m afraid—

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Nay, good my lord, be not afraid of shadows.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$No, my good lord, don’t be afraid of dreams.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$By the apostle Paul, shadows tonight$NEWLINE$Have struck more terror to the soul of Richard$NEWLINE$Than can the substance of ten thousand soldiers$NEWLINE$Armed in proof and led by shallow Richmond.$NEWLINE$'Tis not yet near day. Come, go with me;$NEWLINE$Under our tents I’ll play the eavesdropper$NEWLINE$To see if any mean to shrink from me.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$By St. Paul, ghosts have struck more terror in my soul tonight than ten thousand of worthless Richmond’s soldiers could, dressed up in their most sword-proof armor. It’s not yet daylight. Come with me; I’ll spy under the tents to see if any of my own people plan to desert me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit

paragraphs.original: Enter the lords to RICHMOND, sitting in his tent$NEWLINE$RICHMOND
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND’s LORDS enter his tent and go to where he is sitting.$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$LORDS

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$Good morrow, Richmond.
paragraphs.translated: LORDS$NEWLINE$Good morning, Richmond.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen,$NEWLINE$That you have ta'en a tardy sluggard here.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Pardon me, lords and gentlemen who stayed awake. You’ve caught me oversleeping.

paragraphs.original: A LORD$NEWLINE$How have you slept, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: A LORD$NEWLINE$How did you sleep, my lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$The sweetest sleep and fairest-boding dreams$NEWLINE$That ever entered in a drowsy head$NEWLINE$Have I since your departure had, my lords.$NEWLINE$Methought their souls whose bodies Richard murdered$NEWLINE$Came to my tent and cried on victory.$NEWLINE$I promise you, my soul is very jocund$NEWLINE$In the remembrance of so fair a dream.$NEWLINE$How far into the morning is it, lords?
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Since you left, I’ve been enjoying the sweetest sleep and most promising dreams I’ve ever had, my lords. I dreamed the souls of the people Richard murdered came to my tent and promised me victory. I tell you, I feel very jolly remembering such a beautiful dream. How late is it, lords?

paragraphs.original: LORDS$NEWLINE$Upon the stroke of four.
paragraphs.translated: LORDS$NEWLINE$It’s almost four.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Why, then ’tis time to arm and give direction.$NEWLINE$His oration to his soldiers$NEWLINE$More than I have said, loving countrymen,$NEWLINE$The leisure and enforcement of the time$NEWLINE$Forbids to dwell upon. Yet remember this:
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Why, then, it’s time to put on my armor and instruct the troops. (to his soldiers) I can’t tell you much right now, loyal countrymen, because we don’t have time. But know this:$NEWLINE$(to his soldiers)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: God and our good cause fight upon our side.$NEWLINE$The prayers of holy saints and wrongèd souls,$NEWLINE$Like high-reared bulwarks, stand before our faces.$NEWLINE$Richard except, those whom we fight against$NEWLINE$Had rather have us win than him they follow.$NEWLINE$For what is he they follow? Truly, gentlemen,$NEWLINE$A bloody tyrant and a homicide;$NEWLINE$One raised in blood, and one in blood established;$NEWLINE$One that made means to come by what he hath,$NEWLINE$And slaughtered those that were the means to help him;$NEWLINE$A base foul stone, made precious by the foil$NEWLINE$Of England’s chair, where he is falsely set;$NEWLINE$One that hath ever been God’s enemy.$NEWLINE$Then if you fight against God’s enemy,$NEWLINE$God will, in justice, ward you as his soldiers.$NEWLINE$If you do sweat to put a tyrant down,$NEWLINE$You sleep in peace, the tyrant being slain.$NEWLINE$If you do fight against your country’s foes,$NEWLINE$Your country’s fat shall pay your pains the hire.$NEWLINE$If you do fight in safeguard of your wives,$NEWLINE$Your wives shall welcome home the conquerors.$NEWLINE$If you do free your children from the sword,$NEWLINE$Your children’s children quits it in your age.$NEWLINE$Then, in the name of God and all these rights,$NEWLINE$Advance your standards. Draw your willing swords.$NEWLINE$For me, the ransom of my bold attempt$NEWLINE$Shall be this cold corpse on the earth’s cold face;$NEWLINE$But if I thrive, the gain of my attempt$NEWLINE$The least of you shall share his part thereof.$NEWLINE$Sound drums and trumpets boldly and cheerfully;$NEWLINE$God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!
paragraphs.translated:
We have God and a good cause on our side. The prayers of saints and those that Richard wronged support us like high-walled fortresses. Other than Richard, even those whom we fight against would rather we won. Because who is this man they follow? Truly, gentlemen, a violent tyrant and a murderer, who rose to his high position by shedding blood and kept the position the same way. He rose to the top by means of others and then slaughtered them. He’s like a worthless stone, who only seems like a valuable gem because he’s on the throne, where he doesn’t belong. He has always been God’s enemy. And when you fight God’s enemy, God will protect you. If you struggle to bring down a tyrant, you will sleep peacefully when the tyrant is killed. When you fight against your country’s enemies, you will be paid for your efforts with your country’s wealth. If you fight to protect your wives, your wives will welcome you home as conquerors. When you free your children from the sword, your grandchildren will repay you in your old age. So, in the name of God and all the good that will come of this
battle, march with your flags high and draw your swords. As for me, if I fail, the only ransom I will offer the enemy is my corpse. But if I succeed, every one of you will share in the profit. Play boldly and cheerfully, drummers and trumpeters. Here’s to God and Saint George! To Richmond and victory!$NEWLINE$battle$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$$NEWLINE$

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter King RICHARD, RATCLIFFE, attendants and forces$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD, RATCLIFFE, attendants, and soldiers enter.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RATCLIFFE

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What said Northumberland as touching Richmond?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$What did Northumberland say about Richmond?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$That he was never trainèd up in arms.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$That he was never trained as a soldier.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He said the truth. And what said Surrey then?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$That’s true. And what did Surrey say to that?

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$He smiled and said “The better for our purpose.”
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$He smiled and said, “The better for us.”

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He was in the right, and so indeed it is.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$He’s right, and that’s how it is.

paragraphs.original: The clock striketh
paragraphs.translated: The clock strikes.

paragraphs.original: Tell the clock there. Give me a calendar.$NEWLINE$He looks in an almanac$NEWLINE$He looks in an almanac$NEWLINE$Who saw the sun today?
paragraphs.translated: Read the time there. Give me an almanac. (looking in an almanac) Did anyone see the sun today?$NEWLINE$(looking in an almanac)

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$Not I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$I didn’t, my lord.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then he disdains to shine, for by the book$NEWLINE$He should have braved the east an hour ago$NEWLINE$A black day will it be to somebody. Ratcliffe!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Then it refuses to shine. According to this almanac, it should have risen an hour ago. It’ll be a black day for somebody today. Ratcliffe!

paragraphs.original: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$My lord.
paragraphs.translated: RATCLIFFE$NEWLINE$My lord?

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The sun will not be seen today.$NEWLINE$The sky doth frown and lour upon our army.$NEWLINE$I would these dewy tears were from the ground.$NEWLINE$Not shine today? Why, what is that to me$NEWLINE$More than to Richmond, for the selfsame heaven$NEWLINE$That frowns on me looks sadly upon him.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$The sun will not appear today. The sky frowns and scowls on our army. I wish there wasn’t so much dew on the ground. So, the sun won’t shine today! Well, why should that be worse for me than it is for Richmond? The same heaven that’s frowning on me looks gloomily on him.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter NORFOLK$NEWLINE$NORFOLK
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK enters.$NEWLINE$NORFOLK

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Arm, arm, my lord. The foe vaunts in the field.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$Get ready, my lord. The enemy is making its appearance on the battlefield.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Come, bustle, bustle. Caparison my horse.—$NEWLINE$Call up Lord Stanley; bid him bring his power.—$NEWLINE$I will lead forth my soldiers to the plain,$NEWLINE$And thus my battle shall be orderèd:$NEWLINE$My foreward shall be drawn out all in length,$NEWLINE$Consisting equally of horse and foot;$NEWLINE$Our archers shall be placèd in the midst.$NEWLINE$John Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Earl of Surrey,$NEWLINE$Shall have the leading of this foot and horse.$NEWLINE$They thus directed, we will follow$NEWLINE$In the main battle, whose puissance on either side$NEWLINE$Shall be well wingèd with our chiefest horse.$NEWLINE$This, and Saint George to boot—What think’st thou,$NEWLINE$Norfolk?
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Hurry, hurry—prepare my horse. Tell Lord Stanley to bring his army. I will lead my soldiers to the field and the battle formation will be like this: the vanguard will extend in a line that is equal parts horsemen and foot soldiers. The archers will stay in the middle. John Duke of Norfolk and Thomas Earl of Surrey will lead the horsemen and foot soldiers. I’ll follow in the center of the troop formation, which I’ll defend with my best horse, and with Saint George on my side, as well! What do you think, Norfolk?

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$A good direction, warlike sovereign.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$A good plan, warrior king. I found this pinned to my tent this morning.

paragraphs.original: He sheweth him a paper
paragraphs.translated: He shows RICHARD a piece of paper.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: This found I on my tent this morning.

RICHARD$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$(reads)$NEWLINE$Jockey of Norfolk, be not so bold.$NEWLINE$For Dickon thy master is bought and sold.$NEWLINE$A thing devisèd by the enemy.—$NEWLINE$Go, gentlemen, every man unto his charge.$NEWLINE$Let not our babbling dreams affright our souls.$NEWLINE$Conscience is but a word that cowards use,$NEWLINE$Devised at first to keep the strong in awe.$NEWLINE$Our strong arms be our conscience, swords our law.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$(reads) “Jackie of Norfolk, don’t be too bold, for Dick your master has been betrayed.” Something the enemy devised. Go, gentleman, every man to his command. Don’t let babbling dreams frighten us—conscience is just a word that cowards use to intimidate the strong. The strong fight we put on will be our conscience, our swords will be our law.$NEWLINE$(reads)

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: March on. Join bravely. Let us to it pell mell$NEWLINE$If not to heaven, then hand in hand to hell.$NEWLINE$His oration to his army$NEWLINE$What shall I say more than I have inferred?$NEWLINE$Remember whom you are to cope withal,$NEWLINE$A sort of vagabonds, rascals, and runaways,$NEWLINE$A scum of Bretons and base lackey peasants,$NEWLINE$Whom their o'er-cloyèd country vomits forth$NEWLINE$To desperate ventures and assured destruction.$NEWLINE$You sleeping safe, they bring to you unrest;$NEWLINE$You having lands and blessed with beauteous wives,$NEWLINE$They would restrain the one, distain the other.$NEWLINE$And who doth lead them but a paltry fellow,$NEWLINE$Long kept in Brittany at our mother’s cost,$NEWLINE$A milksop, one that never in his life$NEWLINE$Felt so much cold as overshoes in snow?$NEWLINE$Let’s whip these stragglers o'er the seas again,$NEWLINE$Lash hence these overweening rags of France,$NEWLINE$These famished beggars weary of their lives,$NEWLINE$Who, but for dreaming on this fond exploit,$NEWLINE$For want of means, poor rats, had hanged themselves.$NEWLINE$If we be conquered, let men conquer us,$NEWLINE$And not these bastard Bretons, whom our fathers$NEWLINE$Have in their own land beaten, bobbed, and thumped,$NEWLINE$And in record, left them the heirs of shame.$NEWLINE$Shall these enjoy our lands, lie with our wives,$NEWLINE$Ravish our daughters?
paragraphs.translated: March on, be brave in battle, and let’s go pell-mell to heaven, if not hand in hand to hell. (to his army) What more can I say? Remember who you’re dealing with—a random bunch of bums, rascals, runaways, Breton scum, and peasant hangers-on whom an overcrowded nation vomits out to populate every desperate, sure-to-fail enterprise. You have been sleeping soundly, and they bring unrest. You own land they want to steal. Those of you who are blessed with beautiful wives, they want to defile them. And who’s leading them but an inconsequential fellow who for the longest time lived in Brittany at his mother’s expense? A girly man, a man who never in his life felt more cold than seeps into one’s boots in the snow? Let’s send these stragglers back over the sea. Let’s whip these arrogant relics of France—these starving beggars, tired of their lives, who would have hanged themselves, poor rats, if it weren’t for this foolish enterprise they’ve been dreaming about—back to France. If we’re going to be conquered, let men conquer us, and not these French bastards whom our forefathers already beat, thrashed, and pummeled on their own turf, and shamed them forever in the history books. Should these people enjoy our lands? Sleep with our wives? Rape our daughters?$NEWLINE$(to his army)

paragraphs.original: Drum afar off
paragraphs.translated: Drum heard far off.

paragraphs.original: Hark! I hear their drum.$NEWLINE$Fight, gentlemen of England.—Fight, bold yeomen.—$NEWLINE$Draw, archers, draw your arrows to the head.—$NEWLINE$Spur your proud horses hard, and ride in blood.$NEWLINE$Amaze the welkin with your broken staves—
paragraphs.translated: Listen! I hear their drums. Fight, gentlemen of England! Fight, brave landlords! Draw your bows all the way back, archers! Spur your proud horses hard, horsemen, and ride in blood. Startle even the sky with the sound of your lances cracking.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Enter a MESSENGER$NEWLINE$MESSENGER
paragraphs.translated: A MESSENGER enters.$NEWLINE$MESSENGER

paragraphs.original: What says Lord Stanley? Will he bring his power?
paragraphs.translated: What does Lord Stanley say? Will he bring his army?

paragraphs.original: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, he doth deny to come.
paragraphs.translated: MESSENGER$NEWLINE$My lord, he refuses to come.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Off with his son George’s head!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Off with his son George’s head!

paragraphs.original: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$My lord, the enemy is past the marsh.$NEWLINE$After the battle let George Stanley die.
paragraphs.translated: NORFOLK$NEWLINE$My lord, the enemy has already passed the marsh. Let George Stanley die after the battle.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A thousand hearts are great within my bosom.$NEWLINE$Advance our standards. Set upon our foes.$NEWLINE$Our ancient word of courage, fair Saint George,$NEWLINE$Inspire us with the spleen of fiery dragons.$NEWLINE$Upon them! Victory sits on our helms.
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A thousand hearts beat in my chest. Let’s advance our flags, set upon our enemies, and have our ancient saint of courage, good Saint George, inspire us with the fury of fiery dragons! Let’s go! Victory is with us.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Excursions. Enter NORFOLK and forces fighting; to him CATESBY$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$CATESBY
paragraphs.translated: Blasts of military music (trumpets and drums) and flurries of soldiers fighting. NORFOLK and CATESBY enter with soldiers fighting.$NEWLINE$NORFOLK$NEWLINE$CATESBY

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Rescue, my lord of Norfolk, rescue, rescue!$NEWLINE$The king enacts more wonders than a man,$NEWLINE$Daring an opposite to every danger.$NEWLINE$His horse is slain, and all on foot he fights,$NEWLINE$Seeking for Richmond in the throat of death.$NEWLINE$Rescue, fair lord, or else the day is lost!
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Help, my lord of Norfolk, help, help! The king performs more wonders than seem humanly possible, challenging every enemy he sees. His horse is killed, so he’s fighting on foot, risking his life to search out Richmond. Help, dear lord, or the battle will be lost!
Blasts of military music (trumpets and drums).

paragraphs.original: Alarums. Enter RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHARD
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD enters.$NEWLINE$RICHARD

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$A horse, a horse, I’d give my kingdom for a horse!

paragraphs.original: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Withdraw, my lord. I’ll help you to a horse.
paragraphs.translated: CATESBY$NEWLINE$Get off the field, my lord. I’ll find you another horse.

paragraphs.original: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Slave, I have set my life upon a cast,$NEWLINE$And I will stand the hazard of the die.$NEWLINE$I think there be six Richmonds in the field;$NEWLINE$Five have I slain today instead of him.$NEWLINE$A horse, a horse, my kingdom for a horse!
paragraphs.translated: RICHARD$NEWLINE$Peasant, I have gambled my life on this one throw of the dice, and I’m willing to take what comes. I think there are six Richmonds on the field. I’ve killed five that looked like him, anyway. A horse, a horse! I’d give my kingdom for a horse!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Alarum. Enter RICHARD and RICHMOND. They fight. RICHARD is slain. Retreat and flourish. Enter RICHMOND, STANLEY bearing the crown, with divers other lords and soldiers$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$STANLEY
paragraphs.translated: Blasts of military music (trumpets and drums). RICHARD and RICHMOND enter; they fight. RICHARD is killed. The trumpet sounds to signal a retreat. RICHMOND retreats. RICHMOND and STANLEY, bearing the crown, return with several lords.$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$RICHARD$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$RICHMOND$NEWLINE$STANLEY

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$God and your arms be praised, victorious friends!$NEWLINE$The day is ours; the bloody dog is dead.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$God and your work be praised, victorious friends. The day is ours. The bloody dog is dead.

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(offering him the crown)$NEWLINE$(offering him the crown)$NEWLINE$Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee.$NEWLINE$Lo, here this long-usurpèd royalty$NEWLINE$From the dead temples of this bloody wretch$NEWLINE$Have I plucked off, to grace thy brows withal.$NEWLINE$Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$(offering him the crown) Courageous Richmond, you fought well. Here, I’ve taken back the stolen crown from that violent lowlife so it can grace your brows. Wear it, enjoy it, and make much of it.$NEWLINE$(offering him the crown)

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Great God of heaven, say amen to all!$NEWLINE$But tell me, is young George Stanley living?
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Great God of heaven, say amen to all this! But, tell me, is young George Stanley alive?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester town,$NEWLINE$Whither, if it please you, we may now withdraw us.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$He is, my lord, and safe in Leicester, where, if you’d like, we can retreat to.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$What men of name are slain on either side?
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Which gentlemen on each side have been killed?

paragraphs.original: STANLEY$NEWLINE$John Duke of Norfolk, Walter, Lord Ferrers,$NEWLINE$Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.
paragraphs.translated: STANLEY$NEWLINE$John Duke of Norfolk, Walter Lord Ferrers, Sir Robert Brakenbury, and Sir William Brandon.

paragraphs.original: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Inter their bodies as becomes their births.$NEWLINE$Proclaim a pardon to the soldiers fled$NEWLINE$That in submission will return to us.$NEWLINE$And then, as we have ta'en the sacrament,$NEWLINE$We will unite the white rose and the red.
paragraphs.translated: RICHMOND$NEWLINE$Bury them in a manner appropriate to their noble births. Proclaim that I’ll pardon the soldiers who fled if they will return and submit to my rule. As I vowed, I will unite the York and Lancaster families.

paragraphs.original: ORIGINAL TEXT
paragraphs.translated: MODERN TEXT

paragraphs.original: Smile heaven upon this fair conjunction,$NEWLINE$That long have frowned upon their enmity.$NEWLINE$What traitor hears me and says not “Amen?”$NEWLINE$England hath long been mad and scarred herself.$NEWLINE$The brother blindly shed the brother’s blood.$NEWLINE$The father rashly slaughtered his own son.$NEWLINE$The son, compelled, been butcher to the sire.$NEWLINE$All this divided York and Lancaster,$NEWLINE$Divided, in their dire division.$NEWLINE$O, now let Richmond and Elizabeth,$NEWLINE$The true succeeders of each royal house,$NEWLINE$By God’s fair ordinance conjoin together,$NEWLINE$And let their heirs, God, if thy will be so.$NEWLINE$Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace,$NEWLINE$With smiling plenty and fair prosperous days!$NEWLINE$Abate the edge of traitors, gracious Lord,$NEWLINE$That would reduce these bloody days again,$NEWLINE$And make poor England weep in streams of blood!$NEWLINE$Let them not live to taste this land’s increase,$NEWLINE$That would with treason wound this fair land’s peace.$NEWLINE$Now civil wounds are stopped, peace lives again.$NEWLINE$That she may long live here, God say amen.
paragraphs.translated: Heaven, for a long time you have frowned upon the hatred between them. Smile, then, on this beautiful union. What traitor hears me and doesn’t say amen? England has long been so crazy that she was willing to hurt herself, brothers blindly shed their brothers' blood, fathers rashly slaughtered their own sons, sons were forced to butcher their fathers. All this further divided the two families, which were already so badly divided. Now let Richmond and Elizabeth, the true heirs of each royal house, be joined together! And let their heirs, if you are willing, God, enrich the future with peace and plenty! Gracious Lord, blunt the swords of those traitors who mean to tear poor England apart again! Let those who would mar this fair land’s peace with treason die before they can enjoy its wealth. Civil wounds now can heal, and peace can live again. So that England may live a long life like this, let God say amen!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.
